Ottawa, May 16th—1900.

Sir:

With further reference to Department letter of the 12th March, and previous correspondence, I beg to enclose herewith Cheque No. 5185 for $2,500.00.

This Cheque represents the contribution of the Department toward the expenses of the removal of the Lac La Riche school buildings to Blue Quill's Reserve.

The reason for sending you this Cheque at the present time, is that the Reverend Father Leduc has called at the Department and represented that he furnished the late Indian Commissioner with full vouchers in triplicate for the expenditure mentioned above.

In order to expedite matters, the cheque is placed at your disposal; in order that, when you can satisfy the demand of the Department for proper detailed vouchers, you may endorse the cheque over to Father Leduc. The Reverend Father will call upon you in a few days upon his arrival in Winnipeg. I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Hon. David Laird,
Indian Commissioner,
Winnipeg,
Man.

Saddle Lake 29 Sept. 1902

The Secretary Department
of Indian Affairs
Ottawa

Sir,

The two following remarks have been found in
the Inspector's report upon the Blue Quill Boarding School:
"The boys dormitory is at present overcrowded..."
The inspector also mentions that facilities for
healthful exercise within doors are not good for lack
of space... there is an other serious defect. Should
some of our little people fall ill there is no infirmary
to keep them isolated.

Therefore Honorable Sir, I hereby apply for
obtaining from the Department a supply of
$2000.00 to help us in the erection of an additional
building. The first floor would be serviceable as
a recreation room, on rainy days and the second
story will be used as a dormitory for the boys.

At the same time I ask the Department a supply
of $400.00 which would help us to give a coat of
paint to the actual School building; otherwise it will
be destroyed very soon.

I will also make an other application, that,
instead of 45 boarders in the future we should
be allowed to admit 55 boarders or 60.

If the Department complies with this request,
and I hope they will—the future school building
could be arranged accordingly.

Hoping that you will kindly sanction
my request,

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

L. Balter.

Acting.
OTTAWA, 15th September, 1908

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter asking that the sum of $2000.00 be provided for the purpose of enlarging the accommodation at the Blue Quill boarding school and that $400.00 be also appropriated for the purpose of painting the school building as well as provision made for an increase in the number of pupils authorised from 45 to 55 or 60. In reply I beg to say that this matter has been referred to the Indian Commissioner for his report and you will be further advised.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean,
Secretary

Rev. L. Walter,
Acting Principal,
Blue Quill Boarding School,
Saddle Lake, Alta.

for Manitoba and the Northwest Territories,

Winnipeg, 24 Sept. 1902.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 18th instant, covering copy of a communication from the Acting Principal of the Blue Quill Boarding School in which he asks for certain appropriations.

The application for aid to erect an additional building for boys dormitory and recreation room, I am of opinion, should to some extent be granted. Mr. Inspector Chisholm in his report on the School last January stated there were 31 boys in attendance, and "the capacity of the dormitory is properly not sufficient for more than 22 to 24 pupils". He also remarked that "the facilities for healthful exercise within doors are not good".

But the amount asked for is rather too much. If the Department approve I would suggest placing in the estimates for the next financial year the following items:

Building for boys dormitory and recreation room.............$1200.00
Painting..................................................300.00
Fire protection..............................................100.00

$1600.00

An increase of 5 boarders, making the total number for the school 50, might also be allowed.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary

Indian Commissioner.

Dept. of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa.

Honorable D.C. Scott,
Superintendent of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Honorable Sir:

Knowing the interest you take in the welfare of our Indian Boarding Schools, we beg to present our needy case before you with the hope of receiving a favorable reply. As you know the conditions of our school, and have tried at different times to improve the school for the interests and benefit of our Indian pupils. We would be most grateful to you, if the Department could supply the school with an Electric Washer complete with the wringer attached to the washer and a quarter horse power motor. The size of the washer inside cylinder 27 x 30.

And a Dough Mixer with ½ horse power motor, size about 1/2 bag of flour mixing.
This would be very necessary for the pupils, to exempt the hard labor of these little ones.

Hoping to receive an early reply,

I am Honorable Sir,

Your obedient servant,

B. L. Derryberry

Sir:-

I have to inform you that the Rev. Principal of the Blue Quills Boarding School has applied to the Department for an electric washer, complete with wringer and one-half horse power motor; and a dough mixer with one-half horse power motor. I am informing the Principal that we are writing to you for your comment and recommendation, as the Department is somewhat in doubt as to the advisability of supplying this type of equipment to a small and not modern Indian boarding school.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

J. E. Pugh, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Saddle Lake,
Alta.
As an incentive to the operation and conduct of the school, such installation would be an asset, and I feel sure would be thoroughly appreciated by the Principal, and staff, whom as I have stated previously are constantly at work.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Dept of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Sir,

I have the honor to submit herewith my report in reply to Departmental letter No.18-1-5, of Oct 26th 22, re the advisability of installing certain machinery at the Blue Quills Indian Boarding School.

I beg to state that I have gone carefully into the matter, and have delayed sending my report in order to get the opinion of The Delco Light Co's expert, who has been out testing and adjusting the plant at that school.

In regard to the actual necessity of requiring a power washer and wringer, I would state that the work at present is done by hand machines, and requires two days to do the work of the institution, in which there are about 72 pupils and staff. I find that the elder girls have been assisting in this work, but there are only four or five, and three of them are about to be discharged, the work will then devolve on the Sisters mostly, as the girls remaining are much younger and will not be capable of doing much, though able to help in folding etc., and help in the light work.

In regard to the dough mixer, I find that some 23 lbs. of flour is used at one baking, and this entails considerable work in mixing by hand, and this work is done at present by the kitchen Sister.

From information obtained, re the machines asked for, I find that a washer would cost about $450.00 F.O.B. Warehouse, this has a capacity of about 25 sheets, or about 3 times that in clothing etc., and would accomplish the work in about 6 hours, this as will be seen would reduce the work on the staff to a very great extent, where I know are constantly at work. This machine would be run by a ½ H.P. Motor, and the power will be taken from the plant already installed. There is also a water supply on hand, so that apart from the cost of installing the machine, there should be no further expense.

In regard to the Mixer, this will cost about $120.00 F.O.B. Warehouse, and will also require a ½ H.P. Motor, this machine would reduce the work to about ½ an hour.

The Delco Light expert assured me that the plant is quite capable of running these machines, provided however that they are run separately, and also when the lights are not in use. In regard to the Motors, if this installation is allowed, I would suggest that the one motor could be used, and so save the cost of an extra motor of $100.00, this I know can be arranged.

In so far as actually recommended, it is admitted that the school is up to date, though it has all that is needed in machinery, still the cost of such machines would suggest that some firm in Edmonton be consulted, to insure that what is situated as this school is, would make such an outlay.
Ottawa, November 28, 1932.

Dear Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 14th inst., with reference to the washing machine asked for, for the Blue Quills Indian Boarding School, I beg to advise you that the Department is prepared to give favourable consideration to this request, but is not disposed to allow the machine to be operated by an electric motor obtaining its current from storage batteries, as this has proven in the past a very unsatisfactory method, and resulted in shortening considerably the life of the storage battery. It will therefore require a small gasoline engine to operate the proposed washing machine, and I would ask you to please advise me if the school has a one or two horse power gasoline engine that could be used in operating this machine.

This information is required before prices can be invited for the proposed machine.

Your obedient servant,

(J. D. McLean)
Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

J. E. Hugh, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Saddle Lake,
Alta.
BLUE QUILLS INDIAN BOARDING SCHOOL

1o-ELECTRIC WASHER:- The Principal asks for this washer complete with wringer attached to it and a Century horse power motor. The size of the washer inside cylinder is shown as 27 x 30. The School has a Delco Light Plant which gives complete satisfaction and according to an expert who has made a special examination of the plant a horse power motor of 32 volts direct current could be used for the machine above referred to.

2o-DOUGH MIXER:- A dough mixer holding about 1½ bag at one time complete with a horse power motor would be needed in Blue Quills School. I wish to note that the two machines (washer and dough mixer) would not be used at the same time.

I draw your attention to the above requests and would earnestly ask that they be included in the estimates.

Joseph [signature]
Sir,

I have the honor to state in reply to Departmental Letter No 118-1-5, dated Nov. 28th, that I find that there is only one Gas engine at the Blue Quilla School.

This engine is 7 H.P., used for pumping from the deep water well, and is situated some 60 yards from the school building and is a fixture in the pump house, and therefore could not be utilized for the proposed washer.

There is no other engine at the school.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant.

[Signature]

Dec. 5, 1922.

Mr. W.M. Graham, Indian Commissioner,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Regina.

Honorable Sir:

I wish to ask a favor. The Christmas Season coming on, brings with it many distressing problems, and many little hearts are filled with a great desire to receive, at least one gift, from Santa Claus. Here in our school, we have 58 stockings to fill, and our resources being very small, I find it a rather difficult task. Therefore I come to ask if I may count on your generosity to give us a little help, in order to procure for our little Indian children a Happy Christmas.

Hoping to receive a favorable reply,

I am,

Yours truly,

"Sister Cournoyer"
Supt.
Sir:

I enclose copy of a letter I have received from the Sister Superior of the Sacred Heart School in the Saddle Lake Agency, and if there are any funds available which can be drawn upon to make a contribution to this school to assist in adding to the enjoyment of the children at Christmas time, I shall be glad to recommend a grant to the school of $7.00 or $5.00 to purchase candies to place in the children's Christmas stockings.

May I ask for an early reply as the mail very often takes several days to reach Sacred Heart from Regina.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham
Indian Commissioner.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,

SPECIFICATIONS OF WASHER REQUIRED AT BLUE QUILLS INDIAN BOARDING SCHOOL, "SADDLE LAKE" -- ALTA.

SIZE: The inner cylinder shall be 36 inches in diameter by 54 inches in length and shall have one door and partition. Single ganged.

CYLINDER: Shall have heads and staves of Prime yellow pine with ribs of maple. Staves cut from 1-1/2 inch stock shall be nailed to heads cut from 2-inch stock. Shall be three large lifting ribs cut from stock 3 inches thick by 5 inches deep, also a 2-3/8 x 2-5/8 inch rib at iron and back of door opening rabbeted to receive door. Door shall be 16-1/2 inches wide. Door battens shall be all cast brass. Hinges shall be wide, heavy and of galvanized malleable and shall rest on bottom of door opening and on brass plates on front door rib. Catchers shall be of cast brass with wide lips. Cylinder shall be banded with wide and heavy hoops or galvanized iron fastened to the staves by means of brass screws.

TUB: Shall be constructed of 2-inch stock Sitka spruce with staves tongued and grooved and ginned to fit over heads to which they shall be nailed. A galvanized iron sliding door shall operate in grooves provided on adjustable encircling bands or hoops. A brass apron shall be fitted at the bottom of door opening to protect the staves. Shall be fitted with 1-inch water gauge glass with brass union elbow.

IRON FRAMES: Cast iron frames of sufficiently heavy design shall support the weight of the inside cylinder and outside tub and the driving mechanism shall be bolted to these frames. Frames shall be bolted to the tub heads and shall be absolutely rigid.

INLET AND OUTLET: Located in the center bottom of the tube shall be a combination cast iron flange tee through which the steam and water shall enter and waste water be discharged. Steam shall enter the tee through an annular steam passage carried in the tee without contact with the wood or linen. Connected with the tee shall be an outlet pipe on the end of which a 3-inch stopping valve or the hollow taper pipe type shall be fitted.

JOURNALS AND BEARINGS: Cast iron trunnions shall be cast into cylinder heads by means of brass covered bolts and inside trunnions shall be fitted with two brass trunion rings. Inside trunnions shall operate in babbitted bearings on the frames.

GEARING: Shall be machine cut from solid blanks and provide suitable cast iron guard. The main gear shall be of the type bolted and keyed to trunion journal. A gear lock shall be provided for holding cylinder door in position while loading.

AUTOMATIC REVERSE MECHANISM: Shall consist of 3-1/8 inch pulleys operating in conjunction with two belts and shaft movement, producing a fixed number of reverse revolutions. Cylinder, entire shifting mechanism shall be mounted on iron swiveling arm adjustable to belt at various points and be supported by bracket arm bolted to cast iron. Strength, simplicity and reliability.

Sir,

I have the honor to state, that the Principal of the Blue Quill's Boarding School, has brought to my attention the matter of New Desks, Teacher's desk and a Geography Globe, for this school.

During the Inspection of this School by Inspector Murison, it was noted that several children were sitting at forms and tables, and it was found that all the desks were small and hardly permitted of two children working in comfort. It is suggested that 18 large size single desks be purchased, subject to the approval of the Department, and which purchase I would recommend to make the accommodation comfortable at this school.

In the matter of the Teachers desk, it was noted that the present desk was supported on four pieces of tree, to make it convenient for the teacher to sit at. It was also badly warped, and hardly in keeping with the rest of the class room.

In regard to the Geography globe, I find that the Department refused to purchase a globe some time ago, but it would appear to me that this is almost a necessity in school, and the suggestion was also made by the Provincial School Inspector, and I would therefore ask the department to re-consider their decision.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Sir:

You should consult the Principal and ascertain from him the sizes of the desks he requires and the number of each. Sir:

The Department has been considering the supplying of a dough mixer, with a capacity of approximately 12 bags of flour, for the use of the Blue Quills Indian Boarding School. Kindly state as soon as possible whether this mixer, which would require a 3 H.P. to operate, could be used in connection with the Fairbanks-Morse engine that was supplied the school for laundry purposes. If the dough mixer is supplied, we could not allow it to be operated by an electric motor obtaining its current from the storage batteries in connection with the lighting system. Please state where it is proposed to install the mixer, as, if the power for same is obtained from the 3 H.P. gasoline engine, it will be by belt drive to pulleys on the dough mixer.

If possible, you may wire information asked by night telegram.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

ONE BARREL DOUGH MIXER

Fig. 1900-B44

This is a miniature of our Fig. 1511 machine and as are all our machines is guaranteed fully adjusted to working capacity, construction and finish.

It is designed to mix bread or cake doughs or cake mixtures of any kind very quickly, thoroughly and efficiently.

The packing boxes and bearings are the same as used on our Fig. 1511 machine and will not leak if kept adjusted and lubricated.

The entire weight of the tub and contents is carried on a bearing, independent of the beater shaft, leaving the beater shaft bearings free to do the mixing only.

The beater shafts are equipped with bronze sleeves which are non-corrosive and last indefinitely.

This, like our Fig. 1511 machine is so ruggedly constructed that in all the years we have been building it we have yet to find a broken beater arm.

The gears are machine cut and guarded to remove the possibility of accidents.

The dumping is done with a hand wheel at the rear engaging a worm and rack attached to the end of the tub. This works easily, quickly and free from danger as the tub cannot change position unless the operator turns the hand wheel.

If it is desired that the mixer dump into a trough of standard height it is necessary to block it up or place it on a platform and this platform should be 37" long by 28" wide by 9" high, constructed of 2" plank. The platform of course is not included in the price.

This machine is used extensively in the smaller bakeries, for bread and cake doughs and as a general utility machine. It is also used in the larger cake plants for rubbing and creaming, and for mixing cake doughs and batters, and on account of the splendid bearing construction it is impossible for oil to leak into the machine and discolor the batch.

This machine is a wonder for service and durability.

Our many years of experience in building single arm dough mixers has made it possible for us to offer you a machine unequalled in mixing qualities, construction and durability. The beater designs are correct for the greatest efficiency in mixing and their mixing qualities are unsurpassed.

There are many exclusive features embodied in the construction of these machines too numerous to mention, but we would particularly point out the special stuffing box with which our machines are equipped and
which insures you against leakage. These stuffing boxes are so arranged that anyone who can handle a monkey-wrench can repack them in a few moments and this is only necessary at very long intervals. Our special bearing arrangement, by means of which the weight of the barrel and contents is carried on a separate bearing independent of the beater shaft, eliminates the breakage of beaters, given longest life and reduces friction and operating costs to the minimum, and we believe we are the only concern building single arm dough mixers who can make the claim that we have never known of one of our beaters (or mixing arms) breaking.

The widespread use of these machines throughout the whole of Canada and the splendid letters of recommendation which we ultimately receive from our customers are evidences of the superiority of our mixers.

It is indeed a pleasure for us to quote you prices on this equipment and should we be entrusted with your order, we can assure you of delivery within ten days of receipt of order.

Yours very truly,

PENDRITH DOUGH MIXERS

Bulletin No. 15

It is now over Forty Years since the first Pendrith Dough Mixer was placed on the market. Since that time they have been in great demand by bakers, building up a reputation for efficiency and long service that extends from coast to coast.

The Mixers described in this Bulletin make up an excellent line of mixers for all classes of work in all sizes of plants. The high standards of workmanship and finish established by Pendrith Products will be rigidly adhered to, and the refinements in design and construction which we have added to the line will add to the fine reputation they already enjoy.

Direct Connected Motor Driven Mixers

The direct connected idea is rapidly becoming popular and full attention to this feature is paid by all Pendrith Mixers. The advantages are: saving reduction of space required, added safety, reduction in power consumed and freedom from trouble with belts, pulleys etc.

Owing to the great variation in the size of different types of mixers, it is not possible to give full particulars of the current type supplied as follows: (1) Voltage, (2) No. of cycles, (3) No. of phases, (4) diameter after mixing, (5) speed, (6) weight. The selection of proper machines will be greatly simplified if these details are given when asking for prices.

Extended Shafts and Clutches

When two or more of our direct connected mixers may be furnished with an Extended Shaft and Clutch, which allows of the running of another mixer from the shaft of another mixer without stopping the mixer. This Extended Shaft and Clutch can be used to advantage in operating a Moulder, a Cake Cutter, Flour Bag Elevator etc. The extra charge is small.

Blades revolve in the same direction giving the dough a stretching as well as a mixing operation. The blades are placed in such a position that they intersect, transferring the dough from one to the other.

The Bottom of the Barrel is shaped to conform to the radius of each of the blades, consequently it is impossible for any part of the contents to remain being thoroughly mixed.

All gears are machined and thoroughly ground. Celere driving pinions are provided, reduced noise to the minimum.

The simple stuffing boxes are readily accessible for repacking.

A complete Lubricating System is provided.

The weight of the Barrel and Contents is carried on a Trunnion Bearing placed at the side of the barrel, consequently the balance is maintained so that the whole is dumped without the strain and power required to lift the whole weight as is necessary in some machines.

When using the dumping lever the angle of the blades is such that the dough is thrown out into the trough with pressure in accordance from the operator.

All shafts running bronze bearings insulated throughout. Shafts are extra large and more than sufficient margin of strength is provided. Barrel ends and blades are machined to scrape closely.

Where an exceptionally smooth dough is desired in order that the finished loaf may be of the highest quality, this machine is strongly recommended.

The perfect development of the Gluten in the Flour and the Maximum yield from the materials used is assured by the thorough mixing and stretching process employed.

The two smaller sizes are recommended for the rapid and efficient mixing of cake doughs and batters in large quantities and nothing finer for this work is produced.

The Triumph Mixer

The Triumph Mixer we offer today contains many new features and refinements. These, with the quality materials used, the careful inspection of every piece while in operation, and methods used to secure accuracy in manufacture, add to the well known wearing qualities and efficiency of this Mixer.

Entire leg frame and base is one solid casting, insuring rigidity and avoiding any twisting strain on bearings.

The mixing bowl is made of a steel sheet riveted to cast-iron ends. The ends are cast with a trunnion or hub which is made to rest on a solid leg frame. These hubs support the bowl and contents and serve as a bearing for the bowl when turned down to dump. This relieves the shaft of any weight upon it, and allows it to work freely in its bearings. The cast-iron ends are planed smooth as are the ends of the mixing arm, enabling it to scrape the ends closely.

The mixing arm thoroughly mixes the batch without any other assistance, and when bowl is dumped will roll out the batch into the trough with one turn of the mixing arm.

The patent phosphor bronze stuffing-boxes are frictionless and insure no packing troubles; no leaks.

The special packing we use is similar to that used on the piston rod of a steam engine.

All gears and vital parts, including motor, are fully covered and enclosed, protecting them against dust and dirt. This also avoids possible accidents to the bakers.

The shifting lever, which is always within easy reach, is connected to a friction clutch with which the mixer is started or stopped without shutting off the power, and with this lever the mixing arm can be brought around to be cleaned quickly.

Rear of mixer base is open, for easy access to motor.

Gears are cut on automatic machines, therefor accurate and noiseless.

A canopy cover usually needed in connection with a flour hopper can be furnished for most sizes of mixers, or a flat hinged top when wanted.

The powerful and reliable friction clutch we use avoids any shocks and jars in starting up a Mixer and also avoids using a tight and loose pulley on a pulley driven machine.

Power dumps are applied only to the 3½ and 5 bbl. sizes of Gluten Developers and the Heavy-Duty Mixers.

Horsepower listed on each type of Mixer in this catalog is for the usual run of soft and medium doughs. If a very stiff dough is to be mixed daily, additional horsepower is needed.

To secure a more noiselessly running Mixer we are now using Micarta motor pinions.

These mixers have been designed by engineers who know the needs of the bakeshop, therefor are built not only for strength and durability, but also to produce a reliable machine simple in operation, requiring the least possible horsepower, one that will produce a perfect mix, and one that is easily cleaned and operated.

The Triumph service and guarantee are back of each Mixer.

Sir:

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter No. 407-4 A of the 22nd instant in regard to the telegraph office building and in reply, I beg to state that it is the intention apparently to remove this building to the school site. The distance is approximately five miles.

The building is lathed and plastered and is not of very sound construction and no doubt, if moved would require replastering throughout. It would be impossible to move this building until there was snow on the ground as I am quite sure that the building would not stand moving on rollers. The dimensions are 22' x 28' by 18' height with an office addition about 15' x 16'. The foundations are very poor.

Underdriven Solid Curb Extractor

Angle Countershaft

Size
Inside basket shall be 26 inches in diameter. Countershaft shall be angle type.

Basket
Shall be constructed with sides perforated with sufficient number of holes to permit free discharge of extracted water, heavily galvanized inside and out, and riveted to top and bottom of basket. Bottom shall be of cast iron, cored to make a double web, truly machined, and inside surface covered with sheet copper, heavily tinned. Top shall be reinforced with a steel ring spun into place. A series of steel bands shall be fitted to basket sides to reinforce same. Basket shall be tested for running balance at rated speed.

Curb and Base
Outside curb shall be an extra heavy one-piece casting and standard or base shall also be cast in one piece. Curb and base shall be securely bolted together, becoming in effect one solid, rigid casing. Curb shall be equipped with drain openings in bottom and fitted with detachable cast-iron top ring.

Safety Cover
Shall be equipped with hinged safety cover.

Safety Bumper and Spindle
Rubber safety ring shall be fitted on bottom of basket and so arranged that when basket is unevenly loaded the rubber shall engage with curb bottom, thus preventing basket from striking outer curb while finding its balance. Basket shall be supported on spindle-steel spindle, equipped with clutch pulley. Spindle shall be turned and ground to size and taper fit in basket bottom. Shall be secured by a brass lock nut. Lower end of spindle shall have a syphon arrangement, consisting of a hollow chamber, forming an oil reservoir for circulation of oil around the spindle. See sectional view on reverse side.

Balancing Device
Base casting shall be constructed with a detachable well casting for receiving the balancing device. In said casting shall be located a phosphor-bronze sleeve bearing for receiving spindle.
Underdriven Solid Curb Extractor—Continued

Angle Countershaft

provided with flange above and below which shall be located rubber spring cushions, engaging flanges on well casting, and held in place by a spanner nut threaded in well casting. Shall be provided with three hardened, double convex, tool-steel buttons at bottom of bearing, on which spindle shall operate. Oil nuts shall be fitted on top of bearing in such a manner as to feed oil to spindle and furnish a tight joint, to prevent oil from coming in contact with rubbers.

Brake

Extractor shall be fitted with a friction foot brake attached to base, working on spindle pulley. Shall be equipped with locking device, to prevent sudden shock and hold brake in position until basket stops revolving.

Countershaft and Idlers

Shall have countershaft belted to curb and base, forming a self-contained part of the machine. Shall consist of a cast-iron bracket supporting the shaft with its tight and loose pulleys and friction driving pulley, and also guide or idler pulleys. One of the idler pulleys shall be equipped with an adjustable device for taking up slack in belt.

Sir,

I beg to inform you that at about 11-30 o'clock last night, the stable at the Blue Quills Residential School was completely destroyed by fire. The stable was a frame structure about 80 feet by 40 feet, and at the time of the fire, contained four sets of harness, six head of horses, about 55 loads of hay and a bin full of oats, all of which were destroyed along with the barn. An adjoining building containing a grain crusher and a quantity of chop was also destroyed. The origin of the fire is unknown. The fire had apparently gained such headway when first noticed that it was impossible to save anything in the buildings. I was notified this morning and immediately proceeded to the scene of the fire. I made careful enquiries but was unable to discover the cause. Apparently all of the children and staff at the school were in bed when the fire started.

I have advised building log stables for temporary use, as there is no accommodation for their stock of which about 35 head are usually kept in.

The Principal, Miss Tabillon, is in hospital at present, and in discussing the matter of the fire with the Sister Superior in charge of the School, she informed me that they had been given to understand that a motor truck was to be furnished by the Department next year. In view of the loss of their work horses she asked if it would be possible to supply them with a truck as soon as possible in order that it may be used for hauling their grain and supplies this fall. The Sister Superior informs me that they now have two small horses only with which to carry on their work, and that while she intends purchasing another team, she considers that they would not at present require any more than a heavy work team and the two small horses, providing a motor truck were furnished.

Your obedient servant,

I forward for your information the report of his visit in April to the Blue Quills Indian residential school by Mr. W. E. Gullion, Indian Agent at Saddle Lake.

Honourable Sir,

Newly appointed Principal of the Blue Quill's Residential School, Saddle Reserve, Alta., I found that school in a very poor condition. The buildings and machineries are pretty old and continually requiring repairs. I may add that it is useless to repair them on account of their age, and moreover I am not able to bear the cost of such repairs.

It will be very difficult to live this winter in the school building, and it will be impossible to stay in it next winter.

I am told that last year you saw by yourself that state of things.

as the spot is already chosen and the well dug. I hope for the sake of the Indian children the Department will take the matter in hand and act diligently.

Re- Blue Quill Indian School, St. Paul, Alta.

Sir:

In accordance with your instructions I called on the Commissioner of Irrigation, Calgary, (Mr. Tempest) and asked for the site plan of the above mentioned school. Mr. Tempest said their Mr. Jennings had the matter in hand, and Mr. Jennings took me to their Mr. French who had been to the site more recently, and who had gathered data bearing on the situation.

Mr. French showed me several sheets of drawings showing profiles, contours, etc., of the locality, and unfinished plans of water systems and sewage disposal works. Mr. French said that before completing the plans for these auxiliary services he would like to confer with me on the site, and as I was leaving next day for St. Paul, Mr. French came too.

On arrival at the school site I found that the well which had been drilled was choked with quicksand. Its original depth of 465 feet now measures only 335 feet by actual test. Had it not been for Mr. French's assurance that he checked the original measurement, I should be inclined to doubt the correctness of the greater depth claimed. Apparently the quicksand has risen 133 feet from the bottom of the well, thus shutting off the water vein at the bottom of the casing. Although there is now 240 feet of water in the well, which comes to a point 95 feet below the surface of the ground, we have a solid column of quicksand below, of 133 feet depth, which at present effectually shuts off the water intake. Moreover, Mr. French informs me that at the end of a 48 hours' test which he supervised personally, the pump raised the water at a rate only slightly over 3 gals. per minute, and that at the end of this period the quicksand choked the cylinder, thus stopping the pumping.

This well is of very doubtful value, and entirely inadequate even if it functioned at all. The contractors are now on the ground erecting their camp, and the excavating has been let to a local teamster. I asked that no excavating be started until the water supply is assured, and this work is being deferred in consequence.

We sent for a local driller, and Mr. French arranged with him to commence drilling another well next Tuesday, the 24th instant.
about 6 or 8 feet to one side of the existing hole. I am told that water is usually found in the locality at a depth of about 120 feet, but that in the previous case the driller had cased off this vein in order to get softer water at the greater depth. We have a different driller this time, and one said to be much more reliable, and he is very sanguine of getting ample water from a comparatively shallow well. Even if this water from the nearer vein does prove somewhat hard, I should hesitate to incur the expense of deeper drilling in view of the recent experience, and soft water for boiler and laundry purposes could be got by means of a rain-water cistern such as we installed at Old Suns School for this very purpose.

I am leaving today for Gleichen to get things wound up there, and to issue the final Certificate to the Wyndels Co. I aim at returning to St. Paul next Friday, the 27th inst., to be present to put a baling test on the new well, and to satisfy myself of a sufficient water supply before allowing the construction work to proceed. The contractors' representative, Mr. Borgford, Jr. fully concurs in the action I am taking in this regard; in fact he says they could not carry on their work with the present inadequate and precarious water supply.

Mr. French is also returning to Calgary, and will go ahead with his plans for water storage on the assumption that sufficient water will be secured from the new drilling. I will advise the Department promptly by wire of the results of the further efforts to secure sufficient water.

The conditions for sewage disposal are not good, but we shall try to work out a feasible scheme, and I shall make this feature the subject of a later letter.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Inspector of Construction.
I am leaving tomorrow evening for St. Paul. By the time I reach there the drill should be down to water in the well now being drilled for the Blue Quill School, and I wish personally to test the capacity of the well beyond all peradventure. Until a sufficiency of water is assured I deem it unwise to proceed with building construction. I am not anticipating any hitch in this regard, and expect very soon to be able to advise the Department that an abundance of water has been secured.

Re- Blue Quill School, near St. Paul, Alta

Sir:

As already intimated, there has been some delay getting the well-drilling rig hauled to the school site. Owing to heavy rains the roads became almost impassable, and the driller was four days hauling his rig the 20 miles to the site. After playing out his horses he finally had recourse to a caterpillar tractor, and finally succeeded reaching the job last Thursday evening, the 26th instant. This information I received by wire and long-distance phone after reaching Calgary on my way north. I therefore returned to Gleichen, as I deemed it useless going there until at least two or three days' drilling had first been done.

I shall leave here for Calgary on the evening train, and take the midnight train for Edmonton, and shall arrive at St. Paul to-morrow, the 30th instant. I shall be on the site on Tuesday, July 1st, and shall make a very careful and accurate check-up of the well which should be brought in by about that time, and shall wire the Department as soon as a sufficiency of water is assured; and shall supplement the wire with a written report.

Just as soon as the water supply is proven I shall allow the contractors to proceed with the excavating.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Sir,- I beg to submit the following report on my inspection in connection with the proposal to improve the water supply of the Edmonton Indian Residential School near St. Albert, Alberta.

Date of inspection: June 27, 1930.

Since I reported on this water supply on May 10, 1929, several improvements have been made. In the first place an underground rain water tank has been constructed of about 9,000 gals. capacity. Water is drawn from this by means of a steam ejector to supply the small service tank from which the boilers draw their supply by their own injectors; provision is also made for heating the tank by means of a jet of steam; last winter, the rain water supply being insufficient, snow was shovelled into the tank and melted by this jet. This work appears to have been very economically carried out.

The power head or pump jack which was condemned in my last report has been replaced by a new Myers self oiling power head; repairs have also been made to the drop pipe and pump rods in the well which makes them more accessible.

Additional hydrants have been provided in the building.

It has been proposed, and I understand sanctioned, to bring power in from the Calgary Power Company's line which I believe is about 1½ miles away at present. I have not concerned myself with the details of this, but assume for this report that three phase, 60 cycle, 110-120 volt electricity will be available.

I further understand that the purchase of a 7½ h.p. motor to replace the gasoline engine driving the pump jack has been sanctioned.

The proposed improvements outlined by Mr. Woodsworth are briefly as follows.

1. To drill a new well about 20 feet from the existing well in a position where he feels sure of tapping the same supply at a depth of 165 or 175 feet; the power head at this well to be worked from the same motor as the existing well by means of a line of shafting.
2. To put in two additional 1000-gallon pressure tanks in line with the existing two and a small one at the pump house to supply the stock watering troughs.

If we accept the general principle of these improvements I should modify them slightly. The location of the new well is chosen because Mr. Woodsworth feels certain that it is possible to get water there from the same source as the existing well. This is quite true, but I think that if a new well is drilled it is worth while attempting to strike an independent source of supply. Last year there seemed to be good reasons for putting the new well near the boiler house and I think these reasons still hold. I consider that an expenditure up to $400 would be justified in trying out another site before returning to the locality of the original well.

In any case I should prefer the pumping machinery on the new well to be entirely separate unit. This need not entail increased expenditure as a 12" stroke power head with air compressor attachment coupled to a 5 h.p. motor with automatic starter equipment can be purchased for less than the price of the power head on the existing well and will be quite sufficient to supply the school. The provision of an automatic starter will ensure the pressure tanks being reasonably full at all times instead of practically empty as they must be in the mornings at present.

The proposed small pressure tank in the pump house can be almost automatically eliminated. A check-valve will be needed above each well to prevent one pumping into the other; at present there is a check-valve at the pressure tanks in the boiler house which prevents back pressure on the well. If this be removed to just above the well the farm trough can be fed from the pressure tanks.

The cost of this installation will be as follows:

Allowance for trial well (may not be needed) $400.
Cost of well 175 feet deep with 5 5/8 casing 4" drop pipe, brass cylinder and cypress rods. $1000.
Myers 12" stroke self-oiling working head with 5 h.p. 3 phase motor, air compressor and automatic starter 420.
Two 1000-gal. pressure tanks each $500 1000.
Valves and piping 80.
Housing pump, motor and pressure tanks 400.
Contingencies 300.

$3600

If a well of good quality and quantity be obtained and this machinery be installed, the school will have a first class water supply for domestic purposes.

I do not feel that the same can be said about fire protection. The two existing pressure tanks and the two new ones will have a total capacity of 4000 gallons but when deduction is made for air space, and the probability of them being partially empty, about 2000 gallons is the
most that can be relied on in case of fire. This might give about twenty minutes supply at two nozzles, in which time the two pumps would supply about 400 gallons additional.

There is the rain-water tank with a capacity of about 9000 gallons; it had to be filled with snow last winter, and is almost empty at present. The water in it is there to be used and is only replaced when rainfall occurs. In the circumstances I do not consider that any expenditure on pumping machinery to make it available in case of fire would be justified. If water is in this tank when the fire brigade arrives from Edmonton it will be available for them to use.

Although the main shell of the building is of brick and hollow tile construction this quantity of water appears to be a somewhat meagre provision. If development is to be along the lines set out above further pressure tank storage can be provided at $0.80 to $1.00 per gallon of water actually available for fighting fire up to the limit that the Department is able to spend.

On the other hand a 20,000-gallon elevated tank 100 feet high (the building is about 50 feet) would cost in the neighbourhood of $8,000 and could be kept practically full so that water would be available at about 40¢ per gallon.

By the method outlined in my report last year some 20,000 gallons exclusive of rainfall would be available for fire fighting purposes at a cost on an equivalent basis of between $5000 and $6000 or about 28¢ per gallon. This system suffered from the disadvantage that it would be necessary to start up an engine if a fire should occur.

As regards the pressure, the pressure-tanks would give the best pressure at first, while the pump method would give more than the elevated tank, but the last mentioned method would be the least liable to break down.

It is very difficult to decide upon a recommendation without some knowledge of how much the Department is prepared to spend and unwise to make partial expenditures which do not form part of a co-ordinated whole.

If the Department is only prepared to spend some $3,000 or $4,000 then the scheme set forth seems to be the best, but if the amount they have available exceeds $6,000 and particularly if it amounts to $8,000 I should recommend that it be spent upon storage and fire fighting equipment rather than well drilling.

The existing well is an excellent well; its quality is fair although it contains some soda which makes it unpalatable after storage. In quantity it is quite adequate. It is said to have yielded 40 gallons per minute on test without lowering. When I was there last week the pump was only making 18 strokes per minute or about 10 gallons. Even on a laundry day it would apparently not run more than half time so that there is a large reserve supply.
The case for an additional well is based upon the possibility of a break-down. This might happen through the failure of the engine or motor drive or of the power head or of something going wrong in the well itself such as a break of the rods or the drop pipe. I am also informed that sand is coming slowly into the well and that at some date it will require cleaning out.

The repairs to the well have removed most of the dangers of a break-down there and the existing gasoline engine might serve as a stand-by to the motor already sanctioned, so that the case for an additional well does not seem so strong as it was a year ago.

If storage is provided the objection to using the stored water for drinking purposes could be overcome by bye-passing it and using directly from the existing system; while the taste might be endured for the time when repairs are being made.

I am not prepared to say that a second well will not be required at some date but my own opinion is that with adequate storage it can be indefinitely delayed.

My report of last year included a considerable amount for piping separate firelines to the hydrants and for other fire fighting equipment, which may be eliminated if it is not considered desirable to spend so much money. It would also appear that by helping the contractor with labour and cartage Mr. Woodsworth can carry out concrete and building work at a cheaper rate than a direct contract can be let at.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd) F. R. Burfield

Sir:

The work of construction on the above-mentioned building is now away to a good start, there being at present about 30 men on the McDiarmid Co.'s pay-roll.

The excavation is now completed, and the top soil has been stacked by itself so as to be available for the top covering of the ground later on.

To-day a start was made on the running of concrete, and the pier footings were placed, all heavily reinforced with steel, as called for in the specifications.

An enormous pile of rocks has been hauled by local residents, and the contractors' rock-crushing plant is in daily operation breaking up the stone to suitable sizes.

After a good deal of prospecting suitable sand was found about two miles from the building site. The pit is being opened out more, and the top covering of soil removed, and I'm hopeful we shall get sufficient sand from this source to complete the job. It is unusually good sand, coarse, full of tiny particles of disintegrated stone, and in conjunction with the crushed rock should give us excellent concrete. In a careful check-up of the concrete mixture to-day, I found it necessary to add about 20% more sand, reducing about 20% of the rock, and keeping the cement the same, in order to get the best consistency for the footings. The deviations referred to mean, of course, deviations from the proportions mentioned for walls in the specifications, and applies only to the pier footings where we have the reinforcing. For the wall footings, and for the walls themselves, we shall watch the mixture closely, and I think we may get good results with about a 10% increase of sand, and a corresponding 10% decrease of rock, and the same quantity of cement as specified. A large steam concrete mixer is being used.
The contractors have erected suitable camp buildings, a good cook and capable helper are providing good meals, for which the men are being charged 45¢ per meal.

Building materials are arriving by every train, and being hauled out to the site by tractor power. The steel and stone plans have been sent to me for approval, and I am returning them as quickly as I can, with slight changes asked for in the steel in the basement steel plan, particularly in increasing the reinforcing.

I shall be pleased to learn the Department's intention with regard to the electric service for this school. I understand Mr. Jennings, of the Water & Reclamation Branch of the Department of the Interior has been gathering data on the subject, but I have not heard the outcome.

The well that was drilled lately seems to be holding up well under present demands, and all the indications point to a sufficiency of water for the use of the school. So far there is a cloudiness in the water which indicates the presence of a very fine sand, but this may lessen as more water is drawn through the vein. At any rate I shall watch it in this regard.

I expect to go to Gleichen for a couple of days the last week in this month to check up on some work that was still to be done when I came away. Also, I shall likely have the two or three accounts of Wyndels Co.'s creditors which had not been confirmed when I sent the rest of the accounts forward, and when these are dealt with the Wyndels affair can be closed out.

Our weather is fine here, and the crops could scarcely look better hereabouts.

Will you please send me a supply of Certificate blanks, and stationery.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Sir:

In reference to the water supply for the Indian School at St.Paul, a report has now been received from Mr. M.H.French. He states that well No. 2 is now completed and at 104' water was obtained and is standing at 57' in the hole. A baling test made produced 305 gallons per hour and reduced the water to a 35' level. A second baling test produced 600 gallons per hour and lowered the water to a 25' level. The water is hard but good for drinking purposes. Some coarse gravel and sand were found at the 104' level and a little fine sand was raised in the water while baling. The contractors are now making preparations to install a temporary pumping plant to use this water in connection with their work.

The deep test well, it has been revealed, is not filled with quicksand as previously reported. From investigations made by Mr. French it would appear that a boulder had been dropped into the well which lodged at a point 335' from the surface. In an effort to pull the inside casing this boulder became dislodged and fell to the bottom of the well. In all probability, this well will supply all the soft water required and also serve as an emergency well.

The well driller has now left and settlement for work completed has already been made with him, details of which will be forwarded to you at a later date.

GLEICHEN, Alta.

Re- Blue Quills School, St. Paul, Alta.

Sir:

I had a call today from the plumbing, heating, roofing and sheet metal contractor (Mr. Reeve, of Lethbridge) and we went over the plans and specifications together as relating to his manifold sub-contracts. Several suggestions were made as to slight changes, viz:

1. No grease traps are specified for the scullery. If we are to provide one for each scullery sink, of the water-jacket type, connected up complete, they will cost $94.00 each.

2. In the specifications the self-closing faucets are mostly in staff rooms, and in the boys' and girls' wash rooms the faucets are the compression type, which are not self-closing. Should we not reverse this arrangement? We did so at Gleichen. The difference in cost would be $112.00

3. Should the vents from the boys' and girls' lavatories not be extended to vent the toilets, as was done at Gleichen. This would cost $50.00.

4. Mr. Reeve recommends that the basement rads be raised to come above the level of the steam mains, so as to heat freely at times when the pressure is low. Mr. Walker, of Dunham Co., holds the same view. There would be no extra charge if arranged for in advance.

5. It is suggested that both chimneys be raised 10 ft. above the highest point of roof in order to get good draft. There is a knoll covered with trees near by which might affect the draft when the wind is from that quarter, and this in conjunction with the circulation around the area walls of the roof, might have an adverse effect on the draft. An extra 7 ft. would give us a 10 ft. clearance above the roof. I have no price on this, but would expect the extra height to cost about $20.00 per foot.

6. Owing to the hardness of the water which we are using from the last well drilled, and which gives no lather at all with ordinary soap, it would seem advisable to provide a rain water cistern. This could be placed either beneath laundry floor, or just outside the laundry, my own preference being inside, covered with a reinforced concrete slab finishing flush with the laundry floor, with manhole opening, and overflow to laundry drain. We followed this plan at Gleichen, with every satisfaction. The
soft water would be available both for the laundry and heating boilers, probably about a 4000 gal. cistern would serve all purposes, and while I have no price on this proposed cistern, it would likely cost from $450 to $500 complete with intake and outlet connections. The firm's estimator will give an exact figure when he comes to the job again, but it will be about what I quote.

7. Should we place concrete slabs over any of the ceilings below the roofs? At Gleichen we did so over the ceilings of the rear extension, but Mr. Orr arrived at the job at about that time and decided to omit the slabs over the top ceilings of the main building and residence. Please let me know what we should do here.

8. The roof space between the ceilings and roof should, perhaps, be ventilated to insure against condensation forming on the under side of roof and dripping on to the ceilings immediately beneath. We made small openings into the ventilating flues at Old Suns to provide ventilation, but a better plan would be to do so by means of vents through the roof itself. This will be the more necessary where we omit the top slab. Will you please let me know your wishes in this regard.

There will be other matters about which I shall write the Department,—for instance, the water supply and sewage disposal—but I shall defer doing so until complete plans are worked out. In the meantime will you kindly instruct me on the 8 points mentioned in the foregoing paragraphs.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Re- Pole Line to Blue Quills Indian School.

Gentlemen:

In compliance with the request in your letter of the 9th instant, I called on the various owners of the land across whose properties the suggested alternative route 1' north or south of the quarter line through Sections 7 and 12 would be built. In order that any arrangements made with the several owners might be legal and binding, and not subject to being revoked by a possible change of mind, I deemed it prudent to have a legal form prepared. As Mr. A.U. Lebel, solicitor, of St. Paul, had previously conducted business for your Company in this locality, I asked him to prepare the legal papers, which he has done.

Having obtained the names of the owners of the land to be traversed, I called on them in turn. A certain patriarch named Charron, who seems to be father-in-law to many persons in this neighborhood, including one or two owners of the affected land, has advised his "in-laws" against consenting to the line crossing their respective properties. This objection applies particularly to his son-in-law, Mr. Chamberland, because of the fact that Mr. Chamberland has no divisional fence, and this suggested line would cross a wheat field, and be a great handicap in the future farming of his half section. I received a message from Mr. Chamberland yesterday to the effect that he will fight it in the Court rather than submit to the proposed pole line crossing the middle of his farm.

Mr. Chamberland, however, is quite agreeable to signing an agreement giving your Company the right to place poles on the south boundary of his property contiguous to the main highway to St. Paul, and will consent to the poles being placed up to 10' on his land, if necessary. The other owners of the affected properties are equally willing to sign up for the pole line to come this way.

In view of this development, I 'phoned your Calgary office.
asking if it would not be feasible to meet the wishes of the various land owners affected by bringing the line just inside of their south boundaries, and at the same time keeping off the main highway as made necessary by the decision of the Provincial gov't. Your office replied that the matter would be considered, and that I would receive your answer by early telegram. I went to town the next morning, and as no answer had come up till noon, I wired again. About the middle of the afternoon I received your wire in reply, in which you stated that in the event of the main highway being widened at some future time your Company would be under the expense of moving the pole line; and you asked me, if possible, to obtain the consent of the owners to the line crossing their land as per your sketch accompanying your letter of the 9th instant.

Mr. Lebel suggests inserting a clause in the agreements providing that in the event of the main highway being widened, the owners will give the right to the Company to move the poles the same respective distance on their south boundaries as applies in their present proposals. As this highway is of the standard width now, the prospect of it being widened seems so remote as to be negligible. In the interests of harmony, and as the extra distance is not serious, my own recommendation would be to fall in with the wishes of the local residents affected, and build the pole line close to their south boundaries.

I may say the Town Council has officially consented to the building of the line within the town limits, as requested, and a copy of the Resolution may be obtained at any time.

I am enclosing the sketch you first sent me, in which I show another possible route to follow which for the most part would follow the road allowance 1 mile north of the main highway to St. Paul. If this route were adopted, we should just require the consent of two owners, viz., Mr. Guimond, and Mr. Lessard, and I believe their consent could be obtained without difficulty. In this case the pole line would skirt the edge of the railway right-of-way until reaching the road allowance along the N.W. quarter of Section 8. In your sketch the railway line seems to be shown too far north of Main Street, and I have indicated in pencil its approximate exit from the town.

From the foregoing, you will see that there are two possible routes, to which there are no objections from local residents, and I think you can now go ahead and give the Indian Department a tender for providing electric service to the school by either one of the routes indicated, or alternative tenders in case there should be any considerable difference in the cost as between the suggested routes. The owners whose land the line may cross will accept compensation on a basis not exceeding $5.00 per pole.
I'm afraid, however, we shall have to abandon the idea of crossing the owners' farms as suggested in your communications on account of the opposition that has developed.

Whatever legal papers you may require to be signed by the land owners affected can either be prepared by Mr. Lebel, or if you have your own regular forms they could be sent to him, as he is now in touch with the owners, and could have said owners call and execute the papers at his office.

As I am desirous of having the electric current brought to the school site as soon as possible I shall appreciate a tender from you at your earliest convenience. I shall then take the matter up with Ottawa and get a prompt decision.

Yours very truly

Sir,

Report on Sewage Disposal Works for the Blue Quill Indian Residential School at St. Paul, Alberta.

Introductory.

The Blue Quill Indian Residential School now under construction is located four miles by road west of St. Paul de Metis, Alta., upon a branch line of the Canadian National Railways 127 miles easterly from Edmonton. The school is located in a school section in a well settled community.

Topographically the section is undulating with no decided slope in any direction. There are many small depressions which apparently overflow into the large shallow slough in the SW¼ of the section.

A gravity sewage disposal plant was found impossible. A gravel sub-irrigation disposal bed was considered expensive and unnecessary. It was ultimately decided to build a standard septic tank similar with one exception to that used at the McIntosh Indian School at McIntosh, Ontario. The effluent from the main chamber would be discharged intermittently into a sewer pipe by a sump pump instead of by another syphons.

The sewage would be conducted through a 6-inch vitrified clay pipe, 800 feet to a depression to the southwest of the school. The discharge end of the sewer line will be hidden from the school by 300 feet of poplar bush. The sewage will flow westward to a large slough in the southwest quarter of the section.

General Description.

As can be noted from the general plan the septic tank is close to the west side of the school. The sewage from the toilets, baths, etc., is carried to the main chamber of the septic tank. The laundry water will be conducted directly to the overflow chamber.

Considerable thought was expended in devising a suitable method of disposing of the effluent from the septic tank and of the laundry waste. Because of the severity of the winter climate and lack of adequate slope in the land it was found necessary to discharge the effluent intermittently in large quantities so that it would not freeze close to the outlet from the sewer and eventually block it, but flow a considerable distance away before freezing. It is expected that the midwinter sewage will freeze and form ice before it reaches its destination in the aforementioned large slough in the southwest quarter of the section. Hence it was necessary to keep the discharge end of the sewer as high as possible above the bottom of the depression. It was found that two feet was all that the pipe could be raised without getting it above ground. Most of the pipe will be close to the surface of the ground and covered with a fill. To avoid an unsightly fill...
close to the school it is intended to encase 300 feet of pipe in a creosoted plank box filled with insulating material and use a shallow earth cover for that section of pipe.

As before mentioned the main chamber of the septic tank structure is the same as constructed for the McIntosh Indian School at McIntosh, Ontario. The effluent will pass over a weir into a receiving chamber holding close to 900 gals. This receiving chamber will also receive the laundry waste. (The rain water from the roof is not to be handled by this system but run out upon the ground about 200 feet back of the school).

A sump pump will sit upon a reinforced slab above the effluent and discharge intermittently into the sewer pipe. The capacity of this pump will be 40 to 50 gallons per minute and will hence empty the receiving chamber in 20 minutes.

The sewer pipe projects into the receiving chamber and will receive the effluent as it is received in case the sump pump for any reason should stop.

This structure has been very carefully designed in order to utilize every inch of fall and yet function properly.

The grade of the sewer pipe is three-tenths per cent. One manhole has been provided half way along the pipeline for inspection and cleaning purposes.

Entrance to the main chamber of the septic tank may be had through a 16-inch cast iron manhole or through an opening from the receiving chamber. The interior of the receiving chamber will be lighted with one electric globe. The walls should be whitewashed to brighten up the interior.

The first two items were kindly estimated by Mr. Borgford of the McDiarmid Construction Co. which is now constructing the school. The amounts are intended to be considered liberal. When the plans are approved he will submit a tender in the usual manner.

Re- Suggested Electric Line to Blue Quills Indian School, near St. Paul, Alberta.

Sir:

Since coming to St. Paul I have continued the negotiations with the Calgary Power Co., Ltd. already commenced by Mr. P.J. Jennings, Commissioner of Irrigation, Calgary, on the subject of obtaining electric current from the Company's plant at St. Paul. Being right on the ground I was in a good position to expedite the proceedings, which I have been doing with the approval of Mr. Jennings.

The first proposal was to bring the line along the main highway from St. Paul for 2 miles, and then northerly for ½ mile along the cross road to the school. This proposal was objected to by the Highways Branch of the Provincial Gov't.

The second proposal was to come direct along the quarter section lines between St. Paul and the school, but as this alternative meant crossing wheat fields, the affected owners refused to grant easements for this route, but they agreed to grant easements if the line were located 2 ft. on their lands skirting the main highway mentioned in the first proposal.

I passed on to the Calgary Power Co. the views of the local land owners concerned, and they agreed to the third alternative of locating the line 2 ft. on private property adjoining the main highway, and then building on the edge of the road allowance a half mile northerly to reach the school. They then sent me legal forms for these various owners to sign, giving the necessary easements on the seven properties involved, and offering compensation on the basis of $5.00 per pole, which is the usual scale when crossing cultivated land. I procured the required signatures to the legal papers, which I returned to the Calgary Power Co, who were then in a position to give the Department a definite tender.

Sir:

I beg to submit an alternative proposition in connection with the water supply plans for the Indian Residential School near St. Paul de Metis, Alberta, which apparently merits consideration.

Review of first Proposition.

Two wells were drilled to 104 feet and 461 feet, respectively; the first, containing very hard water delivered 600 gallons per hour in a two hour test and might even deliver 1,000 gallons per hour. This well is being used by the contractors and appears to be clearing up. Probably by next winter the water will have cleared sufficiently to be pumped directly from the ground into the pressure tanks without first being passed through a sand settling tank and filtering tank. The capacity of this well seems ample for the school requirements.

The other well, containing very soft water, delivered 200 gallons per hour with a hand pump in a two day test. This is not at all the capacity of this well which appears to be drilled into a very powerful vein of water. In the above test a teaspoon of sand was raised to every gallon of water or about one gallon of sand in every 700 gallons of water. During the two day test 5,000 gallons of water were pumped and about 7 gallons of sand, sufficient to fill 12 to 13 feet of well casing. During the test the sand and mud in the casing was lowered 11 feet by measurement. This sand is not considered ordinary quicksand by two experienced well men but it is somewhat coarser and sharper. Since the finer sand would be raised by pumping the coarser sand would be left behind; hence, the body of sand at the bottom of the well is no doubt considerably coarser than ordinary quicksand. In fact, Mr. Morris, who assisted in the drilling, stated that some gravel and clay were raised from the bottom. Since the sand level in the casing did not rise during the two day test but instead, lowered about 11 feet, the well was considered to have good possibilities of finally clearing up and supplying a fair amount of clear, soft water.

With this data to work upon, plans were prepared to use the water from the deep well with an air lift system or a deep well pump, and the water from the shallower well with a deep well pump. The water was to be passed into a sand settling tank and then through layers of sand for the removal of the clay in solution and thence into a 5,000 gal. concrete reservoir. From there the top water would be drawn off and forced into two pressure tanks.

This in brief covers the first proposition.

Second Proposition.
Second Proposition.

The second proposition is to abandon the deep well entirely and use only the hard water well, and endeavor to pump the water directly from this well into two pressure tanks. The water used for boiler, laundry, bathing and washing purposes can be obtained from rain water and by the use of a softening plant. In this proposition the 5,000 gallon concrete reservoir mentioned in the first proposition would be dispensed with. There would also be a saving in a portion of the remainder of the pumphouse structure.

This second proposition is estimated to cost $6,000, while the first one will cost close to $8,000.

Discussion of Two Propositions:

1. Water Supply.

The installation of either scheme will no doubt supply all of the soft and hard water required at the school. The first proposition, which has in view the development of both wells, would no doubt provide a larger amount of water and hence a larger factor of safety in the water supply.

2. Simplicity of Works and Ease of Operation.

The second proposition is much simpler, may give little trouble in operation and would be of a fairly permanent nature depending largely upon the future performance of the hard water well. There may be considerable sand raised for sometime which would necessitate cleaning the pressure tanks occasionally. If the shallow well should clog up in time as has occurred to wells drilled in St. Paul for the creamery another could be drilled nearby at a cost of about $500.00.

The use of a water softener does not present any difficulty since they are in common use when soft water is desired.

In the first proposition provision is made for three pumps, or two pumps and one air lift system. Since all water was to be passed through a sand settling tank and a filtering tank and into a 5,000 gallon reservoir, it would be delivered to the pressure tanks free of sand and clay. The only trouble that might arise is in connection with the pump or air lift system to be installed in the deep well. A deep well pump might require frequent replacing of washers upon the cylinder and even a new cylinder occasionally until the well cleared up. (It is presumed that the deep well would clear up as other wells in that district have already done). An air lift system might develop leaks in the air pipe requiring attention and also, the air pump (costing about $100.00) might require replacing. If the deep well failed to clear up sufficiently to satisfy the entire needs of the school, there is little doubt but what it would supply in ten hours about 1,500 gallons of soft water. The hard water well would supply all additional water required. There

is also the possibility
is also the possibility that the deep well would clear up and make an excellent producer and be of a more permanent nature than the shallower well.

Summary.

In the second proposition there is only one well, one pump, two pressure tanks and a softening tank. There is a simplicity of operation but also the possibility of the occasional cleaning of the pressure tanks of sand, and the possibility that the well might clog. There will be a saving of about $2,000, if the cost of the water softener does not exceed $1,000.

In the first proposition there will be a complete duplication of units such as two wells, two pressure tanks and two means of forcing water into the pressure tanks. This will insure no interruption in the water supply. If the deep well clears up there will be provided a greater abundance and more certain supply of good water than from the second proposition where the deep well was to be abandoned.

Conclusion.

Since there are two wells the nature of whose future performance is still to be proven I must recommend the first proposition although the cost is about $2,000, greater. The deep well does present difficulties but the nature of the sand in the well and the fact that it lowered during a two day test indicates that it is good for at least the soft water requirements of the school. It also has the possibilities of developing into a first class well. Whether it is developed with a deep well pump or an air lift system is immaterial. Both methods have advantages and disadvantages. The deep well pump is more efficient and will deliver more water with the same consumption of power. A cylinder pump may require frequent changing of washers until the sand is removed. An air lift system will require more power for the delivery of the same amount of water. Any leaks in the air delivery pipes will further reduce the efficiency. No trouble will arise, however, by the raising of sand. When the well clears up the cylinder pump can be connected directly to the pressure tanks while the air lift system cannot. The cost of a cylinder pump and of an air lift system is about the same. Air lift systems have been used in the Adanac Brewery, the Regina Brewery and the General Motors plants in Kellena with success. Before definitely deciding upon an air lift system some definite assurance is required of the makers of the air pressure pump as regards the permanence of its performance. As regards leaks developing in the air line there is no doubt but that this can be avoided by careful installation.

Your obedient servant,

(sgd) Merritt H. French.
