Sir,-

Report upon the proposed water supply installation for the Blue Quill Indian Residential School at St. Paul de Metis, Alta.

Introductory.

The Department of Indian Affairs is now constructing a residential school four miles by road west of St Paul de Metis, Alta., a town upon a branch of the Canadian National railways, 127 miles north and easterly from Edmonton. This report deals with the methods to be used in providing for an adequate water supply from two drilled wells.

General.

The school is intended to house approximately 150 people. The water is desired primarily for domestic consumption and the calculations are largely upon that basis. The water required for fire protection is of secondary consideration since the building is strictly of fireproof construction.

To provide for domestic consumption and any small fire that might occur in the contents of the building, 100 gals. per minute should be ample allowance. Since any fire in the building would be of very short duration only a limited storage has been provided. Two 1500-gallon pneumatic pressure tanks will be operated at a maximum pressure of about 80 to 90 lbs. per sq. inch. This will be augmented by 15 to 20 gal. per minute pumped from a 5000-gallon concrete reservoir nearby.

The data for domestic consumption for such an institution seems rather meagre. In one school in the West a daily per capita consumption of 40 gals. was reported. This seems rather high, not knowing the circumstances, and would indicate the need for a check-up upon the system in use. At Maple Creek the domestic consumption for 63 residences, housing 187 children and adults, is 13 gallons per day. This water is all carefully metered and paid for upon that basis. The above houses are all equipped with modern sanitary conveniences. The pressure upon the ground floor has of necessity been maintained at 17 lbs per square inch for several years.

However, in the present plans provision has been made for a daily per capita consumption of 50 gallons for domestic purposes. (4500 gals. per day). It is suggested
that in the building the pipes for fire and domestic purposes be kept separate, and that a pressure reducer and regulator be installed for domestic system. The following pressures are recommended for the domestic system:

Second floor 20 lbs.
First floor 25 "
Ground floor 30 "
Basement floor 35 "

These pressures will decrease the trouble from leaky taps and connections (always a source of annoyance and waste of water where the pressure is 75 to 80 lbs) and reduce the daily consumption.

The amount of water used by the stock which may be ordinarily kept upon a section farm should not be high.

The laundry and boiler water will be wholly obtained from rainfall during the greater part of the year and stored in a 5000-gallon concrete cistern under the laundry room. During the winter months soft water may be obtained from the deep well. Since this cistern is now very likely completed it will not be dealt with in this report.

The pump house structure containing a pump room, a 5000-gal. reinforced concrete reservoir and a room holding two pneumatic pressure tanks is located at the base of a small knoll 370 feet northwest from the school. The water will be obtained from two wells; one 104 feet deep giving good, but very hard, water, and one 461 feet deep giving soft water. The pumps will be electrically driven with power obtained from the Calgary Power Company's plant at St. Paul.

The nature of both wells has created a difficult problem and the need for a more expensive plant than would otherwise have been required. As, for instance, at the Indian School at Gleichen, Alta., the existence of an old proven well with a capacity of 1000 gallons per hour has simplified the works to the need of only one deep well pump and pneumatic storage. At St. Paul the water supply is from two newly drilled wells, the nature of whose future performance is still an uncertain factor. While the wells are being proven the school must be provided with an adequate supply of good water. The abundance of underground water has never been questioned but the best method of handling it has required much thought.

The existing wells in the St. Paul district contain more or less fine sand and clay when first drilled but tend to clear up with moderate continued use.

Pumping Machinery.

It was considered advisable to install in the deep well, which has only a 4½ inch casing, an air lift system of which there are several already in operation in the West. It may be possible to obtain a considerable portion, or all, of the daily needs from this soft water well. If the sand ceases to rise it may be possible to replace the air lift system at some future date with a standard cylinder deep well pump.
In the shallower well a Crane deep well pump, similar (but smaller in size), to the one now in operation at Gleichen is recommended. This well tested 600 gallons per hour with 25 feet of water standing in the casing. The contractor will be pumping from this well for his requirements all summer. A pump with a capacity of 450 to 500 Imperial gallons per hour is recommended.

The water from both wells will be turned into a settling basin for the removal of the sand. It will overflow into a filter tank containing layers of fine sand, coarse sand, gravel and crushed stone to remove the clay in solution. Thence it will flow into the 5000-gallon reservoir.

The water will be pumped from the reservoir to the pressure tanks with a pressure pump (probably a Decatur turbine pump) having a capacity of about 900 to 1000 gallons per hour. Air will be forced along with the water in the same operation in order to maintain the required amount of compressed air in the pressure tanks. The suction pipe will have a loose, or swivel, joint resting upon the bottom of the reservoir and the end of the pipe buoyed up by a float so that at all times the top clean water will be drawn off.

To provide for the contingency that this pressure pump should for any reason fail to function the Crane deep well pump should also be connected to the pressure tanks so that water may be pumped to them directly from the shallower well under a pressure, say, of about 30 to 35 pounds. This will maintain a supply to the school under a lower pressure until the pressure pump functions properly. By this arrangement the water supply system is supplied with complete duplicate units such as two wells, two pressure tanks, and two means of forcing water into the pressure tanks.

Description of pump house structure including a pump room, pressure tank room and reservoir.

The pump room portion of the structure will be 12' 0" x 16'3" outside measurements. The floors and that part of the walls below ground will be made of concrete and the walls above ground of brick. The pump room will contain the sand settling tank, filter tank, stove, and the three sets of pumping machinery described above.

The two pressure tanks will be housed in a room attached to the south side of the pump room and be completely buried for frost protection. The floors and walls will be made of concrete but the roof of creosoted timbers in order to provide for the easy removal of the pressure tanks whenever required for replacement. An overhead reinforced concrete beam supporting the upper part of the wall between the pump room and pressure tank room converts their interiors into one large room.

The reservoir will be attached to the west side of the pump room from which easy access may be had through an opening in the west wall. The reservoir will be of reinforced concrete throughout, and be covered with two feet of earth for frost protection.
The elevations of the floors have all been designed so as to pass the water from one tank to another in the easiest manner and with a view to economy in roof and floor design. Consideration was also given to the lay of the ground, drainage of tanks, etc.

Since a structure of this kind must be frostproof, as much of it as possible is to be below ground and covered with earth. The frame roof over the pump room is to be double boarded so as to create a 4-inch air space. Provision has also been made for a small coal stove and brick chimney in one corner of the pump room. Heat from this stove may reach to all parts of the structure.

All inside woodwork should be painted white and all concrete and brick work whitewashed in order to brighten up the interior. Suitable provision should be made for electric lighting and convenient switches. Windows will be placed in the door and in the two trap-doors in the roof which are provided for the raising and lowering of well piping, pump rods, etc.

Provision for emptying the reservoir is made by a 4-inch pipe extending from the southeast corner and crossing under the pressure tank room and out to the foot of the knoll. The valve will be located in the floor of the pressure tank room which is also provided with drainage through the same pipe. The sand settling tank can also be emptied into this same pipe.

The water from the pressure tanks will be conveyed to the school through a 3-inch galvanized iron pipe laid with a 7-foot cover. In the same trench should be laid a 1½-inch galvanized iron pipe to run water directly from the soft water well (deep well) to the soft water cistern under the laundry room. This is just a provision for a winter supply of soft water and such a pipe would be less expensive than a softening plant, laid in the same trench with the 3-inch pipe.

A 1½-inch galvanized iron pipe will be required to serve the barn and barnyard which will probably be located about 200 feet northwest of the school upon a level piece of ground.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd) Merritt H. French.
Sir,

I enclose herewith two alternative reports on the proposed water supply for the Blue Quills Indian school near St. Paul de Metis received from Mr. Tempest, the Commissioner of Irrigation. The first report, which is dated August 16, deals with the general layout and describes in detail the works of the system proposed, pumping plants, storage and housing arrangements.

The second report, which is dated September 5, deals with an alternative scheme whereby the deep well is eliminated and the system depends entirely on the recently drilled shallow well. Although there would be a considerable saving by adopting the second proposal, in view of information which has been obtained in the district and particularly in the locality of St. Paul de Metis, it would not appear to be wise to depend entirely on the permanence of the shallow well. A steadily diminishing water supply with ultimate exhaustion would create a very unsatisfactory condition at the school.

After reviewing these considerations Mr. Tempest states that he would therefore unhesitatingly recommend that the proposal contained in the report of August 16 should be adopted, the estimated cost of which amounts to $7956.00.

The plan showing details of the works proposed under the report recommended is also enclosed, and as soon as we are advised that this has been approved, Mr. Tempest will be instructed to call for tenders and endeavour to have the concrete and housing portion of the system completed before freeze-up.

I shall be glad, therefore, if you will advise me as to the decision of the department in regard to this matter as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

J. T. Johnston,
Director.

Sir:

I have had two calls from the Rev. Principal (Father Angin) with reference to a Barn for the above mentioned school.

In order to get some idea of his requirements, I gave him an old floor plan of a barn drawn for St. Paul's School at Cardston, but never used, and I asked him to amend it to suit the local needs in this regard. I am now sending you herewith the amendments suggested by him as written on the drawing, and amplified in his accompanying letter now enclosed. The red markings are mine.

You will note he asks for a barn of the dimensions shown on the drawing, but I think one of lesser size would prove sufficient for a one-section farm. I suggest reducing the size from that shown to 36' wide by 90' long. This reduction could be accomplished by omitting two of the double horse-stalls and four cow-stalls, as indicated in my red markings, and a slight pinching of stall-widths, and passages.

Regarding the suggested Root-house crosswise under the centre of the barn, the idea seems commendable, but I would prefer the doorways and steps on the outside of the barn, and protected from the weather. This would prove safer, easier of access to Sisters or pupils, and avoid taking up inside floor space. Possibly one doorway would answer, and a chute could be put at the other side of the barn for delivering the roots. This root-house would require ventilation shafts to the outside air. Electric lights, with switch at stairway, would be installed.

The Grainary asked for might better be an entirely separate building, and not connected with the barn. The feed-room shown would hold perhaps a week's supply of grain or chop for all the animals, and supplies could be brought in periodically from the regular grainary elsewhere on the farm.

The water-troughs asked for could be of heavy plank construction, reinforced with iron rods. Concrete troughs often prove leaky, and are not so suitable when ice forms and has to be chopped out. The outside trough should be farther from the
barn, to avoid a fire-hazard from the tank-heater. It could be
fed by an underground pipe with sto-and-waste.

I was absent when the Rev. Father returned the Plan
with his notes, or I should have discussed the points with him
that I am mentioning in this letter, but I think from the
information now being sent you, you will know pretty well what
the needs are. Interior fittings, and hay-unloading machinery,
such as was installed at the Old Suns Barn at Gleichen, should
prove very satisfactory here.

The water supply for the barn should be taken from the
line which will supply the school, and I shall place a Tee in
said line at a convenient place for the branch to the barn
should the school water-system be installed before authority is
given for the barn.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Dear Sir,

I have considered your plan of a barn and I approve it plainly. It is not complicated and so, very advisable. I think it is not too big for the School, as now I have 12 cows and 12 horses, to accommodate the needs of the School, and I will need more when I will have 140 pupils. So the barn can be built according to your plan and the very same dimensions kept.

You will see, on the plan, that I change the direction of the barn, the horses being placed on the south side, instead of the north. It is better to have the horses on the front of the main building.

Some additions have been made:
1) A cement trough inside, near the feed-room, and placed along it, the dimensions of this being diminished. This trough would have a cover, and would be 8 feet long, 2 feet wide and 2 feet deep.
2) A galvanized iron trough outside with a heater (tank heater) to water animals on summer time and those that will winter outside, dimensions of same being 8 feet long, 2 feet wide and 2 feet deep. It should be placed on the east side, as indicated on the plan, to drain the water.

Those 2 troughs should receive water from the well.
3) No need of silo, but instead of it and at the same place, a grainery, round or square, containing 1000 bushels of oats, for feeding the horses.
4) A root-cellar should be provided for, from wall to wall, west-east, under the feed-room and maternity-ward, dimensions of same being 32 feet long, 12 feet wide and 7 feet deep, with traps-doors and stairs at the 2 ends as indicated on the plan, with also vent over and lights. Inside the root-cellar, 4 partitions, every 6 feet, with 4 feet passage, north side, from stairs to the other stairs.

I hope these additions will meet your approval.

I am, dear Sir,

Yours very sincerely,

Report on Blue Quills School, St. Paul, Alta.

Sir:

Good progress is being maintained in the construction of the above mentioned school by The J. McDiarmid Co., Ltd., general contractors, of Winnipeg and Calgary, there being between fifty and sixty men now employed.

The brickwork is up to the window sills of the 1st Floor, of the main building, and up to the window heads of the Chapel, and by the time this Report reaches Ottawa, the brickwork should be completed up to the ceiling of the 1st Floor. Fourteen bricklayers, under an efficient foreman, are carrying this branch of the work forward rapidly, and good workmanship is being done. Oakum is being used around window frames and outside door frames as called for, and a frequent source of draughts should thus be overcome.

The stonework is being installed as the walls go up, and an experienced stone mason does the setting. The Tyndall stone sent us is generally good, although we have had to ask for a little replacement in a very few instances of defective stones. The stonework of the main entrance looks ornate and distinctive, and will impart dignity to the whole building.

We have had good success with the floor slabs of Ground and 1st Floors, there not being a single crack in evidence throughout. Within a week or ten days we expect to run the slab of the 2nd Floor, which will be the last one. It is a great advantage being able to get this important work done without having to contend with frost. After considerable deliberation, we decided to defer putting on the finish topping until the roof is on, and the bulk of the traffic over, and unusual care will be exercised to secure a bond, and this work will be done by expert cement finishers, and as called for in the specifications.

No basement floors have yet been run except in the boiler room. Six inches of additional excavating has been done, and broken stone to this depth is now being spread to cut off the ground dampness of the moist clay sub-soil. Within the next few days the concrete floors of the basement will be laid.

The drains for sewage and kitchen and laundry waste have been installed, and subjected to the usual water test which in this case revealed a cracked pipe, and several weeping joints, but which was remedied before filling in was done. The sewer
leaves the building at 7'-3" below grade, and has been given
the prescribed fall of 4" to the foot run.

We have installed a soft water cistern, 7'x 7'x 12', at
the rear end of laundry, which will contain about 4000 Imp. gals.,
and which will be supplied by rain water from the roofs of rear
extension and Chapel. This source of soft water will be available
for the heating and laundry boilers, and for laundry purposes.
The overflow from the cistern will join the main roof water drain
and pass to a surface outlet at the rear of the school in a
slight depression about 150' distant, and not to the septic tank.
As taking care of rain water is only a summer condition, we did
not have to provide against frost at the outlet.

The heating boilers have been placed, and steam fitters
are now installing the basement mains and returns. The boilers
seem very suitable, and similar in type to the Pascol, Bircho-
field, and other boilers recently installed in other Indian
schools. The high pressure laundry boiler, and the hot water
storage tank, have also been delivered. Dunham heating special-
ties will be used, which fact will give us the free inspection
and cooperation of Mr. Alex. Walker, Dunham's Alberta represen-
tative.

The electrician is placing the necessary lines of conduits
as the work proceeds. There will be additional requirements in
providing for power lines to the laundry, bakery and prospective
pumping house, and I have asked him to submit a suitable layout
with estimate of cost for these services, and when received, I
shall forward same to the Department for approval.

Material deliveries have kept well ahead of the work,
and all the Tyndel stone, pressed and common brick, tile, and
steel beams, columns, joists, etc., are now on the ground. The
erection of the steel columns and beams has proceeded with
remarkable precision.

About a week ago I had a call from the Rev. Father Angin
and Sisters from Sacred Heart, and the first question I was asked
was about the much-coveted passageway for the Sisters from the
1st Floor to the gallery of Chapel. I broke it to them gently
that the Department could not sanction this expenditure. They
bore up bravely under their disappointment, perhaps realizing
that there's a limit to what even a beneficent government can
grant.

Regarding electric light and power for the school, I am
hoping soon to receive the Department's decision with respect
to the tender of the Calgary Power Co. for bringing electric
current from their plant at St. Paul.
The question of septic tank and sewage disposal is also in abeyance. I understand that full data bearing on this service was sent forward by the Commissioner of Irrigation, Calgary, and no doubt the Department will appreciate the desirability of having this essential work done before freeze-up. In my letter of Sept 10th I mentioned that I had collaborated with Mr. French in designing a suitable system to meet the peculiar conditions existing, and I consider the scheme submitted is just what is needed at this place.

The source of water supply for the school, and the best means of delivering it, is another very important matter awaiting the Department's decision. I have a copy of the Report submitted by Mr. French to the Commissioner of Irrigation, and also the blue print of the proposed building and equipment. Mr. French has gone into the subject so lucidly and exhaustively that it seems that nothing more can be added to what he has already stated, except, perhaps, a little passing comment on his report.

There seems no question but what the water in the deeper well is of better quality, being soft as proved by it lathering readily with ordinary soap in cold water. This well is 463 ft deep, the casing from top to bottom is only 4½", and it would not be feasible to install a pumping plant of large capacity in this well,—probably about 250 gals. per hour being the maximum. The water stands in the casing to within 100 ft. of the surface of the ground, but we have no data as to the level it falls to under pumping. There is also a condition of sand to contend with, which might cause much trouble from cutting cylinder leathers, or even the cylinder itself, thus making necessary the frequent arduous task of lifting the well piping. On the other hand this well might clear itself within a comparatively short time, and give no further trouble from sand.

Sept 26th,

I stopped my Report at this point because it occurred to me that something more definite should be known as to the capacity of the deep well before asking the Department to incur perhaps unnecessary expense in a water service. I therefore asked the contractors to change their pumping outfit from the shallow well which they have drawn from since the job started. They did this, adding more drop pipe and pump rod, and lowering the cylinder 175 ft., or 75 ft. in the water. We have now been pumping from the deep well nearly all day for three days. The results are very encouraging. The large amount of sand in this well as indicated in previous reports, and which threatened to choke the well, now seems much less menacing, and the water is already coming almost clear. The main factor of doubt now seems to be the capacity of the vein supplying this well. The contractors were unable to use the same size cylinder as they had been using in the shallow well because of the smaller casing in the deep well (only 4½") and the rate of pumping from the deep well under the test now going on is only 115 gals per hour. However, we have procured a special cylinder which I think will about double...
the present capacity, and next Sunday while the work of construction is shut down, the contractors will draw the well piping and attach the special cylinder. I shall then check the performance of this well closely, and after two or three days' pumping I hope to be in a position to make an intelligent recommendation regarding the water supply and pumping plant. I think it very probable that we shall be able to dispense with some of the outlay indicated in Mr. French's Report.

Every man in the Camp appreciated the change of water, as that from the deep well is so much softer.

When in Calgary I asked the Commissioner of Irrigation for a copy of the analyses of the water from the wells here, but it could not be found. I have therefore sent samples of the water from both wells to the Provincial Laboratory at Edmonton, and hope soon to receive analyses of the samples, copies of which I will forward you.

In my night-letter of yesterday's date, asking for authority to dig the trench from the well to the school, and lay the water pipe, I also mentioned that we are testing both wells, and that I expected to make a recommendation within the next few days. As the season is advancing rapidly, I am anxious to get these auxiliary services installed before severe freezing weather sets in. Last night we had 15 degrees of frost.

Since commencing the first part of this Report, the concrete floors of the basement have been laid.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Re- Sewage Disposal & Water System, Blue Quills School.

Sir:

With regard to the Plan of the suggested Sewage Disposal System for this school, prepared by Mr. M. French, of the Staff of the Commissioner of Irrigation, Calgary, and already dealt with by me in my letter of Sept 10th. The scheme as outlined in Mr. French's Plan and Report is exactly suited to the peculiar conditions existing here, and I have no hesitation in recommending its adoption in its entirety. I have been in daily expectation of receiving the Department's instructions to proceed with this work.

WATER SUPPLY AND EQUIPMENT.

No doubt you are now in possession of the Plan for Water Service prepared by Mr. French (Plan F4811, Sheet #3) and his Reports of Aug. 16th and Sep't 5th addressed to the Commissioner of Irrigation.

Mr. French has devoted much time and very careful thought in designing a suitable Water Service for this school, and the scheme as shown on the Plan, and recommended in his Reports, provides for every possible contingency that might arise. He was guided, of course, by the data and information available to him at the time, and by his deductions drawn therefrom.

As intimated in my general Report of Sept 20th, and completed on Sept 26th, we have been experimenting with the deep well, and I have had it under close test and observation during the past 10 days, and during this time all the water used by the contractors in their work of construction has come from this deep well. We have drawn and lowered the well piping several times so as to test the well at different depths of pumping, and have experimented with different cylinders, and I have checked the amounts of water delivered under the different conditions. This work has of necessity been an expense to the contractors, but I took it on myself to authorize this necessary experimental work, and a charge for the labour and material involved will eventually be rendered the Department.

We are now pumping from the deep well at the rate of 250 gals of water per hour, using a 3"x 12" cylinder, placed
175 ft. below the surface of the ground, and with an intake pipe 15 ft long attached to the bottom of the cylinder. Originally, the water level in the casing was within 100 ft. of the surface, but under pumping at the rate mentioned it was found that the water level had dropped only 30 ft. At present the cylinder is submerged 47 ft in the water, and with the intake added, we are drawing from a point 62' below the working level of this well.

We have raised a good deal of clay in solution, and considerable sand, but this condition is improving steadily. On an examination of the cylinder last night, after 10 days' pumping, no wear was noticeable on the leather washers, which fact removes the fear of excessive wear on the cylinder from the sand content of the water.

I have not yet received the expected reports on the water samples sent to the Provincial Laboratory from both wells, but there is no question as to the superiority of the water from the deep well for all ordinary purposes. Our engineers, however, report this water harder to hold in their high pressure hoisting and concrete-mixer boilers than was the water from the shallow well, but as we are providing the school with a rain-water cistern, water for the heating and laundry boilers in the school will be available from this source.

Now for my recommendation: I agree with Mr. French that both wells should be made available for the needs of the school, which means there should be a pumping plant installed over each well. I would aim at supplying the school entirely from the deep well owing to its superior water, but in the event of an insufficiency of water, the supply could be augmented from the shallow well. (Note: the "shallow" well is 104 ft deep, and the "deep" well is 463 ft deep) A pump of sturdy design, and a capacity of 300 gals. per hour should be installed for the deep well; and one with a capacity of 500 to 600 gals. per hr for the shallow well, in which there is a larger casing, and an abundance of water.

Where Mr. French shows the building, or pump house, on his Plan, I would dispense with all the underground part, and build simply a small well-house above ground, of about 8' x 12' in size, of brick and tile, concrete foundation and floor, with door, window and brick chimney. I would place two pressure tanks of 1500 gals each, in an extension from the boiler room of the school, south of the coal bin, and with access through a door from the boiler room, and with a slab roof over. At this point the tanks could be installed at less cost than elsewhere, for two of the walls are already there, and the gauges would be under the observation of the engineer more readily. The pressure tanks should be equipped with man-holes, and so placed as to be readily flushed out. A 2" galvanized pipe line would bring the water from the pumps in a 7' trench to the pressure tanks; the pumps would be motor-driven, with automatic starters and cut-outs.
The water from the deep well would be the main supply, and probably the only supply, piped into the school; there would be no need of a water-softening plant; and as the water under the actual pumping now going on is clearing itself, there would be no necessity for filtering or storage tanks as shown in Mr. French's drawing. Both pumps should be connected direct to the water supply line leading to the two pressure tanks to be located in a chamber extending from the boiler room of the school.

The foregoing recommendation provides for a simple installation similar in most respects to that installed in other schools, the main difference being that I am recommending two pumping plants, one for each well, instead of the usual single unit. The cost I estimate at approximately $5000.00, including the two pumping units, motors, water line, pressure tanks and chamber, well house, and incidentals. I would respectfully suggest that the contractors be authorized to perform this work at proven cost, plus 10%, in which event I should personally select the mechanical equipment, and obtain from the manufacturers their guarantee of successful performance. Should the Department approve my recommendation, but prefer that the contractors submit a definite tender for all the work complete, I shall gladly carry out instructions to that end, or any other instructions which the Department may see fit to give.

In departing from Mr. French's recommendations and Plan, I do not wish to appear to be treating his views lightly, for I have nothing but the highest praise for the great pains and care he has exercised in designing a water system for this school, but in view of our more recent findings it would appear that a much simpler and less expensive water service will meet the requirements.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

[Signature]

Inspector of Construction.

Report on Blue Quills Indian School, St. Paul, Alta.

Sir:

Since my last Report of Sep't 20th and 26th we have had much broken weather which became progressively worse, and which culminated in a violent snow-storm and blizzard on the 14th instant. Over a foot of snow fell in this locality, and the drifts were so heavy that the main highway to St. Paul was for several days blocked to traffic. The temperature dropped to 10 degrees below zero, and we were plunged into Arctic conditions. For about a week the work of construction was completely halted, and about the only work done was the thawing out of pipe lines of the contractor's temporary water system, and the shovelling of snow from the various floors of the building. On the 20th instant the bricklayers resumed work, the ingredients all being heated, and salamanders being placed on each mortar board. We were even then getting below zero weather, but the storm had subsided, and it was again possible to proceed with the work of construction. The weather is now comparatively mild again, and most of the snow is gone except the drifts, and good progress is again being made.

I have been much concerned in view of the ground becoming frozen, and with nothing yet done in the way of installing the sewage disposal works and water supply. Under these circumstances I took it on myself to authorize the digging of the water trench from the well to the school, and laying the 2½" gal. water pipe in same. In places it was necessary to use a sledge and drill to break the frozen crust, but most of the line of digging was protected by the snow from deep freezing, and only required ordinary pick-and-shovel treatment. Apart from the laying of this essential water-line I have not authorized anything further regarding either the sewage disposal works or water system as I am still awaiting the Department's instructions with regard to both these services. Perhaps, however, I may be pardoned for reminding the Department that the longer the delay in performing this outside work, the more costly it is likely to be, as will be readily understood.

The outside brickwork is now nearing completion, the work still remaining being the completion of the coping walls of the main building, and the carrying up of the chimneys to a height of 10' above the coping of the school walls. Then will follow the building of the interior stair walls, enamel brickwork in kitchen and scullery, and the erection of the gypsum partitions.

Carpenters are now framing for the roof of the main building, and I hope by the end of the month most, if not quite all, of the roofs will be boarded in. The roofing contractor
is expected to arrive this week to commence laying the felt-and-gravel roofing. His materials are already on the ground.

No windows have yet arrived, but are supposed to be now on the way from Port Arthur where the order for millwork was placed. No time will be lost in attaching the storm windows, so as to keep out wind and snow, and permit the proceeding with plastering and other interior work.

The steamfitters have the heating boilers installed, and the mains run, and most of the risers and returns placed, but the breeching to connect the boilers to the chimney has not yet arrived, nor have any radiators yet been received, but these too are supposed to be in transit.

The plumbers are well ahead with their roughing-in, and are about ready for the second water-test, but we have no place to run the test water to, and we dare not leave the water in the pipes for fear of freezing, so this, also, is having to be deferred.

The electrician is also carrying his work forward as the progress of the building makes possible.

Under date of Oct. 1st I wrote the Department with regard to the necessary power wiring, and additional power and light outlets required, for which provision should be made during construction. With my letter I enclosed a blue print and layout submitted by the electrical sub-contractor (Brotherston Electric Co.) and an estimate of cost quoted by him. As it is desirable to have these various lines laid during construction, I asked that the Department wire me in reply, but no word of any kind has come in response. This additional work is being held up pending the Department's instructions, except that I had the electrical contractor lay a conduit from the power room in school to the outside of the building nearest to where the septic tank will be located. It was necessary to place this conduit previous to the laying of the concrete floor in basement. Current will be conducted through this line to operate the motor in the 2nd chamber of the septic tank.

In recent correspondence I have had a good deal to say about the water from the two wells which have been drilled here, and I'm sorry to advise that the subject has not yet been exhausted. You will recall that the first well was drilled to a depth of 463' in an effort to get a supply of soft water, but that under a pumping test carried out by Mr. French the performance of this well was unsatisfactory, much sand and mud being raised, and the well eventually choked and the water ceased coming. We then drilled a second well, to a depth of 104', and got an abundant supply of water which enabled the contractors to go ahead with their contract, but the water from this shallow well was found to be very hard, strongly flavored with iron, and altogether not very suitable for supplying the school. During an interval when the contractors were not using very much water, I got them to set up their pumping plant over the deep well, and after a good deal of experimenting in the way of getting the most suitable cylinder, and pumping from various levels, we
were rewarded by getting this deep well to come into production again. For about 10 days we pumped from this source continuously for several hours each day, and on one occasion we kept the pump going day and night for about 48 hours, allowing the surplus water to run to waste, the intention being to make a thorough test of the capacity of the vein supplying the well. During this long test we found the water steadily clearing, and at the last it was just slightly cloudy. Everybody in the Camp appreciated the change of water, and it seemed that our troubles in this regard were over. I got an excellent report on this water from the Provincial Laboratory—a copy of which I sent you—and in my Report on the water question I recommended that the water from the deep well be the main supply for the school. We had been pumping at the rate of 250 gals. per hour, and it seemed that this rate of delivery might be increased when the permanent pumping plant were installed. During the 10 days' test referred to, all the water used in construction, and in the Camp, came from the deep well, and the supply was abundant for all purposes.

Then trouble came very suddenly. On starting the pump, after standing over Sunday, it was found that something had happened, the water came extremely muddy, and then choked up and stopped! The contractors drew the well piping and cylinder, cleaned the mud from the latter, added 40' more well piping and rods, and tried again. More very muddy water was raised, but in a short time the water again stopped coming. On again drawing the cylinder and piping it was found that the water level had dropped 100', and that the well was choked. On lowering a weight down the casing it was found that there was 80' of mud at the bottom of the well, which had cut off the intake. As the contractors had to have water for their work, they changed their plant back to the shallow well, and have since been drawing all water from that source, and the deep well has been temporarily abandoned.

Knowing that at Elk Point, 20 miles east of here, a well-driller named Frederickson, had just arrived with a modern rig to drill a well for the Municipal Hospital there, and wishing to get expert advice on our water problem, I went to Elk Point to see him. I explained the whole situation to him as fully as possible with regard to the performance of our deep well, and asked his opinion as to what, if anything, could be done to save this well. Mr. Frederickson has had many years' experience in drilling, and perhaps knows the structures in this part of the country as well as anybody does. He thinks the trouble is from a "squeeze up" from the water vein itself, and that it may or may not be possible to save this well, but he says we have a good "sporting chance" of doing so. His recommendation is that we have a well-driller set up over the well, and drill and bail out the mud until the well is clean, pumping as may be found necessary also. Then when the well is clean, he suggests that screened gravel be poured down the casing to a depth of about 100'. The gravel, he thinks, will not only act as a sort of filter, but its weight will tend to hold back the mud and prevent a repetition of the "squeeze up" which has occurred. In answer to my question as to what he would charge to come
with his rig and do this work, he estimated the total cost at from $200 to $250. Owing to the smallness of the casing in this deep well (4") he would be to some expense in getting rigged up for this particular job, and would also have to procure additional heavy rope for drilling, and extra cable for balling. Also he would be under the expense of shipping his rig to St. Paul, and hauling it to and from our job.

According to Mr. French, this deep well has already cost somewhere about $3000.00, and it might be good business to spend another two or three hundred dollars on the chance of saving it. Also, if we have to use the hard water from the shallow well for supplying the school, it would seem necessary to install a water-softening plant.

I shall be glad to receive the Department's instructions with regard to this serious situation which has arisen. I have asked the well-driller to hold himself open to come here next, after finishing his work at the Elk Point Hospital, and that I would let him know the Department's decision at the earliest possible date. He expects to be at his present job for a week or 10 days, and if he then moves away to other work we may not be able to get him or any other driller for an indefinite time.

Trusting that I may soon receive the Department's decisions on the various matters still pending,

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

In the play-rooms of basement, and in the main dining room, also in class rooms and dormitories above, are exposed 1 columns. Sir,

Report on Sewage Disposal Works for the Blue Quill Indian Residential School at St. Paul, Alberta.

Introductory.

The Blue Quill Indian Residential School now under construction is located four miles by road west of St. Paul de Metis, Alta., upon a branch line of the Canadian National Railways 127 miles easterly from Edmonton. The school is located in a school section in a well settled country.

Topographically the section is undulating with no decided slope in any direction. There are many small depressions which apparently overflow into the large shallow slough in the SW¼ of the section.

A gravity sewage disposal plant was found impossible. A gravel sub-irrigation disposal bed was considered expensive and unnecessary. It was ultimately decided to build a standard septic tank similar with one exception to that used at the McIntosh Indian School at McIntosh, Ontario. The effluent from the main chamber would be discharged intermittently into a sewer pipe by a sump pump instead of by another syphons.

The sewage would be conducted through a 6-inch vitrified clay pipe, 800 feet to a depression to the southwest of the school. The discharge end of the sewer line will be hidden from the school by 300 feet of poplar bush. The sewage will flow westward to a large slough in the southwest quarter of the section.

General Description.

As can be noted from the general plan the septic tank is close to the west side of the school. The sewage from the toilets, baths, etc., is carried to the main chamber of the septic tank. The laundry water will be conducted directly to the overflow chamber.

Considerable thought was expended in devising a suitable method of disposing of the effluent from the septic tank and of the laundry waste. Because of the severity of the winter climate and lack of adequate slope in the land it was found necessary to discharge the effluent intermittently in large quantities so that it would not freeze close to the outlet from the sewer and eventually block it, but flow a considerable distance away before freezing. It is expected that the midwinter sewage will freeze and form ice before it reaches its destination in the afore-mentioned large slough in the southwest quarter of the section. Hence it was necessary to keep the discharge end of the sewer as high as possible above the bottom of the depression. It was found that two feet was all that the pipe could be raised without getting it above ground. Most of the pipe will be close to the surface of the ground and covered with a fill. To avoid an unsightly fill...
close to the school it is intended to encase 300 feet of pipe in creosoted plank box filled with insulating material and use a shallow earth cover for that portion of pipe.

As before mentioned the main chamber of the septic tank structure is the same as constructed for the McIntosh Indian School at McIntosh, Ontario. The effluent will pass over a weir into a receiving chamber holding close to 900 gals. This receiving chamber will also receive the laundry waste.

(The rain water from the roof is not to be handled by this system but run out upon the ground about 200 feet back of the school.)

A sump pump will sit upon a reinforced slab above the effluent and discharge intermittently into the sewer pipe. The capacity of this pump will be 40 to 50 gallons per minute and will hence empty the receiving chamber in 20 minutes.

The sewer pipe projects into the receiving chamber and will receive the effluent as it is received in case the sump pump for any reason should stop.

This structure has been very carefully designed in order to utilize every inch of fall and yet function properly.

The grade of the sewer pipe is three-tenths per cent. One manhole has been provided halfway along the pipeline for inspection and cleaning purposes.

Entrance to the main chamber of the septic tank may be had through a 16-inch cast iron manhole or through an opening from the receiving chamber. The interior of the receiving chamber will be lighted with one electric globe. The walls should be whitewashed to brighten up the interior.

Estimate of Cost.

The following is an estimate of the cost:

SPECIFICATIONS FOR SEWAGE DISPOSAL WORKS.

The Contractor will be required to connect with the sewer line and kitchen drain where said drains leave the school, and to construct and make all connections to the Septic Tank, as shown in detail on accompanying plan. All sewer lines leading to and away from the septic tank to be 6" vitrified tile with joints well sealed.

SEPTIC TANK:

The septic tank shall be constructed to conform with that shown on plan, except that it will be 2 ft. deeper throughout. The concrete shall consist of broken stone of approved sizes, and coarse clean sand, with the addition of Portland cement in the proportions of one part cement, three parts sand and five parts of broken stone, well placed in forms erected by carpenters. Reinforcing steel of the sizes shown shall be installed where indicated in the drawings. On completion the entire inner surface shall be trowel smooth, with a half inch coating of cement and sand, mixed in proportion of one part cement to two and a half parts of sand. The exterior walls of septic tank shall receive an application of approved water-proofing, well brushed in.

In the second chamber of tank shall be installed a motor-driven Sewage Lift Pump of Buffalo or other approved make, with a lifting capacity of not less than 40 gallons per minute. Electric current to drive motor shall be brought underground in conduit from the power panel in School.

DISCHARGE LINE:

The first 300 ft. of the discharge line shall be enclosed in creosoted 2" plank boxing, of 12" x 12" dimensions, and filled with insulating material, and said boxing to be covered with 2 ft. of earth. The remaining portion of the sewer line shall have a covering of earth of approximately 5 ft. in depth to point of final outlet. The earth for the fill may be scraped from the land adjoining the sewer line. A grade of 3/10% shall be accurately followed from the outlet of tank to the point of final discharge. The total length of sewer line is approximately 800 ft.

INSPECTION CHAMBER:

A concrete Inspection Chamber to the design shown, with manhole opening and 16" cast iron cover, shall
be installed midway between the septic tank and final outlet.

All work to be performed in a thorough and substantial manner, and to the approval of the Commissioner of Irrigation.

PAYMENTS: Payments will be made at the time and in the manner following:

The Contractor shall be entitled to eighty per centum (80%) of the value of the finished work at the end of every month after its commencement, on the certified estimate of the engineer, approved by the Commissioner.

All the permanent equipment to be installed in accordance with the plans and specifications approved and forming part of this contract is to be paid for on an eighty per centum (80%) basis when laid down on the property on the certificate of the engineer.

The remainder of the amount of the contract price with the exception of any deductions required to be made in accordance with this contract, shall, on the completion of the work, be paid to the Contractor on the certificate of the Engineer, approved by the Commissioner, that the work has been satisfactorily completed in accordance with the terms of the contract.

In the event of solid rock being encountered in any of the excavations the same will be paid for on a cost basis plus fifteen per centum (15%).

The works specified herein are to be completed ready for use within a period of ninety (90) days of the signing of the contract.

Sir:

Steady progress is being maintained in the construction of Blue Quills School, and the weather during past few weeks has been moderate, and only an inch or two of snow covers the ground. We have had several below zero dips, however, and the ground is frozen to about one foot of depth.

The septic tank and sewer line are completed as far as can be done at present. This work has been done according to the plan prepared by the Water Branch of the Department of the Interior, Calgary. There still remains the installing of the motor-driven lift pump in the 2nd chamber of the tank, and this apparatus is coming from Ontario. Also, the sewer line has yet to receive its earth covering during the greater part of the line where the tiles come close to the surface, but as the ground is now frozen, this ploughing and scraping work will have to be deferred till the spring.

The 2500 gal. pneumatic water tank arrived a few days ago and is now being installed in a prepared concrete chamber adjoining the boiler room, access to which will be through a doorway to be cut through the concrete wall of said boiler room. The tank will be covered by a reinforced concrete slab which will finish on the same grade as the adjoining roof of coal bin.

The well driller, Mr. Frederickson, whom I have engaged to clean out our deep well of soft water in an endeavour to bring it back into production, is still at Elk Point, 20 miles from here, where he is putting down a second well for the Municipal Hospital. In speaking with him by phone yesterday he said he expected to reach a water-bearing strata within another day or two, and to be able to come to our job in about a week from now. Much depends on the effort to save our deep well as its water is infinitely superior to the hard, iron-tainted water we are at present using from the shallow well. I will keep the Department informed as to developments in this regard.

The principal work now going on is the plastering, this part of the contract now being about one third done, and it gives
promise of being a first class job. The steam boilers are in operation, and sufficient radiators have been set up to give the necessary heat for the drying of the plaster and keeping frost out of the building.

I am asking Mr. Alex. Walker, Dunham Heating Co's Alberta Engineer, to come and inspect the Dunham system which has been installed here, which service is free to users of Dunham specialties, and I think Mr. Walker will come soon after his return from Lytton, B.C. He advised me that he was leaving Calgary last Sunday in connection with the rearranging of the heating services at St. George's School for the Department. Then before we take over the building from the contractors I shall have the usual inspection made by the Provincial Boiler Inspector.

In my letter to the Department of Nov. 17th I asked for instructions on several matters brought up in that letter, but no reply to my queries has yet been received.

The Reverend Principal, Father Angin, has asked me several times about a barn. I suggested that he write the Department direct on the subject.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

[Signature]

Inspector of Construction.

Dear Sir,

I paid a visit to the new Blue Quills School near St. Paul yesterday, and I was much surprised to learn that no step has been taken till now by the Indian Department to get the barn built over there. May be you have no money to dispose of now, and this building will be delayed till next spring, or your intention is that the new school be opened only next fall, as I cannot move over there, if there is no barn and no fence. If this work is undertaken only next spring, vid. on May or June, it will not be advisable to move to St. Paul before the summer vacations.

Truly yours,

Rev. Jos. Angin,
Principal.
December 24th, 1930.

Dear Father Angin,

I have your letter of the 11th instant, with reference to a barn and fencing at the new Blue Quills Indian Residential School. It was never the intention to move into the new building during the winter or early spring as the plaster walls would not be sufficiently dry to be healthy. My thought has been to have the outbuildings started some time late in March or early April, as soon as the frost is out of the ground and they can be rushed to completion and everything ready to move over not earlier than June.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Report on Blue Quills School.

Sir:

The work of construction is proceeding steadily on the above-mentioned building, there still being about 20 men at work.

The plastering has been the main activity during recent weeks, and it will be quite another week before this branch of the contract can be finished. At this place we have been free of the dust blizzards which were so frequent at Gleichen, and such a tribulation to all concerned. The plastering is looking well, and so far we have scarcely any cracks. Both boilers have been kept going day and night, and the drying of the plaster has been steady and uniform, and during the milder days we have also allowed currents of outside air to pass through the building. Just single windows are so far installed, with the result that a lot of ice forms on the outside window sills from the damp inside air meeting the outside frost. The effect of this ice on two or three Tyndell stone sills has greatly surprised us, it having caused noticeable disintegration. The condition causing this will not arise in the future, it being caused by the excessive moisture from within running down on to the stone and freezing there, in consequence of the plastering in mid-winter. All the sills will be carefully examined for defects before we take over the building; the contractors have already ordered new sills to replace the ones showing trouble. The stonework of the building looks particularly well, especially the main entrance, the latter feature receiving many favourable comments from visitors.

Three painters are now busy staining and painting the inside trim. The ingredients are being supplied by the contractors, and these local painters have been awarded the contract for labour only. The chief painter has worked at the trade most of his life in London, and seems painstaking and efficient. Sometimes while watching him at work I am entertained with descriptions of famous buildings in the world's metropolis painted by him, and of the peers of the realm who often employed him. His two grown-up sons are his helpers, and they, too, are experienced painters, which circumstance would seem to prove that great talent is sometimes hereditary.

Carpenters are setting up trim in the parts of the building in which the plaster is thoroughly dry, and fitting doors and windows. The quality of the millwork supplied for this job by the Port Arthur Shipbuilding Co. is better than average quality. It is too soon, perhaps, to express an opinion on the merits or demerits of the "Superior" windows being installed in dormitories and class-rooms.
Certainly they are more difficult and costly to install, and more than once I have overheard our carpenters consigning the inventor of them to a region not noted for deep snow! Also, they are not well adapted to work in conjunction with the storm windows specified. The upper part of the storm sash is a fixture, and the lower half opens into the room like French windows. The special feature of the "Superior" window is that both top and bottom parts can be tilted into the room, and brought to the horizontal for ease of cleaning, which might work all right with ordinary outside storm windows, but where, as in our case, we have inside storm windows permanently placed and reaching from jamb to jamb, the action of the "Superior" window in respect of its tilting feature is blocked. However, we shall meet the difficulty by holding the storm windows in place by means of small neat bolts, so that when the "Superior" windows are required to lie down for cleaning, the entire storm window can be unbolted and taken down out of the way in advance. This is not an ideal arrangement, but seems the best we can do to avoid nullifying the special feature of the "Superior" window.

The finishing of the cement floors is proceeding well, and I'm glad to say we are getting excellent floors. The sand we are using is very largely the fine screenings from the rocks that were crushed, which we kept specially for this purpose, and being a hard granite, the residue from such rocks is ideal for cement floors. This semi-pulverized rock crushings, with a small addition of ordinary bank sand, made an excellent aggregate for our purpose, and with skilled cement men doing the work, the result is very gratifying. The floors are about three-quarters laid at present.

The brickwork is completed with the exception of the enamelled bricks in the kitchen and scullery. The contractors short-estimated the bricks required in these two rooms, and are having to await the arrival of additional bricks from the East before being able to complete this work.

During the plastering interim nothing further has been done in connection with heating and plumbing. Next week I expect the steam-fitters back, and they will then move the rads, now used for temporary heating, back to the walls, and set up the remainder of the rads throughout the building, and complete the work in the boiler room. This work and the heating installation generally will be inspected by Mr. Alex. Walker, of the Dunham Heating Co.; and the Provincial Boiler Inspector will also pay us a visit and issue his report previous to our taking over the building from the contractors.

The plumbing fixtures have been delivered to the job, and the putting of them in place will proceed after the completion of the plastering. Also, the laundry machinery is here.

The septic tank and sewer line are completed, except that more covering has yet to be placed over the sewer, and the pumping apparatus for the 2nd chamber of the septic tank has yet to be installed. This automatic motor-driven, float-controlled sewage lift pump arrived from the East to-day, and will be connected up soon. Mr. French, of the Water Branch of the Dept't of the Interior, Calgary, was here last week and checked up our septic tank and sewer line levels with an instrument, and found everything to his satisfaction. It was Mr. French who drew the plans for this service. As we have only 15" fall in 800' run between
the septic tank and the final outlet, we have taken extraordinary pains in laying this sewer so as to maintain a uniform fall. The flow will be helped by the initial impulse from the pump, and Mr. French pronounced the conditions satisfactory from an engineering standpoint.

The well-driller, Mr. Frederickson, has not yet arrived here with his drilling rig. He has been engaged to set up over the deep well, and drill out the sand and mud now lying at the bottom of the casing to a depth of 80', and to do all possible to bring this deep well back into satisfactory production so that the school may have a supply of healthy soft water. Mr. Frederickson has had a whole series of discouragements in drilling for the Municipal Hospital at Elk Point, but in the end he succeeded in getting what is believed to be an ample supply of water for that institution. I am informed that he was commissioned to procure and install a pumping plant, and that after this is done, he will move his outfit here. He is due to arrive at any time now. I shall report promptly to the Department the results of the drilling here. I consider this water question one of extreme importance, and if we can succeed in securing the soft water from the deep vein it will prove a great boon to the school. The water from the shallow well, though ample in quantity, is so extremely hard and so impregnated with iron, that it is unpleasant to use and possibly detrimental to health as well.

Yesterday I had a call from the Rev. Father Naessens, of the Order of Oblate Fathers, Edmonton, and he spent most of the day with me in making out the list of cupboards, lockers, shelving, pews, etc., required for the new school. I took notes of all his requests, which follow closely along the lines of what was supplied in other schools, and shall prepare a list with details in readiness for submission for tenders. In this connection I would respectfully ask for instructions as to whom I should go for prices. Should the general contractors also be allowed to submit their figure? No doubt they would be willing to install the additional millwork, either at a stated price, or on the basis of cost plus 10%. I shall take no steps in this matter until receiving the Department's definite instructions.

From present indications I should judge that the general contract will be completed sometime in March. I am deferring the building of the well-house until we see what success attends the effort to procure a water supply from the deep well, and this work is not in the contract anyhow. If the weather should turn too cold for outside construction, the building of the well-house could be deferred till spring. Our weather continues moderate, with an occasional snow flurry. The temperature for today is zero to 20 degrees above.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

[Signature]

Septic Tank.

This structure has been built materially according to plan and as stated by Mr. Gardner-Smith, Inspector of Construction, a very excellent quality of concrete was poured. The floor of the structure throughout was lowered two feet, thereby giving greater storage for sludge in the main chamber. This change also gives larger capacity to the overflow chamber and permits of a greater volume of effluent being pumped at intermittent periods into the outlet sewer, which will decrease the trouble from ice formation close to the end of the sewer line.

The pump and motor for the overflow chamber have not yet arrived at the school, but it is understood that they have been ordered.

The conduits from the school to the overflow chamber for the electric wiring are in place but the moisture-proof switches are not yet installed.

Sewer Line.

As far as constructed the works have been built materially according to plan. The manhole half way along the sewer line was not considered necessary because of the
clean character of the effluent. It was therefore eliminated. The sewer-pipe was laid according to plan in an excellent manner and true to grade. As specified, the first three hundred feet of pipe was encased in a creosoted box filled with insulation for frost protection. This was done to avoid an unsightly fill across the school grounds.

The earth cover over the sewer line is only about 70 per cent completed. It was intended that this earth should be borrowed in low ground along the lower end of the pipeline and moved with teams and scrapers. However, the season had so far advanced before the work was authorized that borrow pits could not be opened up upon low ground because of frost. It was found necessary to borrow the earth from a hill about 800 feet distant and haul it with wagons. Even there the earth is partly frozen and has to be picked and loaded by hand.

He says there is no room in the basement that could possibly be spared for a Dairy, and yet he deems it essential that a suitable room be provided.

Father considers that an outside Dairy, 8'x10' inside measure, placed against the S.E.corner of the laundry between the laundry window and the vestibule, would meet the requirements admirably. By a glance at the basement plan of the school you will see at once the place meant.

This proposed Dairy should be built to match adjoining construction, and should be provided with concrete floor with floor drain, electric light, steam heat, hot and cold water, sink, and with waste connection to the laundry drain; tar and gravel roof, pre-cast copings, a door and two windows, and the interior walls and ceiling plastered. Only three walls would be required to be built, and the floor level would be about the same as that of the vestibule floor.

If the suggested Dairy Room, as outlined above, meet with the Department's approval, the contractors could build it while their mechanics are still here, which I'm sure they would be glad to do on the basis of proven cost plus 10%.

Awaiting the Department's decision,

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Inspector of Construction.

P.S. This room is wanted for the cream separator and churn, and butter-making.
Sir:

The well-driller, Mr. Frederickson, arrived here yesterday from Elk Point where he succeeded in bringing in a good well for the Municipal Hospital at that place, and under very adverse conditions. To-day he made a test of our deep well here. I'm sorry to say he reports it as hopeless, and that it would be a waste of money to attempt to draw on that source of water supply for the school.

The reasons he gives are as follows: In the first place the previous driller used "inset" casing, instead of the "screw and socket" kind, and that under driving it has telescoped and bent. Then the hole has been drilled crooked. The original 6" casing had become stuck, and a 5" casing was then used inside the other. This too jammed and stuck under driving. Then recourse was had to a 4½" casing, and this has been driven to the bottom of the well and into a formation or strata of "heaving" sand, or sand in motion, where also water was met with. The drilling stopped too soon, and should have been continued through the sand to the water below, and the sand cased off. It is now impossible to do this because of the smallness of the 4½" casing, in which drilling is not feasible, and this small casing is also badly bent and crooked for the greater part of its length.

Mr. Frederickson is convinced that there is a good body of water at the bottom of this well, and we proved the same by ten days' pumping during the building construction when an inflow of sand suddenly shut off the water and we were obliged to change back to the shallow well. Also, both from our own use of the water from the deep well, and from the analysis of the water, we know it is soft and pleasant to use, and immeasurably superior to the water from the shallow well. But we cannot make use of this deep well for the reason stated. To-day after several hours' steady baling the sand was actually higher in the casing than before the baling started, there being almost 100 ft. of it.

I have a good deal of confidence in Mr. Frederickson. He comes highly recommended, he has had many years' experience in drilling and is familiar with the formations of this section of the country, and he has a first class deep-well rig. His advice is to abandon our deep well, not because there is any lack of water there, but because the hole is hopelessly blocked by jammed casings, and under these conditions it is impossible to shut out the sand, or deepen the well. He says the evidence shows that the previous driller started the well wrong, and went from bad to worse as the work proceeded.
I have an ample supply of water in the shallow well, but I'm very doubtful as to the wisdom of using it for the needs of this large institution. The analysis of it speaks for itself, and from personal experience over several months I know it tastes strongly of iron, especially when freshly drawn, and it lathers scarcely at all unless a hard-water soap is used. It also corrodes and discolors wash basins and cooking utensils, and is ruination on boiler flues.

It seems to me that the Department will have to choose between making another attempt at drilling for soft water or installing a water-softening plant at the school for treating the water from the shallow well, if this institution is to have a pure water supply. I called the driller in to my room to-night, and in answer to my questioning he told me he is confident he can secure a good supply of soft water from the deeper level by drilling a new well, and by using 6½" screw and socket casing, and by following his own methods which have proved successful elsewhere under similar conditions. He refuses to use inset casing at all. His terms for drilling are $1.50 per foot with board and water for self and man, or $1.75 per foot and he supply board and water. An additional 25¢ per foot is charged after 250' depth. The wholesale price of 6½" casing is $129.00 per 100' FOB Regina or Calgary.

A new well drilled down into the soft water might be expected to cost from $1200.00 to $1500.00, with an almost assured prospect of securing an ample water supply of excellent quality. On the other hand a suitable softening plant would probably cost as much or more, besides annual upkeep for ingredients. As the question of a pure water supply is of prime importance, I am holding the driller here until I hear from the Department, and I would respectfully ask for telegraphed instructions in reply.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

E. Gardner Smith
Inspector of Construction.

P.S. I have already sent the Department the gov't analyses of the water from both the deep & shallow wells.

Dear Dr. Scott:

Since writing you two days ago I have been visited by our family physician, Dr. G. D. Stanley, and he has ordered me back to bed, and has intimated that it may be a week or ten days before I may return to St. Paul and resume my duties there. In my last letter I expected to make a very short stay in Calgary, but doctor's orders can not safely be ignored.

Dr. Stanley is leaving for Ottawa tomorrow to attend the Session of the House, and has arranged with his associate, Dr. Lincoln, to attend me so long as this is necessary.

I was present at Blue Quills School as recently as last Friday. The work is well advanced and with the exception of erecting blackboards, some replacements in toilet bowls which came wrong and the completion of the painting, little now remains to be done to complete the general contract.

My main concern at present is the drilling of the second deep well recently authorized by the Department. On learning that I shall be detained here so much longer than I had intended or expected I took the liberty of conferring with Mr. J. S. Tempest, of the Water Branch, Department of the Interior, Calgary, and he has arranged to send up Mr. French, a competent hydraulic engineer, to supervise the well drilling operations in my absence.

I trust soon to be able to report back for duty, this illness being unique in my experience as it is the first time since early childhood that I have been attended by a doctor.
I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

G. Gardner Smith

Dear Dr. Scott:

I am writing to let you know that I expect to resume my duties at St. Paul, Alberta, within a week or so.

My illness has proved quite protracted, the doctors here diagnosing it as a relapse from "Para-typhoid" which I had evidently contracted at St. Paul. On the 28th ultimo, I wrote you stating that I expected to return to St. Paul within a week or so from that date.

Everything is progressing well at the Blue Quills School, the painting being nearly completed, and the grading of the ground is now being done. Sir:

With reference to the drilling of the second deep well at Blue Quills School I am pleased to be able to report excellent results attained. At a depth of 327', a strong vein of water has been struck, which, under a bailing test, yielded over 600 gals. per hour, and the water level in the casing was lowered only a few feet. The quality of the water seemed satisfactory, it lathered well with ordinary soap, and was pleasant to the taste. However, I deemed it prudent to get a report on the water from the Provincial Laboratory at Edmonton, which report reached me yesterday, and is fully satisfactory. After giving an exhaustive chemical analysis of the water the report ended "From this chemical examination it would appear that this is a good potable water".

I have arranged with the General Contractors to extend the present tank room ten feet, which will then enclose the new well and pumping plant under the one reinforced concrete slab roof at grade level adjoining the boiler room.

Honourable Sir,

During the summer, I suppose, we shall move to the new school, but what will be done with the old school here, at Sacred-Heart? Nobody will stay here who will watch over the old buildings, and I am pretty sure that after one year, they will be burnt, as every spring fire runs all over the Reserve. Furthermore, I will have to build by myself a small house and barn for the Indians who will come to the new School to visit their children.

Could you, then, empower me or Mr. Gullion, Indian Agent, to expropriate these buildings for the profit of the new school. The old material which will not be used in the new school and even the main building itself could be sold. Of course, I don't expect that this will give much money, but it is better to have something for, than to leave the buildings for prey to the fire.

I know also that the Archbishop of Edmonton thinks to have a claim on these buildings, but as they have been erected only with the grant of the Department, I think that they belong to the Department Of Indian Affairs, and so you can dispose of them.
