Sir:

The general contract for the above building is now practically completed. Since my return here I am having a little more grading of the grounds done, and more covering placed on the sewer line owing to settlement of the earth placed there during the winter.

Inside the building there remains a little additional painting to be done; some very slight patching of plaster in 2 or 3 rooms; some floor plates to be placed over clear-outs in the basement floor; a pressure-reducing valve to be placed on the steam line to washer in laundry; and a few very minor adjustments here and there throughout the building, all of which can be done within the next few days.

Neither the Provincial Boiler Inspector nor the Wiring Inspector, have yet visited the job, although both have been notified,—the former was reported to be ill with grippe, and will come when better, and the latter is waiting till other inspections in the district can be done on the same trip. I shall make it my business to see that both these inspections are made, and the required certificates issued.

The new deep well recently completed has stood all tests successfully, both with regard to the quality and quantity of the water, and will prove a great boon to the school in this district of bad water. I am having the water pumped steadily, allowing it to go to waste, and using the contractors' pumping outfit for the purpose. This pumping of water is advised by the well driller rather than allowing the well to remain inactive, and this applies especially to new wells. As previously reported, this well has been drilled just beyond the pressure tank chamber, and by building a concrete extension to said chamber, the storage and pumping equipment will all be accessible from the boiler room and readily observed. I am in daily expectation of the Department's instructions regarding both the pump chamber and the pumping equipment, as outlined in my telegrams of the 7th instant.

Referring to the concrete floors and base in the various rooms of the school, are these to be painted with a concrete paint as was done at Old Suns School? As no concrete hardener was called for in the specifications, I assume it is the intention that these concrete surfaces be painted, both for appearance and to prevent dusting of the surface where exposed to much wear. If the additional painting is to be done, should it not be done previous to the arrival of the school furniture? No doubt the contractors would be willing to undertake this work at cost plus 10%, or if preferred, I could purchase the materials and have the painting done by day labour. The Sherwin-Williams Co., make a special concrete paint that I have found to be better than some others on the market.

Should we not place woven wire guards over the 14 windows of the two recreation rooms in the basement, as done elsewhere? These guards are made to order by The Western Steel Products, Ltd.
With regard to the additional millwork required, such as tables, benches, cupboards, pews, shelving, etc., and as enumerated in a list I sent the Department on April 13th, I am daily expecting to learn the Department's intentions. This list represents the requests of the local authorities with regard to their requirements. At the time of sending you the list I was too ill to work over a drawing board, so was just able to send you some rough sketches which I had on hand from previous jobs. However, I think you would have no difficulty in understanding just what is wanted. I shall be pleased to carry out whatever instructions I may receive, and if so desired I could call on millwork people in Edmonton or elsewhere and obtain competitive prices, but shall do nothing of this kind unless definitely told to do so. Possibly you are already doing this from Ottawa.

The question of a barn is raised each time any of the staff from the old school call here, and only yesterday the matter was referred to again. Under date of Sept 18th last I wrote the Department on the subject, and enclosed a suggested plan for a barn for Blue Quills School. Regarding the request for a root-house under the barn, I am now of the opinion that it would be unwise to build a root-house there. When digging out a sump-hole, which we filled with rocks, at the outlet of the roof-water line at the rear of the school, we encountered water at a depth of 7'. This condition might not apply at the barn site which is on somewhat higher ground, but I should not care to take the chance. I think it would be safer to build the root-house into the side of a knoll about a hundred yards' distance from the barn site. A pigery and hen-house is also being asked for. I am expecting plans from the Dept of Agriculture, Edmonton, of a pigery and hen-house adapted to local conditions of climate, etc., and after receiving them I will write again regarding these subsidiary buildings. I believe that McDiarmid Co. would give an attractive tender as it would give them a chance to use up materials now tied up in their temporary buildings.

To-morrow I expect Mr. Borgford here, and we shall then go over the accounts pertaining to the additional work authorized, and within the next few days I expect to issue the final certificate, and accept the building on behalf of the Department. I take it that any further work which the Department may authorize may be settled for through the issuing of Vouchers, and that it is not necessary to keep the contractors waiting much longer for the monies now due them. The McDiarmid Co. have given us a first-class job of construction, and I assure the officials of the Department will be very pleased with the building when they have occasion to visit it. They have a good name in the building trade, and their reputation will be further enhanced by the new Blue Quills School. I will, of course, take from them the usual 12 months' guarantee called for in the specifications.

Regarding the shallow well of hard water drilled by the Department for the work of construction, I would point out that we have a water-line laid from this well to the school, a distance of about 550'. Should we not place a small building over this well, and install an inexpensive pumping plant there too? In case of a breakdown of the main pumping system this would then serve as an auxiliary during repair, and save any interruption in the water service. I would further suggest that this proposed auxiliary system be operated by a gasoline engine, and then in case of any interruption in the electric current from the St. Paul plant, the smaller pumping plant would be immediately available. Will you please instruct me in this regard.

Awaiting the Department's instructions on the various matters referred to in this report,

I have the honour to be, Sir

Your obedient servant

Dear Mr. Graham:

I visited this school on April 23rd, and found 60 pupils in residence out of an enrolment of 64; four were absent on sick leave. The health of the pupils was good throughout the year until the month of March when they had an epidemic of influenza. At the time of my visit, the general health in the school was very good. The pupils presented a clean and tidy appearance. They are provided with plenty of good wholesome food, including meat, bread, vegetables, fruit, and milk. Eleven cows were being milked at the time of my visit, which is ample for their requirements.

The junior classroom is in charge of Sister Menard who has had fourteen years experience in primary work in Indian schools. She had had no Normal training, but appears to have a special talent for instructing the small children. The senior room is in charge of Sister A. Gagnon who had had seven years experience. She has had no Normal training; her standing is Grade 12, academic. The pupils appeared to be making fairly good progress.

They have been operating a farm in connection with this school of over 100 acres of cultivated land, but this land is not being seeded this year as the present school will be evacuated at the end of June when it is expected.

SADDLE LAKE, ALBERTA.

May 27th, 1931.

Sir:-

Referring to your letter No.118-1-5 of the 6th instant in regard to buildings and equipment at the Blue Quill's Residential school at Sacred Heart, I beg to submit herewith, list of buildings, equipment, furniture, etc., with notations regarding condition. With the exception of the two 6 h.p. gas engines, power washer, extractor, combination hand and power washing machine, dough mixer, cream separator and pump, the equipment is mostly old. The Beaver Power Washes and extractor will not be required at the new school and these could probably be disposed of. The Sisters of the St. Therese Hospital at St. Paul have made enquiries regarding the washer and extractor. The two 6 h.p. gas engines, hand and power washing machine, dough mixer and cream separator could be used at the new school.

As noted on the list, the buildings are in a very poor state of repair. The main building was built in two sections and I am informed that one part of the building is about 30 years old and the other section which was first used at Lac la Biche, 40 years old. Additions were apparently made at different times shortly after the main building was erected. This building is of no practical value in its present location and owing to its construction and present condition, it would be practically impossible to move it. Most of the windows are in fair condition and the Reverend Principal states that he might be able to use some of these in outbuildings at the new school. Owing to the cost and the time that it would take to pull down the old buildings, I am of the opinion that a very low price would be offered if the buildings were offered for sale as they stand. The buildings might be demolished and considerable useful material salvaged. In this connection, I might mention that the Indians of Saddle Lake reserve have been discussing the matter of erecting a council house. It is possible that this building could be disposed of to the Band. I have not mentioned the matter to the Indians but if the Department considered disposing of all or a part of the main building in this manner, I could take the matter up with them. The Indians of James Seenum's Band may object to using Band funds for this

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
purpose but I am of the opinion that the Indians of the Saddle Lake reserve would be willing to use part of the revenue which may be derived from pasturage dues on the Saddle Lake reserve. Should part of the building only be disposed of in this manner, the other parts might be disposed of in sections and any part or material which may be considered useful at the Agency, might be taken over.

Your obedient servant,

W.E. Gullion
Indian Agent.

A frigidaire plant is provided for cold storage purposes. The whole building appears to be well planned for the purpose for which it is to be used.

A section of land has been set aside for the use of this institution, and at the present time work is being proceeded with in clearing 100 acres of land in preparation for breaking during the coming summer.

I am attaching snapshots of front and rear views of this building.

The Rev. Father Angin is now in charge as Principal and business manager. This school was formerly managed by the Grey Nuns, but is now in charge of the Oblate Order. He appears to be energetic, and impressed me as having a fairly good knowledge of business methods. He is assisted by a Lay Brother and a Farming Instructor, as well as a staff of 8 Sisters of Charity.

NEW SCHOOL.

I made an inspection of the new school building near St. Paul, and found the building nearing completion. The painters were at work. It is a fine brick building; the floors and stairways are reinforced concrete, and the building should be pretty well fireproof. I was greatly pleased with the workmanship on this building. It impressed me as being first class; in fact, the best finish I have seen in connection with any of our recently built residential schools.

A good supply of soft water appears to have been obtained in a well 264 ft. deep. The pumping test, at the rate of 600 gals. per hour, did not lower the water level.

The building is connected with the Calgary Power Company's system, and the laundry machinery will all be run by electricity.

Explanations of Work additional to Contract.

Sir:

With regard to the accompanying list of work performed additional to the general contract, by The J. McDiarmid Co., Ltd., contractors for the above mentioned school, I shall go over the list briefly in the order in which the items are enumerated, and add explanations. You will note I have made a few adjustments in the amounts charged in instances in which the costs seemed excessive, and I have written the contractors at their Calgary office giving my reasons for making the deductions.

Items.

1. **6" COURSE OF BROKEN STONE UNDER BASEMENT FLOOR.** This was not included in the contract, but after the general excavation was completed it was found that ground moisture was present, so this work was subsequently authorized by the Department. The foundation walls and pier foundations were by this time in place, and teams and scrapers could not be used, so this work had to be done entirely by hand. In checking this account it seemed to me that too much labour had been inadvertently charged for the excavating, hence my adjustment.

2. **CHANGES IN PLUMBING.** The Rev. Principal requested that the Engineer's Room be provided with a wash basin, and the waste and vent connections at this point added to the cost. The sink and lavatory were deemed essential, and a good sized one has been installed. The Principal also requested a wash basin in his bedroom, and as this had been provided in other schools, one was placed there for his use. The ash buckets are for the removal of ashes from the heating boilers. The pump at cistern is for raising the soft water for laundry and heating boilers. The charge of $444.15 is for an entirely separate cast iron roof-water line, consisting of 115' of 6" C.I. pipe, and 4" branches, as shown on the plumber's detail sheet attached. This line discharges into a slight depression at the rear of the school, and not through the septic tank. The laundry and kitchen wastes, and the general sewage are discharged to a southerly side sewer, outside the "water tower" site. This means we have three 6" C.I. drains under the basement floor instead of the two drains called for in the specifications. The reason for running the rain water in a separate drain is because of the slight fall in the main sewer, and it was feared that in case of exceptionally heavy rain the main sewer after it leaves the septic tank might not be able to function fast enough. In consultation with Mr. French, of the Water Branch, Calgary, and after taking levels carefully, it was decided to discharge the rain water separately, as stated. The charge of $35.15 is for connecting the 2500 gal. cold water storage tank to the line inside the school. The charge of $79.75 is for providing a vent from the girls' north dormitory on the 1st floor. No vent had been provided in the specifications, and the Principal stated it was equally important that this dormitory be vented too. The charge of $81.00 for "vents in Chapel" was incurred in making connection to the roof vents shown in the roof plan of Chapel, and bringing said vents down to near the floor level, exactly as was shown in the Old Suns plans under similar conditions. The cost of $68.40 resulted from the Rev. Principal's earnest request that the staff bath-room on the ground floor be partitioned off, thus giving separate access...
Items:

2. The charge of $39.10 is the plumber's charge for diverting the rain water from the Chapel and laundry roofs to the cistern under laundry. The local people were desirous to have facilities for lawn watering, hence the charge of $50.65. The last charge of $12.18 is for bringing cold water to the compressor of the refrigerating system.

3. The concrete cistern below laundry was specially authorized by the Department, and provides a large reservoir of rain water from the Chapel and laundry roofs. The cost of $500.00 is less than elsewhere.

4. Further Changes in Plumbing. The 3 items under this heading are self-explanatory, and were authorized at the prices stated.

5. Increasing Height of Chimneys, also specially authorized by the Department because of the proximity of a treed knoll, and to give better draft.

6. Venting Roof Spaces, to prevent the condensation of moisture on the under side of roof during extreme cold weather. Eleven ventilators have been installed, 6 on the main roof, and five on the rear roofs.

7. Plug Receptacles, Light Outlets & Extra Switches, at the special request of the Rev. Father and Sister Superior. These consist of:
   - Plug Receptacle in Principal's Inner Office.
   - " west side of Chancel.
   - " Sewing room.
   - " Community room.
   - " Matron's room.
   - Light & switch in basement rear corridor.
   - Pilot Light in Cold Storage room.
   - 3-way switch in boiler room
   - Extra switch & light in re-arranged bath room, gr. flr.
   - Switch for Sun room, 1st floor.

8. Additional Electric Work. The Item of $24.05 under this heading covers the cost of a switch at the outside entrance of boiler room, and for the lighting of the new tank room where the large cold water storage tank is placed. The charge of $52.00 was specially authorized by the Department for special work and material in bringing power current to the laundry machines, bakery, and to the motor in 2nd chamber of septic tank. The charge of $71.90 is for sundry items shown on the attached detail sheet, and including an extra fire gong on the boys' side of the solid partition wall of the top storey.

9. Experimenting with Deep Well Originally Drilled. It would take an entire chapter to explain fully this Item, but I think it will suffice when I say that we exhausted every means to the effort to bring this well into production, and thus secure for the school a soft water supply. There has been much correspondence on the subject, and I think the circumstances are understood by the Department. In the end we had to abandon this well, but the Lord directed us to another spot, and we have now an assured supply of healthy soft water in a 2nd deep well. The charge of $108.90 shown in this account was for boarding the well-driller and helper while working on the 1st deep well in the effort to restore it, and for a short time after they commenced on the 2nd deep well. The total charge of $121.32 for this item is in order, and I may say I much appreciate the cooperation I received from the contractors; on one occasion their men worked nearly all night lowering and raising pipes and cylinders.

10. Drain at Rear of Building. This Item covers digging the trench and laying tile, and back-filling, for the rain water line carried to a depression at the rear of the school.
Items:

11. Door between Coal Bin & Boiler Room. Because of the fine dust which steam coal gives off when being shovelled into the coal bin, it is necessary to have practically an air-tight door to prevent the dust from penetrating. This is practically a refrigerator door, with door and frame metal covered.

12. Waterline from well to Building. This includes a trench 7' deep and about 300 feet long, and full length of 2½" gal. pipe, and backfilling. This work was deferred till the ground was frozen to about a foot in depth, which made it more expensive; also a short part of it had to be cribbed against shifting. This trench connects the school water system with the shallow well of hard water which was drilled before the work of construction was started. It will make a valuable auxiliary supply in case of a temporary break down of the main pumping plant.

13. Pressure Tank Chamber, and Door from Boiler Room. This concrete chamber, 9' x 21', with reinforced slab roof at grade level, houses the low water storage tank. Access to this room is from the boiler room, and this necessitated cutting a doorway through a 10" concrete wall. This Item also included freight on the storage tank from Edmonton, carriage to the school, and installing the tank on a suitable foundation. The further wall of this chamber is in 8" brick, with cement mortar, so that in the event of the tank having someday to be replaced, no concrete cutting will be necessary, it being much easier and cheaper to make an opening in a brick wall than to cut through concrete.

14. Erecting Belfrey and Installing Bell. This work has been exceptionally well done, but also exceptionally expensive compared with similar installations elsewhere. I have therefore deducted $45.50 under this heading.

15. Framing Blackboards. This covers the cost of building out a framework so that all the blackboards in the various class rooms may be in a continuous unbroken line instead of being broken where piers are met with. This was stressed as very important by the teachers.

16. Panelling Columns in Recreation Rooms & Wash Rooms. These columns were deemed unsafe by the school staff because of the sharp edges. To lath and plaster them was considered unsuitable in play rooms where certain damage would result. On the suggestion of the contractors' foreman I consented to having them panelled 5'-6" high, and a splendid job has been made of it, both in strength and appearance. However, here again too expensive work has been done, and I have felt called upon to make a small deduction under this heading.

17. Additional Hinges on Doors. Throughout the interior of this building we have an unusual number of wide doors, and as they are of 1 3/4" fir stock, they are quite heavy. The contractors strongly advised placing a third hinge to hold these doors securely, to which I assented.

18. Barrel Bolts and Screws on Storm Sashes. These bolts are placed so that the upper storm sash where "Superior" windows are in use can be readily removed. By this arrangement the "Superior" windows are allowed to function as intended by the inventor, instead of the upper half being blocked by a non-removable storm window. The storm windows can now be taken down out of the way very quickly. The screws are for securing the upper half of the storm windows elsewhere throughout the building, so that for cleaning purposes they can be much more readily removed than if fastened solid with nails.
19. **Friction Stays on Casement Sash.** These stays are attached to the top of the casement sash, are up out of the way, and the tension is adjustable. After much investigation this is the only type of adjustment I have discovered for use where casement sash open in. The purpose of them is to prevent damage from the sash being blown about in the wind. I'm sure they will pay for themselves in a short time in districts subject to high winds.

20. **Sump at end of rainwater line.** The purpose of this rock-pit is to allow a slow drip or xin roof water in the winter time to get away instead of being frozen at the mouth of the line. At times when the noonday sun causes a slight melting of snow on the roof, it is feared that the outlet of the rainwater line might gradually freeze unless protected. This precaution was specially recommended by Mr. Bongford, Sr., when on a visit here from Winnipeg. However, in the digging of this sump, excessive labour has crept in, and even allowing for winter conditions of digging, the labour cost is disproportionately high. I have therefore made a deduction of $32.00 under this heading. I don't think there was any intention of overcharging, and probably the mistake is a book-keeping or time-keeping one.

21. **Changing Fire Escape Doors to Windows on Ground Floor.** By a glance at the Plans of the building it may be observed that the rear elevation shows the outlets or exits to the fire escapes on the ground floor to be from doors. The ground floor plan shows these exits as from windows—if that they are intended to be. As the Rev. Principal was very desirous to remodel the staff bathroom on the ground floor, from which little room access to the west fire escape could only be had, he asked to change the door shown on the elevation to a window, as shown on the floor plan. As the building is fire-proofed and as exits from the ground floor can be from the main front entrance, and also from the rear stairways, it was not considered necessary to make the change as asked for, which now gives a bathroom subdivided as desired. In both cases on this floor, the windows have replaced the doors shown in the elevation as giving exits to the fire escapes, and the charge of $72.49 represents the extra cost to the contractors, as shown in their detail sheet.

22. **Iron Ladder to Chapel Roof.** Access to the Chapel roof is necessary for inspection of roof hoppers occasionally, and for other purposes. A sturdy iron ladder has been installed.

23. **Extra Concrete of Rear Foundation Walls.** As we raised the grade of the building 22 inches so as to improve the sewage disposal conditions, and as the natural grade fell away at the rear of the building, more concrete was necessary in bringing up the rear foundation walls. The charge under this heading is a fair one.

24. **Extra Work on Septic Tank.** This work consisted principally of installing a weir of iron rods for preventing the possibility of solid crust passing from the septic tank into the sewage chamber, thereby perhaps choking the sewage lift pump. Also under this heading was included some additional woodwork to prevent frost penetration. This additional work was authorized by Mr. French in my absence, and on showing him the bill for same he demurred at the labour cost, which he said was twice what he expected. On the strength of Mr. French's representation, I have deducted $10.00 from the labour charged.

25. **Painting Extra Vents.** This is the cost of painting the extra vent to girls' Dormitory, the extensions to the toilets in basement, and the Chapel vents where exposed.
Superior Windows for Class-rooms & Dormitories. This change was authorized by the Department after the main contract was let, and I was advised by telegram of it. On asking the contractors for their authority for charging the $452.00 extra, they replied that the additional cost was agreed to between their Winnipeg office and the Department.

This brings me to the end of the list of additional charges, and while the grand total aggregates a somewhat formidable figure, it must be borne in mind that the great majority of the work represents substantial and permanent services, and adds proportionately to the value of the general investment. It would be entirely fallacious to regard anything on the list in the light of the proverbial "extras" that an unscrupulous or tricky contractor wont to slip over an unwary inspector! The bulk of the additional work was specially authorized by the Department, and a few additional items which I have taken it on myself to order are only such as the Department has approved under similar circumstances in previous schools built under my inspection.

It would be negligent on my part if I failed to testify to the integrity and efficiency of the J. McDiarmid Co., in the carrying out of this important contract. They have used good materials throughout, and have employed capable workmen, and as a result we are getting a high-class job of construction. Their local representatives have co-operated with me wholeheartedly, and during my enforced absence from the work on account of illness not the slightest advantage was taken.

Now I must close this long-winded review. If, despite my loquacity, there is anything I have omitted to explain, I shall be glad to do so on my attention being called to it.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

BETWEEN:

SOUTHERN ELECTRIC COMPANY LIMITED a body corporate with its head office at the City of Montreal, in the Province of Quebec (hereinafter called "the Power Company")

OF THE FIRST PART

- and -

HIS MAJESTY KING GEORGE THE FIFTH represented by the Minister of the Interior of Canada (Department of Indian Affairs), (hereinafter called "the Customer")

OF THE SECOND PART

WHEREAS the Power Company is a corporation duly incorporated under the laws of the Dominion of Canada and operates an hydro-electric power system in the Province of Alberta, as a licensee of Dominion Water Powers, virtue licenses granted to it by the Minister of the Interior of Canada pursuant to and subject to the provisions of the Dominion Water Power Act, being Chapter 210 of the Revised Statutes of Canada 1927 and/or The Dominion Lands Act and the Dominion Water Power Regulations passed by the Governor General in Council under the authority of the said Acts.

AND WHEREAS the Customer has established and operates an Indian Residential School known as "Blue Quills Indian Residential School" the same being situated on the North east quarter of Section Eleven (11), Township Fifty eight (58), Range Ten (10) West of the 5th Meridian.

AND WHEREAS the Power Company proposes to extend at the cost of the Customer, its electrical transmission system now being operated in the Village of St.Paul in the Province of Alberta, so as to be in position to supply the Customer at said Indian Residential School with electrical power and energy as hereinafter provided.

AND WHEREAS the Customer is willing to purchase from the Power Company all the Customer's entire requirements of electrical power and energy for use in said Indian Residential School and all buildings connected, used or operated, for the purpose of said School, said School and said buildings being
hereinafter referred to as "said School premises".

NOW THEREFORE THIS AGREEMENT WITNESSETH that the Parties hereto covenant, promise and agree, the one with the other as follows:

1. COMMENCEMENT OF SUPPLY

The Power Company shall commence the supply of electrical energy and power hereunder to the Customer on or before the First day of January, A.D.1921.

2. TERM OF CONTRACT.

This contract shall remain in full force and effect for a period of five (5) years from the date of commencement of supply hereunder. The Customer shall from the date at which supply hereunder can be commenced purchase from the Power Company the Customer's entire requirements of electrical energy and power in said School premises during the life of this agreement. The Power Company shall, from the date at which it commences supply hereunder, sell and deliver to the Customer all electrical energy and power required by it from time to time for use in said School premises, during the life of this contract.

3. VOLTAGE AND FREQUENCY

The electrical energy and power to be supplied hereunder shall be furnished in the following manner,

(a) For power, lighting and domestic purposes, in the form of three phase alternating current, at a normal pressure of two hundred and twenty (220) volts,

PROVIDED always that said electrical energy and power to be supplied as aforesaid shall have a normal frequency of sixty (60) cycles per second, with a variation in the aforesaid respective voltages of generally not more than six (6%) per cent above or below normal, and a variation in frequency of generally not more than one (1%) per cent above or below normal.

4. SERVICE

The Power Company shall endeavor to maintain normal voltage and frequency and render service equal to that usually furnished by modern engine driven electrical plants where conditions are similar, and the Customer shall use the electrical energy and power to be supplied hereunder only
for the Customer's aforesaid purposes, and all apparatus and equipment shall be installed and maintained and said electrical energy and power shall be used by the Customer in such a manner as not to cause sudden fluctuations in the demand for the said energy and power such as would cause disturbance to the system of the Power Company.

5. CONTINUITY OF SERVICE.

The Power Company shall cause to be taken all usual precautions to guard against interruptions or diminutions in the supply of electrical energy and power to the Customer, and shall cause to be terminated such interruptions and diminutions with all possible despatch. If interruptions or diminutions are necessary or unavoidable for repair, overhauling or inspection of equipment or for improving or adding to its equipment the Power Company shall give the Customer reasonable notice of the same. If Possible, and shall cause such interruptions or diminutions to be made at such time as to cause the minimum inconvenience and loss to the Customer.

6. RATES OR PRICES

AVAILABLE FOR ALL PURPOSES.

SERVICE CHARGE

$1.00 per month per horse power or kilowatt of installation with a minimum of Sixteen ($16.00) Dollars per month.

ENERGY CHARGE

First 100 K.W.H. per month per K.V.A. at Twelve (12¢) cents.

All over 100 K.W.H. per month per K.V.A. at Six (6¢) cents

Prompt payment discount - ten (10%) per cent on the even Dollars.

7. METERING EQUIPMENT

The electrical energy and power to be supplied by the Power Company to the Customer shall be measured by suitable recording meters to be supplied and installed by the Power Company on the high tension side of the point where the Tap hereinafter agreed to be constructed for the Customer connects with the Company's present distribution line in said Village of St. Paul. IT BEING AGREED that for the purposes of this agreement the metering equipment shall be deemed to be the point of delivery of electrical energy and power supplied hereunder to the customer.
8. REPAIRS OF METERS

The meters for the measurement of the electrical energy and power supplied hereunder shall at all times be kept in good working order, and shall be tested from time to time to determine their accuracy.

The Power Company shall notify the Customer whenever it intends to have the said metering equipment tested so that the Customer may have a representative present at the test if the Customer so desires.

9. TESTING OF METERS

If at any time the Customer is not satisfied as to the accuracy of its said metering equipment it may upon giving ten (10) days' notice to the Power Company have the said metering equipment tested or calibrated by a competent person delegated so to do by the Department of Trade and Commerce of the Dominion of Canada. If such test or calibration shows that such metering equipment is in error by more than two (2%) per cent then such metering equipment shall forthwith be corrected or replaced by one that is accurate. If the inaccuracy of the metering equipment as shown by such test demanded by the Customer is found to be such that the quantity of power delivered as recorded by it is in error by more than two (2%) per cent then the Power Company shall bear the cost of the test. The bills for power supplied during the two calendar months preceding such tests shall be corrected in the proportion of the error of the metering equipment provided such error exceeds the aforesaid limit of two per cent (2%) per cent such correction shall be accepted by the Customer and the Power Company as settlement in full to that date of all claims on account of inaccuracy of metering equipment.

10. WIRING

The Customer shall assume all obligations, risk and responsibility in connection with all wiring done or caused to be done by the Customer from the point of entry of such wiring into all buildings on said School premises, including therein all wiring done on the School premises on the low tension side of said Tap on said School premises, for the purpose of connecting the respective buildings thereon and also including all wiring done by the Power Company on said School premises, at the request of or under agreement with the Customer.

11. PAYMENT OF ACCOUNTS

The Power Company shall render its account to the Customer in each calendar month for the electrical energy and power
supplied during the previous month and the Customer agrees to make payment of the same within ten days of the rendering of every such account; all payments to be made at the Edmonton Office of the Power Company.

The Power Company may, on giving five (5) days' written notice to the Customer and without prejudice to any of its other legal remedies, cut off the supply of electrical energy and power to the Customer in the event of any amount due for electrical energy and power under the provisions of this agreement concerning the existence of which there is no bona fide dispute, remaining unpaid after the same shall have become due under this agreement.

12. ACT OF GOD etc.

If at any time during the continuance of this agreement the operation of the works or either of the parties hereto is suspended or curtailed owing to war, rebellion, act of God or other causes beyond the control of such party, the party whose operations are suspended or curtailed shall not be liable to the other party under this agreement until the cause of such suspension or curtailment has been removed. Provided that each of the parties hereto shall take all reasonable precautions and adopt all reasonable measures to prevent or remove the cause of such suspension or curtailment.

PROVIDED HOWEVER and it is understood between the parties hereto that in order to supply electrical energy and power hereunder the Company has agreed to build and extend a Tap at the costs and as the property of the Customer, from a point on the Company's present distribution system in said Village of St.Paul to the School premises of the Customer and that if for any reason the Power Company is prevented or hindered in so building such Tap by reason of weather conditions or other unforeseen cause the date of the commencement of supply hereunder as provided in Paragraph One (1) hereof shall be extended accordingly.

12. TAP CONNECTION

The Customer having agreed to pay the cost of the construction of the necessary Tap for the supply of service hereunder from a point on the Power Company's distribution system in the said Village of St.Paul, the Power Company agrees to construct said Tap for the sum of Four thousand, Nine Hundred and ninety seven ($4997.00) Dollars and the Customer shall pay said agreed cost to the Power Company on or before the First day of June, A.D.1931 IT BEING HEREBY AGREED AND DECLARED that said Tap shall include any transformers, lightning arresters,
circuit breakers or other similar or protective apparatus attached to or used or employed in connection with said Tap for the purpose of supplying electric energy and power hereunder and shall also include the cost of any right of way required for said Tap, PROVIDED HOWEVER that the Customer shall allow the Power Company to enter upon and build and maintain upon and over its property and premises such metering equipment, transformer stations and other apparatus as may be necessary for the delivery of electric power and energy hereunder; the locations however to be such as may be mutually agreed upon AND FURTHER PROVIDED that notwithstanding the Customer being the owner of said Tap, the Customer shall during the term of this agreement, release from the Power Company and take over said Tap and without any charge or cost to the Power Company for the use or maintenance of said Tap, its aforesaid entire requirements of electrical energy and power on the terms and in the conditions in said agreement contained.

14. The Customer further agrees that the Power Company shall be at liberty during the term of this agreement to use said Tap for the purpose of transmitting electrical energy and power to such consumers as the Power Company shall desire to serve thereby or therefrom, and the Power Company shall pay to the Customer for such use of said Tap such sums as may be agreed upon between the parties hereto and in the event of disagreement the amount so to be paid by the Power Company shall be referred to an Arbitrator to be agreed upon by the parties hereto and in case of disagreement to an Arbitrator to be appointed by a Judge of the Supreme Court of Alberta, and in either case in accordance with and subject to the provisions of the Arbitration Act.

THIS agreement and everything herein contained shall endure to the benefit of and be binding upon the parties hereto, their and each of their successors and assigns respectively.

Re- Blue Quills School, St. Paul, Alta.

Sir:

With further reference to the water service for the new deep well at this school, I duly received the Department's telegram of the 19th instant giving authority for building the pump house, in which I was also told that I would be further advised concerning the purchase of the pump.

The pump house is now completed, and the present would be an opportune time for setting up the pumping equipment while the contractors' help is still available. The plumbing and heating contractor (Mr. Rieve) returned here today to make a final check-up on the services he has installed to see that everything is working satisfactorily; and tomorrow he expects the Provincial Boiler Inspector to come and test out the boilers, and issue the required permits. Mr. Rieve is an experienced man on pumping equipment, and has the proper tools for doing this work, and it would be advantageous to employ him for this pumping installation.

I enclose a cut and specifications of the "McDougall Self Oiling Deep Well Working Head" that is recommended to us by Beatty Bros., Ltd., Edmonton Branch. The Beatty people stock this pump in Edmonton, and keep the repair parts, and their traveller covers this territory. In case of a breakdown prompt service and repairs would be quickly available. They recommend a 3" working barrel cylinder, 3" well piping, and a 5 H.P. motor, and as previously mentioned their price is $475.00 for the complete equipment, F.O.B. Edmonton. This includes octagon hard wood pump rods with forged screwed couplings.

Should the McDougall outfit meet with the Department's approval I shall be pleased to order the same and have it installed very soon; or if some other design is preferred by the Department, I shall be equally pleased to arrange for the installation of same. In the meantime we shall have to depend on the courtesy of the general contractors to allow us to use their temporary pumping plant so as to keep pressure in the building.

Hoping to receive the Department's decision by telegram or early letter,

I have the honour to be, Sir

Your obedient servant

Re- Blue Quills School.

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith my Time and Expense Account for the months of February and March.

As previously reported, I have been prevented by illness from giving full time to my work. However, even from a sick bed I have kept in close touch with whatever was going on at the job, and gave directions and instructions as occasion required, besides visiting the work by taxi from the hospital at St. Paul whenever I felt able to do so. As by this time the general contract was well advanced, I feel that nothing suffered in consequence of my enforced absence during the worst of my illness in St. Paul.

On my arrival in Calgary on March 1st I suffered a relapse, probably caused by my leaving the hospital at St. Paul too soon, and I have been under medical treatment here ever since. However, I still endeavoured to keep in close touch with the work by correspondence and long-distance 'phone. The contractors' representative (Mr. Borgford) called on me frequently, and I believe the final work has gone on much the same as if I had been present all the time in person. My daughter, who is an accomplished stenographer employed in the office of the Hudsons' Bay Co here, came almost daily to take my dictation and write my letters so that nothing was neglected nor allowed to get into arrears. I am now hopeful of being back on my job by the end of the month.

You will note that I am charging the Department with half-time for Feb'y and March, as this seemed to me to be a fair and honest adjustment under all the circumstances. Should this arrangement not meet with the Department's approval, I can only ask that you adjust the account as seems right to you.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Inspector of Construction.

Government of the Province of Alberta

Poultry House
Scale 1/8" = 1' June '30

Directions:
The construction of the poultry house consists of a concrete foundation and floor, the floor being 6" above the back to accommodate the poultrymen's feet when they enter at the back of the building. The walls are constructed with 6" studding, 2 ply of paper, and 3 ply of lathing. The six inch space between the lathing is packed tightly with cotton waste or shavings. The ceiling is also boarded tightly above which is a layer of paper and insulating material. The cotton waste in the front admits the fresh air from a slant through the ventilation extending from a point 10" above the floor and through the roof. Double windows of glass are used and arranged that they may be opened and closed easily. Ventilation is provided by a small part of the roof that may be opened and closed by means of the open ventilators.

Fittings—Each 100 hens require a hopper four feet long for feeding purposes. Sixteen hens require placed boxes with ventilators to meet the requirements of the birds. Water troughs 4" long, 6" wide, and 6" deep and constructed of galvanized iron are used; one each trough in the small pen and two in the larger. Troughs are installed on the end wall of each room. These may also be used as common seats when not required for feeding. Wherever electricity is available, the buildings should be wired. The design of hanging light globes will be outlined if drop cords are here used to place a right fixture on the ceiling.

Re- New Blue Quills School, St. Paul, Alta.

Sir:

With reference to my Report of May 15th, perhaps the time is now opportune for bringing to the attention of the Department again some of the matters referred to in said Report.

The pump chamber, as authorized by the Department in the telegram of May 19th, was completed by The J. McDiarmaid Co., Ltd., some time ago, the account for which will soon be forwarded for payment.

With regard to the pumping equipment required, I called on the 5 Edmonton firms mentioned in the Department's letter of June 24th, and procured tenders. The best price was secured from Messrs O'Neill-Morkin Machinery Co., so the order was placed with this firm for a Canadian-made "McDougall" deep well pump with a 12" stroke, and with the working parts enclosed in oil. This is a recent addition to the McDougall line. The pump will be driven by a 5 HP motor, with automatic starter and cut-out. This model had to be ordered from Galt, Ont., and my last advice was that it was to be shipped on July 24th, so we are now in daily expectation of its arrival. Through the courtesy of the general contractors, we have been allowed to use their temporary pumping outfit for keeping up pressure in the building pending the arrival of the permanent plant.

Is it the intention to paint the concrete floors and base in the various rooms and passageways? As no concrete hardener was specified or used, it would be a distinct advantage to paint these surfaces with a good concrete paint, such as that made for the purpose by the Sherwin-Williams Co. This treatment would add to the wearing qualities of the cement floors, prevent dusting of the surfaces where exposed to much wear, and add to the appearance of the floors. The concrete is now all thoroughly dry, and in excellent shape for taking the treatment suggested.

In the two recreation rooms in the basement there are 14 windows which, perhaps, should be protected with wire guards such as have been installed in other schools. If this should be authorized, I should like authority also to include wire guards to protect the exposed belts and pulleys of the laundry machines.

Regarding the additional millwork required to complete the building, such as tables, benches, shelving, pews, etc., I shall be glad to carry out any instructions concerning these
requirements. I gathered from a previous letter that it was the Department's intention to prepare a detailed list of these articles, and call for tenders from Ottawa.

No doubt the Department has in mind the need for a stock barn for the school farm, and I shall be glad to supervise the erection of this important building. One or two St. Paul men are anxious to get this work, but from what I can learn of their performances elsewhere in the district I should hesitate to award important construction to them, unless under very close supervision regarding both workmanship and materials.

The Rev. Principal states that a hen-house and piggery are also needed. In this connection I wrote to the Alberta Department of Agriculture asking if they could supply plans for these auxiliary buildings, and in reply I received a plan of a poultry building, which I am enclosing herewith. This plan might be reduced in length to keep down the cost, and it could be extended afterwards as occasion required, and as funds permitted. It seems a good design of building for this climate.

In my Report of May 15th I drew attention to the well that was drilled for the work of construction, situated about 400' distant from the school building. A 2½" gal. water pipe has been laid in a 7' trench connecting this well with the school water system, and although this water is very hard and not recommended for general use, it would serve very well as an auxiliary system in case of a breakdown in the main pumping service from the deep well of soft water located close to the storage tank. I suggested that it might prove advantageous to install an inexpensive gasoline-driven pump at the shallower well so that in case of any mishap to the main water supply, or any interruption in the electric current from St. Paul, this auxiliary service could be brought into operation at once. There is ample water in this shallower well too. Should the Department sanction providing this additional water supply, should we not erect an inexpensive frame pump-house, about 8' x 10', to give protection to the pumping plant at this well?

Awaiting the Department's further instructions, which will receive my careful and prompt attention,

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Inspector of Construction.

P.S. Unlike the central prairies, we have had a superabundance of moisture in this district, and the crops could scarcely look better. During the past fortnight excessive and unwanted rains have been frequent, and almost continuous. Weather report enclosed.

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith a Voucher for $157.50, in favour of Mr. J.E. Frederickson, well driller, for services rendered in connection with the water supply for this school, as shown on his detailed statement enclosed herewith.

It will be noted that this account includes an item of $90.00 for salvaging the well casing in the well we were obliged to abandon. Owing to an unexpected delay in the arrival of the new pump from Galt, Ontario, and as Mr. Frederickson had in the meantime arrived on the job with his outfit in readiness for installing the new pump and heavier well piping, I took it on myself to employ him during part of the interval in salvaging as much as possible of the casing in the abandoned well. We were successful in recovering casing as follows:

- 230' of 4½" casing.
- 180' " 5" "
- 60' " 5 5/8" "
or 470' altogether.

The Department will recover two or three times the cost of pulling this casing. The R.C. Church, at a parish just west of St. Paul, is taking 100' of the 5" casing, and I have $74.00 ready to remit to Ottawa as soon as I can get time to go to the bank. Some of this casing is bent and dinted from driving, and otherwise damaged, but the great bulk of it is fit to use again.

The 2nd item, $67.50, is self-explanatory, and in order.

Yesterday I had the electrician here from the town plant to connect the current to the motor of pump, after which the new pumping service was started. For a few minutes everything went fine, then suddenly the water stopped coming, and the pump stuck. The well-driller said sand had choked the cylinder. Fortunately his rig is still here, although it was his intention to pull out today to the R.C. job, but he will remain until we overcome the trouble. Today he is taking up the well piping and cylinder. (He has just come in to say he now has the piping and cylinder raised, and mud and sand has caused the trouble)

Apparently the change from the small capacity of the contractors' pump (225 gals. an hour) to one of 600 gals an hour has had the effect of raising mud and sand with the water, with the result mentioned.
The driller proposes to clean out the well by drilling and bailing; and then connect up the new pump quickly, and pump continuously day and night for perhaps a week so as to keep any sediment moving. He thinks once the building becomes occupied, with the large daily consumption of water that will then take place, the recurrence of such trouble as we are now having will be much less likely. Of course it will not require the presence of the driller for this continuous pumping which he recommends; the caretaker can look after that. The water will be allowed to run to waste outside until this initial test is completed. Then there will be a little work for the plumber connecting the new pump to the large storage tank, which he can do when here to attend to a few slight adjustments in his other work. I shall notify him when to come.

I shall keep the Department advised regarding developments in restoring the water supply. I have the highest confidence in Mr. Fredericksen, and am much relieved to know that he and his rig are now right on the job. Once the water question is on a satisfactory basis I shall return to Calgary, as it is noted that the Department will be unable to retain my services longer. In another letter I shall testify more fully to my appreciation of the unfailing courtesy and kindness which I have received from the Department officers.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

[Signature]

Inspector of Construction.

P.S. The long-continued wet weather referred to in my letter of the 7th instant is being succeeded by fine dry weather, although a furious electrical storm swept through this district on the 21st, with much damage to crops.

Sir:

With reference to my letter of the 24th ultimo, in which I reported trouble in the new well at this school caused by sand and mud choking the cylinder, I am now able to report that the well-driller, Mr. Fredericksop, and helper, after raising the piping and cleaning out the cylinder, drilled and bailed out the well. Two days ago the pump was again started, and has since been running continuously, with most encouraging results. We are now pumping at the rate of 600 gals. per hour, delivering the water outside where it runs to waste. The driller thinks it was the long period of comparative inactivity in the pumping of water that allowed the accumulation of sediment and sand in the well. He recommends that almost continuous pumping take place until such a time as the building becomes occupied, and that then the normal daily consumption of water by the school will prevent any repetition of the trouble we have experienced. Eventually the water vein is expected to clear itself. The water now being pumped is of excellent quality, and only slightly cloudy.

The plumber is now here making connections from the new pumping plant to the large storage tank in the adjoining chamber. While this work is being done I am having him make provision for the future delivery of water under pressure to the barn, from the pneumatic storage tank. I shall refer more fully to this feature in a separate letter on the subject of the new barn, the plans and specifications of which were received by the last mail.

The plumber, in addition to making connection to the pressure tank, will provide a branch line outside, so that besides keeping up pressure in the building, the main delivery of water during the next few weeks will be outside, as previously mentioned, in keeping with the driller's recommendation. I do not anticipate any further trouble with this well; on the contrary I expect it to prove of inestimable value in this district where good water is indeed rare.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

E. Gardner Smith
Inspector of Construction.

Re- Proposed Combination Barn.

Sir:

This will acknowledge the receipt of the plans and specifications of the proposed new combination barn designed for this school; also the Department's letter of the 27th ultimo instructing me to give tenderers the location of the barn, which I shall be pleased to do.

I also received the Department's telegram of the 25th ultimo asking me to continue as Inspector until Sept 15th, and for which slight extension of employment please accept my thanks.

Regarding the plan of the barn, it will certainly make a most creditable building, and should be most acceptable to the school staff; and prove an object lesson to the farmers of the district.

It is noted that the barn is to be equipped with water-bowls, and provided with an inside water-trough. This will call for care and experience in the plumbing, and the whole system of water supply should be so installed that the water intake could be shut off and the various lines drained in the event of danger of freezing at times of extremely low temperatures.

No doubt it is the Department's intention to deliver water under pressure from the school water system. I have had this in mind from the first, and when the water line was laid from the shallow well to the school I had a tee placed at a convenient point in readiness for a branch line to the future barn. The plumber now at work here connecting the new pumping plant at the school to the pneumatic storage tank is being instructed to connect the pipe line from the shallow well to the outlet from the pressure tank. This line is already laid in a 7' trench from the shallow well about 400' distant from the school where it was hoped the Department might authorize the installing of an auxiliary gasoline driven pump and small pump house which would be immediately available in the event of any interruption in the main service. However, as no funds were available for this suggested auxiliary service, we shall cap this line at its farther end below frost line, and should it ever be found necessary or desirable to utilize the shallow well, it would be a simple job to connect up with the line already laid. In the meantime this line will remain full of water; and at the said location of the tee the barn supply will be taken off. A gate valve is being placed on this line close to the pressure tank so that delivery of water to the barn can be controlled.
The site of the new barn is about 300' distant from the tee from which the service to the barn water system will be taken off. This will call for the digging of a trench at least 7' deep, and the laying of a galvanized water line of not less than 1½". This line should pass under the foundation of the barn, and rise inside the building to feed the regulating tank of water bowls, and with a branch feed line to the water trough in passageway beside the feed room. As already stated, provision should be made for emptying the barn service.

Regarding the electric lighting of the barn, this has also been anticipated, and a service main is in readiness on the outside wall of the school for extending the electric current to the barn. Also, when the Calgary Power Co. built the pole line from St. Paul I got their foreman to leave us sufficient poles for the barn line too.

I have not yet gone over the plans and specifications of the barn very thoroughly, but in glancing over the painting specification I did not see any provision for painting the roof. Should the shingles not be given at least one good coat of oil stain?

A representative of Messrs W.H.Cushing Co., of Edmonton, is here today with reference to the additional inside millwork and I was able to be of some assistance to him in measuring up the places where fixtures are to go, etc. He expects his firm will make delivery of the millwork in October.

As I have no other employment in view, I should be glad to remain to supervise the construction of the barn, if so desired by the Department.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Inspector of Construction.

Sir:

Enclosed herewith is the account of Mr. J.E. Frederickson, well driller, of St. Paul, to the amount of $153.00, for services rendered in connection with the new well at this school, as shown in detail in said account.

As previously reported, trouble developed in this well, and it was found necessary to drill and bail out sand and sediment which had accumulated, and which stuck the cylinder soon after the larger permanent pumping plant was installed. As this well had been carefully drilled, with a straight hole and large size casing, it was not a difficult task to set up the drill and do this work. The results are highly satisfactory, and the water is coming today perfectly clear and in good volume.

I regret very much that this additional expense has arisen, especially as there had previously been so much money spent on the original well which we had to abandon. When Mr. Frederickson rendered me his account last night for this most recent work, I pleaded with him for a slight reduction in his customary rate in view of all the circumstances, and he has very generously consented to allowing the Department a reduction of 25¢ an hour for the services of himself, tractor, well-drilling rig and hired man, which allowance reduces his account from $170.75 as rendered, to $153.00 as amended.

Dear Father Angin:

With regard to heating the new school, I wired the Department on the 8th of August suggesting the desirability of procuring a minimum car of coal in order to safeguard the building against dampness. In reply I received authority to buy one ton only, which, of course, was quickly used up and was quite inadequate for the purpose in view.

I consider it very important that provision be made as quickly as possible to provide heat in this building. The season has been and is still abnormally damp, and this new building is being affected adversely. Scarcely a door or window in the building can now be opened or closed properly because of the swelling of the wood, and the atmosphere in the various rooms is damp and clammy. Cushing Co's representative notified me that they must have heat in the building for the additional millwork which they will soon be installing.

Rather than lose time by further correspondence with distant Ottawa, I would respectfully suggest that you order a car of suitable coal at once, and Mr. Fraser, the caretaker, can fire one boiler and keep the building moderately heated. I think the doors and windows will soon respond to the heat, and work freely again.

It would not be difficult to apportion the amount of coal used previous to your occupancy of the school, and if the Department should deem this a fair charge, you might reasonably expect to be reimbursed. But the main consideration is to get heat into this building at the earliest possible date.

Believe me, dear Sir,

Yours faithfully

Sir:

Regarding the proposed new barn for this school, no doubt it will be the Department's wish that once the contract is let that the work be proceeded with as quickly as possible. The approaching advent of winter, and the fact that the school people cannot move their live stock here until the barn is completed, prompt me respectfully to make one or two suggestions with a view to expediting the barn work.

As mentioned in my letter of the 2nd instant, both for delivering water to the barn under pressure as a permanent service, and also for the work of construction, it would be advantageous to get the trench dug and the water line laid for the 300 odd feet necessary, before freezing weather. Memorandum:

We have received a letter from Rev. Jos. Angin, Principal of the Blue Quills School, in which he states that he was requested by the Inspector of Construction, Mr. Gardner Smith, to buy some coal to heat the new school. He says he will send in the account for payment. Mr. Gardner Smith evidently thought that the Principal would be responsible for this expenditure and would pay for it from his per capita grant, but I hardly think this would be fair as they have not yet moved into the school, but the Principal if he did not consider himself responsible should have asked for authority before making the purchase. Sir:

Sir:-

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your telegram of the 5th instant, as follows:-
"Have sent wire as follows to Fraser, St.Paul. Your telegram fourth instant; barn at Blue Quill's must be in exact accordance with specifications. Do not allow work to be proceeded with until defects are remedied. Take a personal interest in the matter and report."

In this connection, I might state that on receipt of your letter No.118-1-5 of the 27th and letter of the 28th ultimo, I wrote Mr.Fraser advising him of instructions contained therein and in order to avoid delay, I delivered my letter with certificate forms to Mr.Fraser personally on the 3rd instant, the date of receipt of the letters above referred to. During the course of a discussion on the construction of the barn, Mr. Fraser advised me that the foundation was not in accordance with specifications, a considerable saving in material and labor apparently having been made by the contractors in building the foundation.

Not having had any official information as to plans and specifications, I was not in a position to check up on the work being done, but from information given by Mr.Fraser, I came to the conclusion that the contractors had made a considerable change in the plan of the foundation. The information received from Mr.Fraser was based on observations made during a visit to the school site two or three days previous to the date on which he received his appointment as supervisor. In view of this, I suggested that Mr.Fraser wire the Department immediately, advising as to the manner in which the work was being performed, with a request for instructions if he considered it necessary to condemn the work already done.

Upon the receipt of your wire yesterday, I again went to St.Paul to see Mr. Fraser. He had just returned from an official visit to the Blue Quill's school site. Mr. Fraser informed me that he had looked over the work carefully.

Duncan C. Scott Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
and although he found that the foundation was not made according to specifications, he was satisfied that it would be suitable for the building. Mr. Fraser advised the contractors that while he did not wish to condemn the work done on the foundation, he would insist on a proper adjustment being made in connection with the saving effected in material and labor. I understand that the contractors agreed to this. The contractors had been at work for about fifteen days and the work had progressed so far that taking weather, etc., into consideration and being satisfied that the foundation, although not according to plan, would prove entirely satisfactory, Mr. Fraser stated that he did not feel that he would be justified in having the work condemned.

The carpenter work is being proceeded with and on looking this over yesterday, Mr. Fraser found it necessary to instruct the contractors to take up part of the flooring and to replace it with suitable material, diagonally, in accordance with specifications. I asked Mr. Fraser to submit by first mail a written report to the Department.

In view of the fact that considerable carpenter work can be performed by a crew of men in a day or two, Mr. Fraser intimated that two days per week is hardly sufficient for proper supervision and that more time spent in supervising the construction might avoid delays that might be caused in the event of it being found necessary to have changes made in work done in order to comply with specifications.

Now the barn is finished and the contractors left the School for Edmonton yesterday. Of course, the painting will be made early in spring, as now it is impossible to do this work. But I must draw your attention on several points concerning this barn:

Jan.23rd 1932.

To the Honourable Duncan Scott,
Deputy Superintendent Indian Affairs,

Honourable Sir,

I have the pleasure of the Secretary of the Department concerning my requisitions for the school this year, and he states that they cannot be filled up because they reached the Department too late. It is rather surprising you must have yet my general requisition I sent you last year on January 1931. It is the very same requisition I have made this year for barn and shop, and as to the buildings, the Department know what they give usually to the new schools, and what has been granted to Blue Quills School in this connection till now, with only the barn. As to the items needed for main building, they have been already asked for last year and several times. In fact, I had no need to make a new requisition this year, as it was provided for in my last year requisition. If I made it, it was to call in mind my first requisition.

The Secretary notes that complementary blankets, bedspreads, towels, etc., are not supplied by the Department. However, I must state these items have been supplied in other schools. If these things are to be supplied from the per capita grant, it is difficult to know when the grant will give enough to buy them. Actually I pay $350.00 per month, only for light and coal, and I doubt if I will finance the school long with a millage of 6s.

As to the fencing of the play-grounds for boys and girls, and the playground equipment, it must be supplied from the proceeds of the old school. However, you have stated, honourable Sir, that these proceeds be employed to embellish the front of the new school and to level the tram line and make road. I figure the proceeds will not be sufficient to make all this.

Note also the complete equipment asked for barn cannot be supplied this year. You will find enclosed the list of items absolutely needed for this connection. However, I must state that no much work will be made this year on the land. I ask again for the 10 cows and the bull. From a long time, I am unable to supply pupils with milk and butter.

7 wardrobes figure on my requisition. Last year, I was advised that the credit for Blue Quills School was very limited; therefore, I asked for wardrobes very needed that was very needed but the equipment in wardrobes is not complete, and 7 members of the staff have no wardrobe.

Hoping, honourable Sir, you will take my letter in consideration, I remain,

Your obedient Servant,

Rev. Jos. Ansir,
Principal.

February 5th, 1932.

Sir:-

I beg to enclose herewith, report respecting the Blue Quill's Residential school, St. Paul, Alberta, for the month of January, 1932.

I might state that during the course of my visit at this school, the Reverend Principal advised me that owing to the fact that a one way system had been installed, instead of a return system of circulation, it was necessary to spend two days in the laundry each week in order to complete the washing. He claims that the steam from a one way pipe cannot be properly utilized and that a great deal of steam is wasted. It was also noted that no arrangements had been made to carry outdoors, the steam from the pop or safety valves on the boilers. When the steam blows off, the boiler room is filled with a dense cloud of vapor and there is always a certain amount of moisture from this. Suitable pipe should have been installed to carry this out of the building. Piping, which will answer the purpose at least temporarily, was being installed to take care of the escaping steam from the high pressure boiler.

The building is fairly well heated although I was informed that the fireman was having some difficulty in keeping up sufficient pressure and that three or four pounds was about the maximum pressure obtainable. I have since, however, discussed the boilers with Mr. Alexander, Boiler Inspector for this district, and he considered that four pounds pressure, if properly maintained, should be sufficient. One carload of coal is used in about three weeks and the cost of light and fuel so far, has been about $300.00 per month.

The Reverend Principal also informed me that owing to lack of tools, none of the boys have started training in the work-shop. I understand that a requisition for necessary tools has been submitted.

Your obedient servant,

REGINA, SASK., August 24th, 1938.

Dear Mr. Williams:

I have the honour to report that while inspecting the Saddle Lake Agency I also inspected the Blue Quills School which is run under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church. At the time of my visit there were, of course, no children in residence.

As the Department are aware, the building was only completed a short time ago, and is therefore in a first class state of repair. I wish to point out, however, simply for the information of the Department, that I would hate to live in the building on account of the cement floors on the main floor. In all the other schools we have battleship linoleum in the halls, kitchen, &c., and some rugs in the different rooms. In this school the floors are bare in the halls, nor are there any rugs on any of the rooms,—and the appearance of the cold, rough cement floor is certainly not inviting. A certain amount of dust always rises from the cement, which naturally collects on the furniture. The sisters and the Principal brought to my attention that they found walking around on this cement floor continually to be very hard on the feet; I can quite believe this.

The only out-building at the school is the barn, which is a very fine structure, except that there is no drain provided for from the gutters. To provide this would require a trench about 7 feet deep for a distance of about 150 feet.

A. S. Williams, Esq.,
Acting Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
There is also a question of wiring the hay loft for electric light, providing for about four drops.

The Principal also brought to my attention the following requirements of the school:

1 - Seed Drill, 20/ single disk - Not required until Spring.
1 - Disk Harrow, 16 X 16 - " " " "
1 - Brush Breaker - 16" - " " " "
1 - Spring-toothed harrow - 3 sec. - " " " "
1 - Bob-sleigh, 2½" steel shoe with box - Required this fall.
6 - Horses - Not required until Spring.
3 - Sets harness, not required until horses are furnished.

A hog pen and hog pasture are also required. At the present time the school is raising 43 pigs which are housed in little shacks. No chickens are raised at the school as they have no chicken coop. A chicken house is required. At the present time they have seven cows of shorthorn breed. The Principal is asking for 10 more. He also asked for one bull. This is not required until Spring, and could be purchased at the same time as the bulls for the different agencies. An implement shed is also required. A granary should be built this fall, if possible, to provide storage space for the crop. One about 20 X 40 with 9-foot studs would be most suitable.

The pump and rods should be taken out of the well as they are having difficulty with their water supply, and as the man who drilled the well is living in the vicinity, it would be necessary for him to set his machine over the well to clean it out. This is absolutely necessary.

The Principal is also asking for an expenditure of about $250.00 to fix up the playgrounds and fence them, &c. The sewer and septic tank need some attention. It would, however, be necessary to get someone who is experienced in that line to check this matter over. I do not think there is anyone in that vicinity who could do this.

This year the school has in crop 20 acres of wheat.
40 of oats and 30 of green feed; 90 acres in all. Six acres of potatoes and a splendid garden have been raised. The crop looked exceptionally good.

The staff consists of the Rev. Fr. J. Ansin, as Principal; Rev. Fr. A. Wattelle, Assistant Principal; H. Lord Engineer; Alphonse Lord, Farmer; T. H. M. Tuck, Disciplinarian; J. L. Henry, Labourer, and ten Sisters of Charity.

There were 81 children on the register, and three were discharged, leaving 78. The Principal will have to do considerable recruiting.

Considerable work has been done by the Principal and Staff in fixing up the grounds, but there is a great deal more to be done here. The grounds behind the school are not level, and it will certainly require a lot of work to put them in shape, and, as the Principal stated, it will be two or three years before a real showing can be made there. One thing I did not like about the location of the school is that it is hidden from the view of the main road by the brush, and anyone driving past would not know there were any buildings there. I think that in approaching from the west there is only one place on the road where you can see a corner of the school. Of course, this is of little importance.

As far as I could determine during my stay at that school, the management of the institution seems to be good. However, when the children are all there next winter and the school is in operation I shall make a further visit and inspect the class-rooms, &c.

I am aware that the Department have not the funds at the present time to meet all the requirements of this institution, in the way of equipment and buildings, but I thought it well to bring them to the attention of the Department in this report as no doubt, sooner or later, these things will have to be supplied, as no institution can be successfully run unless it is properly equipped.
While I am on the subject of schools: In my rounds of the reserves and at meetings held with each band, the matter of day schools was brought to my attention, and all bands seemed to be very anxious to have day school established on the reserve, and evidently there has been considerable outside influence in the matter, advising the Indians that they could demand day schools on reserves where there is no school. I advised every band that the matter of a day school was absolutely a dead issue as far as my recommendation went, as the Department had built the Blue Quills School for the purpose of taking care of all Catholic children in the Saddle Lake Agency and the Edmonton School had been built for taking care of all Protestant children in those agencies.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson

Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

at
