Asst. Hydraulic Engineer.

I. Purpose of Report.

A letter dated September 21, 1932, was received from the Director instructing an officer of this Branch to investigate complaints received by the Indian Department from the Principal on two matters, viz:

(1) Septic tank for disposal of the sewage from the school was not working properly.

(2) Proper drainage facilities should be supplied in connection with the barn.

This inspection was made by the writer on October 31 and November 1.

II. Results of Inspection of Septic Tank.

The tank is situated about 30 feet west of the girl's entrance, which is on the west side of the school. The details of construction are shown on the accompanying blue prints.

It was found that the tank is not operating as a septic tank but merely as storage for raw sewage from the school. An accumulation of most of the summer sewage must be present. The lumber door in the floor of the motor
chamber was opened for an instant and it was found that the whole chamber is filled with raw sewage to within a few inches of the floor. This means that the whole bottom of the septic tank, including the baffle chamber is filled with sewage to a point an inch or more above the notch between the tanks.

The lumber trap door, about 6' x 3½', is waterlogged, offensively damp, and does not now fit tightly because of its damp condition.

The chamber containing the motor and switch mechanisms is damp, including the walls. The switches are short-circuited and rusted through dampness. Many "false currents" occur all over the machinery.

The motor itself has partially rotted because of the damp atmosphere which of course is saturated with hydrogen sulphide and other gasses. The motor had been removed from the chamber for a considerable time as it was found to be useless, at least temporarily. It has not been in use since April. Everything in the motor chamber is wet and rusted. The wires are rotten and "false currents" are caused by the damp air and by disappearance of insulation. The school engineer thinks that the float for activating the switch is too small. The writer did not see the float as it is buried in sewage.

It is to be noted that the motor chamber is half-planked instead of being made of concrete. This is evidently for the purpose of providing ingress to the
moving parts in the pump chamber.

There is apparently very little bacterial action in the tank.

The overflow sewage - of course untreated, and apparently consisting only of the flushing water - flows from the end of the sewer 820 feet to the southwest. This escapes from the tank by means of the overflow opening in the upper side of the sewer pipe which extends into the pump chamber. The flow into the sewer pipe was designed to be intermittent.

The end of the sewer line consists of about 55 feet of lumber conduit 10" square. The end is two feet off the ground and is not protected from frost. However, the flow has not yet been interrupted by formation of ice and functions well during the winter.

The odour in the general vicinity of the tank is very strong and is a constant source of danger even in the present cold weather. In warm weather it must have been very bad and dangerous.

III. Necessary Improvements to Septic Tank.

The trouble is evidently caused by an excess of moisture in the motor chamber, which tends to rot all susceptible material therein. All of this moisture apparently comes from the trap door. Several remedies may be considered, as follows:

(1) Make a hermetically sealed entrance to the lower chamber instead of the trap door. This would need to contain a manhole for ingress.

(2) Cause a circulation of air in the motor
chamber by making a hole in the concrete wall near the bottom of the motor chamber and connecting this with a pipe and grating on the surface of the ground immediately to the west of the tank. Then make a hole in the opposite side near the surface of the ground and connect this with a pipe running eastward to the wall of the building and up to the roof. This would cause a circulation of air and a draft to draw off the moist air in the chamber.

(3) Build a lumber house say 9' by 9' by 7' high over the chamber. Install the motor switches and float mechanism in this house by lengthening the rods. The motor and switch should be repaired before installation.

This latter proposal is favoured by the writer as it makes a permanent and a sure repair, as in his opinion the mechanism should be removed from the dampness.

A visit was made to the Hospital in the town of St. Paul three miles away where a similar septic tank has been in use for a considerable time. The mechanism is similar but the motor is installed in a small house over the tank. They never have any trouble except that the hospital engineer has to mechanically trip the switch as the float is apparently too small. This tank never gives them any trouble. It was noted that the discharge pipe at the Hospital which is at least 3" in diameter comes up into the surface house. The pipe at the School is about 1/2" in diameter and extends about one foot above the floor of the motor chamber. No way could be found for ingress into the hospital tank. It appears to be entirely closed. How
repairs are made to the under part is not known. The cost of the house, repair of motor, extension of the rods and installation of the motor and switches should not exceed $300 and may amount to a less sum. A small chimney should be constructed for installation of a stove if found necessary.

IV. Barn Drainage System

The sewage from the barn, that is from the troughs behind the horses and cattle, is collected by means of conduits into a sump just outside the small door at the east side of the barn.

This sump is about 5 feet deep by 2 feet square. This hole becomes full of both solids and liquids and has to be dipped out as it will not seep very readily through the surrounding soil, as was originally intended. The soil consists of clay, which explains the difficulty. Here again, two methods may be used.

(1) Lay tile from the sump north-eastward to the water course 3 or 4 feet below.

(2) Deepen the sump to say, eight feet, and at about the frost line - 6 feet - lay 3 or 4 lines of porous tile in several directions for a distance of fifteen feet. The lower portion would collect solids. The latter would appear to be the better method as a larger seepage area would be created. The fact that the sub-soil consists of clay cannot be ignored. This
method would only increase the seepage area,
but the construction of a drain over 100 feet
long to the north-east would be difficult because
of the paucity of disposal grade and changes of
water elevation in the water course.

V. Heating System.

This matter was not mentioned in the letter
from the Indian Department but the Principal, Father Angin,
brought it to the writer's notice requesting that it might
be mentioned in this report.

In short, the extreme ends of the building -
east and west - in which are situated the class rooms and
dormitories - do not heat properly although the centre of
the building is too hot. The Sisters and pupils complain
of the cold even at this early date.

Although cold weather is not yet in evidence
both boilers are now (November 1) being used. During very
cold weather two carloads of coal, or two tons per day,
are burned. Even the extremities of the building are too
cold for comfort.

In the first place, Father Angin considers
the firebox too small. He also thinks that the pipes are
improperly connected. As an instance of this he states that
the Kelvinator was joined to the hot water pipes instead
of the cold water pipes. This was corrected by the Kelvinator
man after investigation. He thinks that they (presumably
the contractor) may have made other mistakes. He states that
the "blow-off" of the boilers had also to be corrected.

He states that the heating system has not given satisfaction on the whole. It has been badly connected, according to him.

The writer, not being an expert in heating systems, did not inspect this trouble but merely states what was told him by the Principal.

VI. Conclusions.

This report is prepared immediately in order that early consideration may be given to the condition of the septic tank as repairs are urgently needed.

The writer will find it necessary within two or three weeks to visit Onion Lake Anglican School where a water-supply installation is being made. If authority be given by the Indian Department to build the house and repair the motors at an early date the two activities could be carried on at the same time, thus saving expense. The improvements to the septic tank should be made immediately as they are a constant source of danger due to the large accumulation of raw sewage in all of the chambers. It is useless to simply repair the motor and replace it in the chamber as it would again deteriorate within 8 days - a space of time mentioned by the school engineer.

The request was made in the letter from the Indian Department that, if possible, the question of barn drainage be postponed until Spring. The matter can be postponed as it is not so urgent as the improvement of the septic tank.

Memoirs

Mr. Bushard,

Referring to memorandum of the 1st of September requesting the drainage work at the Blue Quills Indian Residential School, I beg to say that a report has been received from the Engineer of the Dominion Water Power Branch in Calgary, and the following is the information submitted in their report.

Plans and specifications for the sewage disposal system for the Blue Quills School were prepared in 1920 by the Calgary Office of the Dominion Water Power Branch and the work was carried out under their supervision. The Engineer reports that he found the septic tank was not operating as a septic tank but merely as a storage of raw sewage caused by an excessive amount of ammonia in the chamber containing the motor and switches which are required to operate the pump which discharges the sewage from the tank.

In order to remedy this condition it will be necessary to provide additional ventilation inside the tank and to construct a small building 8 x 8 x 7 over the top of the tank in which to install the motor and switches. These, of course, will have to be repaired before installation. The estimated cost of these alterations and repairs will be approximately $500.00, and I would recommend that the Water Power Branch be instructed to proceed at once with this work, as at the present time the sewage disposal system is a constant source of danger to the health of the occupants of the school.

With reference to the drainage for the barn, at the present time this is taken care of by a sump 6 feet deep by 8 feet square. This was installed at the time the barn was erected as a temporary arrangement. In order to make a permanent job it will be necessary to either install a drain to the water course or provide a larger sump. The Engineer who investigated states that the barn drainage can be postponed until next year as the work is not as urgent as the improvements to the septic tank.

Sir:—

With further reference to your letter No.115-1-34 of the 1st September last in regard to the well at the Blue Quill's Residential school, I beg to submit the following in connection therewith.

On the receipt of your instructions, I immediately got in touch with Mr. Frederickson, well driller, who was then working on a well North of Ashmont. As the school well was giving some trouble, I again went to see Mr. Frederickson on the 26th September and as he had not completed the job on which he was then working, I arranged for him to come to the school on the 3rd October in order that the well at the school could be checked up and the pump placed in a condition that it could be used temporarily. Temporary repairs were accordingly made at that time. Mr. Frederickson moved his well drilling outfit to the school on the 2nd November and proceeded with work on the well. He reported finding 41 feet of sand in the well. After giving the well a thorough cleaning out, the pump was replaced and the well was tested. The test being found unsatisfactory, he was instructed to again take out the pump. It was then found that the wall of the cylinder was very badly worn, no doubt owing to friction caused by sand. I therefore arranged for a new cylinder and two pipe rods as it was considered advisable to put in another length of pipe. Mr. Frederickson then put some gravel in the well, considering that it might to a certain extent, prevent the sand from coming up. I asked Mr. Frederickson to again test the well and to make careful observations in order that he could furnish a report on his findings. I am submitting his report herewith. You will note that he recommends another casing with sand screen attached. I understand that a sand screen would cost about $120.00 and the cost of casing and screen would therefore be approximately $396.00. The well has been giving considerable trouble and it is not considered that the gravel put in will overcome the difficulty permanently. A limited quantity only can be used as it is feared that the flow of water may be interfered with.

Mr. Frederickson still has the well under observation and it is hoped that no further trouble will be experienced for a time, at least.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:-

I beg to confirm my telegram of today's date as follows:

"Referring to my letter ninth instant regarding well at Blue Quill's School advised that this well now giving insufficient water supply. Unable to state cause but flow apparently irregular. Hard water being used at present not suitable for continuous use in boilers. Should depth be extended or new well drilled?"

In connection with this, I might state that on being advised on the 17th instant that the well was again giving unsatisfactory service, I called at the school in the evening of the same date. The Reverend Principal advised me that the supply of water from the well was insufficient to meet their requirements. Water from the shallow well is being used occasionally but this is hard water and not suitable for use in the boilers and pipes for any length of time. Everything possible has been done to remedy the trouble at the school well and although it was considered that it was in good order when Mr. Frederickson completed and tested the well, there has been a recurrence of the same trouble as was previously experienced. The Principal suggested that the depth might be extended to the 460 ft. level where another vein might be tapped but there is considerable uncertainty as to whether this would prove satisfactory as sand and mud was found at this level in the first well drilled at the school. It is also possible that the lower part of the casing in the well was considerably damaged by the drill during the drilling and cleaning out which was done. Should the depth be extended, it would be necessary to put in a five inch casing and if the six inch casing in the well is damaged to any extent near the bottom, it is doubtful if the space would permit the use of five inch casing. The driller is still of the opinion that the 327 ft. level would prove the most satisfactory if a sand screen were used, but he is somewhat doubtful as to whether this could be done in the well now being used.

I should be glad to have your advice and instructions in the matter.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I have your letter No. 4811, of December 22nd, relative to the well at Blue Quills School. I must state that I received your telegram and immediately, I sent to the University of Alberta for containers, thinking that the samples required for analysis should be examined for bacterial germs. As you want only to know about the hardness of water, I will try to send today 2 samples in glass containers.

However, Mr. Gardner-Smith who was present at school when the 2 wells were built, can tell you about this information you require.

Mr. Fredrickson has built the deep well, this one we used till now, 327 feet deep, supplying soft water, but not giving sufficient quantity for the need of the school. However, I may state that we were satisfied with this well because we shared the water in the different departments of the house by special days.

When Mr. Fredrickson has drilled this well, he has put in the bottom 3 feet of gravel to hinder sand and mud to rush up. Lately, 7 weeks ago he was required to clean the well but he drilled these 3 feet of gravel so that the water was filled with sand and mud, being nearly black. After 2 other days, he was obliged to put back gravel and stone about 10 feet deep, but he stopped the vein of the water in doing so. Finally he removed the gravel and stones and now we have water again, but black as at the first time, full of sand and mud. Mr. Fredrickson has worked here since 7 weeks and his outfit is yet on the spot. He suggests that a new well be built, 10 or 20 feet from the deep well, but before imposing upon the Department of Indian Affairs such expense, I think there is something to be done to save this well we have.

I will suggest myself that a new casing 20 ft. long at the bottom, be put, as it is possible that the drill has broken this casing at the bottom. After this, a very fine screen should be placed, to stop the mud and sand. With these, I guess the well should be in good condition.

I think that Mr. Fredrickson is not expert enough in this job, and an experienced driller should be required to examine the conditions of the deep well.

As to the shallow well, 90 feet deep, I must say that the water is very hard and even prejudicial to the health of the pupils. We have used this well when the deep well did not give sufficient quantity of water, and since 7 weeks we were obliged to take water from it.

The casings of the 2 wells have 6 inches in diameter.

Septic Tank and on the Well Conditions

at

by

I. Purpose of Report.

This report is prepared with further reference to a report dated Nov. 8, 1932, regarding the condition of the Septic Tank and also to a telegram received from Ottawa on Dec. 21, 1932, regarding the condition of the wells. The writer visited the location on January 13 and 14.

II. Septic Tank.

A cheque for $300 was received from the Indian Department on 9th ultimo for the purpose of erecting a building 9' x 9' x 7' over the tank and for repairing and changing the location of the motor from the underground concrete chamber to the house provided for it.

H.S. Fraser, of St. Paul, Alta., was entrusted with the construction of the house and I.H. Galloway with the installation of the motor and other electrical work. Estimates were previously obtained and were subsequently closely followed. This portion of the work is now satisfactorily completed.

The septic tank being filled to a depth of 7 feet with unwatered raw sewage which also clogged the outlet pipes, Mr. Fetterly found it necessary, during his visit of January 13, to engage J. Pigeon of St. Paul, to
remove it, as Father Angin would not undertake the work with his small staff and no facilities.

Mr. Pigeon promised definitely to finish the work but a letter was received from the Principal on January 25th, by which time this office had expected the work was completed, to the effect that he only worked one day and then abandoned it. The Principal was instructed to hire another man whom he mentioned. It is too much to expect Father Angin's staff to do this portion of the work.

The cost to date was as follows:

H.S. Fraser, St. Paul, Carpenter $226.62
This was an extremely reasonable cost.

I.H. Galloway, St. Paul, Electrician. 45.32
This was also very reasonable.

Standard Iron Works, Edmonton - 66.40
Repair of motor and fabrication of extensions, etc.

The motor was found when unwound to be in poorer condition than first thought.

Total. $338.34

The first two bills were paid from the $300 advance. The last invoice is in hand but is being held until the bill for removal of sewage is received, which should be within a few days. The total required extra amount will then be requested from Ottawa.

It is suggested that the Department of Indian Affairs send the circular which has been seen at other schools containing instructions that the septic tank be cleaned out every six months. Father Angin states that he
has never received a copy.

III. Wells.

Immediately on receipt of the wire dated December 21st, W.E.Gullion, the Indian Agent at Saddle Lake Agency, in whose district the school is situated, was communicated with. He stated that the driller had again brought in water, at least temporarily and that a visit by the writer was not immediately necessary. A visit was made on January 13 and 14.

A resume of the writer's findings are as follows:

(a) Three wells have been drilled.

Well No.1.

Drilled 300 feet west of the school in 1930 on the slope of a hill about 20 feet high. This well is 470 feet deep. Four veins of water were found 96', 205', 327', 460'. The first vein contained hard water and the last two fairly soft water. There were 350 feet of water in the well producing 2500 gallons per hour. It is said that the hole became clogged in the last few feet. Casing was lowered to the bottom. Some of this casing was afterwards removed. It was 6", 5" and 4½" in diameter. This well afterwards partially filled with sand and was definitely abandoned.

Well No.2.

Drilled within five feet of No.1 in 1930 by the Contractors who built the school, for construction purposes, to the 96 foot vein. This produced very hard water and was not intended for permanent use by the
School. It is at present used continuously when no water is available from No.3, which is now nearly all of the time. It produced 2000 gallons per day. The school requires about 4000 gallons, and consequently must ration the water. They melt snow for soft water. The casing in this well is 6" diameter throughout.

An analysis made January 3, 1933, by the Alberta Provincial Analyst indicated a hardness of 85.68 grains per gallon (St. Barnabas School Onion Lake, Sask., water contains 38 grains).

Well No.3.

This well was drilled to the 327 foot vein within 30 feet of the School, in August, 1931. The hole is 8 inches diameter with a 6" casing throughout. The hole is straight. Water came up to within 92 feet of the surface, i.e. 235 feet of fairly soft water. All veins of No.1 were struck at similar depths.

The water pipe is 3" diameter. The Department had to go to the 327 foot vein to get sufficiently soft water. The analyst on January 3, 1933, found it to contain 14 grains per gallon.

(b) Later Activities with Well No.3.

The driller of Well No.3, Mr. Fredrickson, of St. Paul, Alta., was called in by W.E. Gullion, Indian Agent, to ascertain the reason for cessation of flow, on Nov. 3. He worked at various times until Christmas.

When the well was finished, August 1931, he put 3 feet of average gravel in the casing. During the 14 succeeding months 40 feet of sand, similar to the sample
which is being sent under separate cover, apparently came through the gravel into the casing. The sample being sent was gathered in the water and dried for transportation. It must have some silt as 2 hours are required for settling. It is not sand rock. This sand, as will be noticed, is very fine and would go through a 100 mesh screen or even finer. A sand point would not stop it. Any screen which would stop it would probably clog altogether. This sand is being pumped whenever the well is used.

The cylinder is 87 feet from the bottom of the well. The driller removed this sand at the beginning, November 3, by agitation with a baler. He then drilled through the 3 feet of gravel with an 1800 lb. bit. He then placed 10 feet of average gravel and stone into the casing. Apparently he stopped the water nearly altogether. However, after an interval he again drilled through the 10 feet of gravel, his drill becoming stuck twice in the last two feet. He finished by dumping in one pail of gravel. The water was evidently coming intermittently during these times, but the sand was always present in the pumped water, in suspension. In manipulating the pump rods and cylinder the rods broke. This is the condition of the well at the present time.

One of three things must have happened when drilling. Either the gravel was pulverized, driven below the end of the casing, or the lower ten feet or so of the casing is broken (6" casing in an 8" hole). However, the
writer is assured that the last alternative is not probable.

Mr. Fredrickson, the driller, informed Father Angin that he had sent a report to this office containing a log of the well and an account of his activities but this report has not yet been received.

(b) Solutions of the Problem.

Several solutions were offered, as enumerated below.

The writer returned to Calgary on January 15. He has found since that it is exceedingly difficult to find anybody that has had experience in this sort of well trouble and who has a remedy. After several interviews with engineers, wholesale firms and well drillers, he found that Mr. Nelson, Instructor at the Technical Institute, had drilled many wells of this nature, in Northern Alberta. Pending receipt of Mr. Fredrickson's report, he offered a logical solution. This was afterwards corroborated by a former South Dakota driller who lives in Calgary and who has invented a pump for this kind of water trouble in which the leather cup washers are inverted and the water forced through a hollow pump rod.

The various solutions are as follows:

Father Angin's Solution

Purchase a 4 ton block and 40 feet of chain to lift out the rods if they break because of sand and to pull the cylinder. The accumulated sand could then be
taken out by a baler, hand-operated. This could be done every 10 or 12 months and would occupy 5 or 6 days. He states that his own staff could do this work. However, it would constitute a permanent operation. It would cost about $200 for hand-operation, plus the cost of an engine which undoubtedly would have to be purchased for permanent operation, a total of $600.

Mr. Fredrickson's Solution.

He would sink another well in the immediate vicinity of No.3, to the same depth (327 feet) at a cost of about $900. This is also favoured to some extent by Mr. Gullion. Mr. Fredrickson does not want to touch the old well at all.

A new well may develop the same trouble as before.

A solution considered by Mr. Gullion and the Writer.

Use No.2 (96' deep) with possibly another of the same depth near it and use a Zeolitic Water Softener, to soften the water. This water is very hard (86 grains per gallon) and a water softener would cost from $1200 to $1500 for 4000 gallons per day. It would be a sure solution of the difficulty. It is to be noted that the capacity of No.2 is 2000 gallons per day as far as proved.

Mr. Nelson's Solution

Repair No.3 in the following manner:

Remove the Cylinder and pipe. Clean out the sand and gravel to the bottom of the casing - 327 feet.
Attach sufficient pipe to lower the cylinder to the bottom of the well. Pump slowly steadily and incessantly for two or three days or more, night and day. The thickness of the water vein at 327', possibly consisting of the fine sand, is not known. It may be 6" or one foot. The pump should never stop. The cylinder should be at the bottom to catch all sand as possibly only the finer sand is carried up at present by the cylinder 87 feet above the bottom. However, this incessant pumping should clear a space beneath and around the bottom of the casing and also for a distance vein itself. This would then act as a reservoir. If enough sand were pumped out it might never trouble the well again.

IV. Conclusion

This report is prepared pending receipt of Mr. Fredrickson's log and report and possible subsequent consultation with Mr. Nelson.

It is evident from the divergence of opinion and from the various interviews that the solution of the problem is difficult. The only feasible source of water for the school consists of one of the exposed veins and one of these must be developed.

Considerable consideration of the problem before taking action is warranted because of the cost of experimenting.

A sample of the sand which comes from the well with the water is being sent under separate cover.
This sand may or may not consist of the entire content of the vein or the coarser sand may be at the bottom.

P.A. Fetterly
Assistant Hydraulic Engineer.

O.H. Hoover
Engineer in Charge.

Calgary, Alta., January 30, 1933.

P.S. One would expect that, considering the number of deep wells which have been drilled in the west, some authoritative method would by this time be found, but two more expert opinions have been given, since the above was written. Mr. MacDonald, Toronto Engineer in charge of Construction of the Glenmore Dam, Calgary, considered that a form of "air lift" and settling tank could possibly be used.

L. Michael, of Gleichen, when being consulted regarding the Old Sun School well on January 30, and who has had considerable experience, stated that he would use the baler, instead of lowering the cylinder and damaging it, to take out the water and sand. He prefers a short stroke for deep wells, and at any rate, a slower speed than is usual.

Quick action is necessary as a letter has been received from Father Angin stating that "the well is not fixed up and we have not sufficient water with the shallow well. I would be satisfied if you could give orders that the well be fixed up the soonest possible."

To the Honourable Harold Mac Gill,
Deputy Superintendent of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,

Honourable Sir,

You have received very lately a report from Mr. Fetterly, hydraulic engineer at Calgary, concerning the well at Blue Quills School. In reading myself this report that I have received also, I have seen that Mr. Fetterly writes about my opinion as to give the solution of the trouble with water at school. But it appears that Mr. Fetterly has not understood my solution of the problem. My solution is very simple and I have asked him for fixing up the deep well No. 2 as it was before the driller spoiled it lately.

When Mr. Frederickson has drilled this well in 1931, he has put at the bottom of the well 3 feet of gravel to prevent the sand to come up and with this stopper, we had a good service from the well during 8 months. Lately, on last November, he came to clean the well, and he drilled these 3 feet of gravel; it was a mistake, and I do not know if Mr. Frederickson did it purposely to drill another well because he had no work elsewhere. Then, my solution is to put again at the bottom of the well 3 or 4 feet of gravel, to be used as a stopper for sand. If this is done, I guess we can have a good service from the well as before.

I talked to Mr. Fetterly of a block chain of 4 tons, but it is not to clean the well by ourselves, it is to repair the pump when the rod is broken; this rod is a wooden one, and has been broken 4 times since Mr. Frederickson has worked at the well since last November. The rod can break again and if we are obliged at every time to ask for Mr. Frederickson, this will be expensive and will take long, as sometimes the tiller is far away. Then, I ask to the Department to equip the school with this block chain and 40 feet of chain, that we may repair the pump by ourselves.

I am very much opposed to the solution of Mr. Fetterly, viz., to buy a water softener for the well No. 2. This water softener, without regard to the high cost of $1200 or $1500, is a dirty thing, expensive in brine, and that does not give satisfaction. More of that, you have remarked that Mr. Fetterly states that the well No. 2 gives not sufficient water for the school why then install a water softener?

I think that the matter about this well has not been placed in the right way. When Mr. Indian Agent Cullion has sent a telegram to the Department one month ago, he has stated that the water formed the boilers. This is false as the water from the well No. 2, which is exceptionally hard, has never been used for the boilers. We have used till now the water from the cistern which is soft water. I must say that now this cistern is empty, and a prompt action of the Department is wanted, because in the next future, we shall be obliged to use this hard water for the boilers.

The Department will do as they wish, but for me, I consider that the matter is very simple. It is easy however to try my solution, this will not be very expensive; I try to save the deep well we have used till now, the water is soft and good, and this well gives water nearly sufficient to the school. I consider as a shame to impose upon the Department such big expenses as to drill a new well or to place a water softener, which are not necessary at all.

Your obedient Servant,

Rev. J. Q. Anglin,

Dear Sir,- Re: File 41167-W

I have your letter of February 6th in reference to difficulties encountered in drilling for water at the Blue Quills Indian School near St. Paul, Alberta, and sample of sand from No. 3 well.

The difficulty of fine sand and silt coming with the water and plugging the well has been met with at many places in the prairie Provinces, and in other regions. H.E. Simpson, State water geologist of North Dakota states in a recent report that "it is not an exaggeration to say that thousands of holes (in North Dakota) have been abandoned and hundreds of thousands of dollars lost through the inability of the drillers to secure water in ample amounts from fine sand deposits in which the water occurred in abundance. Even after wells have been finished and enough water apparently secured, the life of other thousands of these wells has been brief due to the infiltration of the fine sand, the clogging of the screens, the filling of the pipes, and the cutting out of the valves in the pumps. If the problem of securing this water through the proper drilling and finishing of these wells can be solved, it will be not only a great financial saving, but also a great material benefit to the people of the state by reason of better water supplies.

The method proposed by Mr. Nelson, namely cleaning out of the well and pumping sand and water sufficiently long to clear a space around the bottom of the casing, is the one commonly adopted. As much of the material is fine enough to be carried in suspension in the water I doubt whether the method would be successful except temporarily. A method used by the Kelly Well Company, the Layne Canadian and other large well drilling concerns might be successful, but would be very expensive. A large outside casing is put down to the water sand and fine gravel placed between it and the screen at the lower part of the inside smaller casing. The outer casing is then withdrawn and a filling placed around the inner casing. A modification of this scheme by using two small casings with a screen on the inner one and gravel between the two at the water sand might be tried. A very fine screen would be required and it is doubtful whether it would not become plugged.

A sieve analysis of the sand is as follows: probably the sand in place is somewhat coarser:

| Plus 0.1 mm | 36 |
|-------------|----|
| 0.1/0.05 mm | 14 |
| Minus 0.05 mm | 50 per cent. |
The sample is, therefore, fine grained. A little of the plus 0.1 mm. portion is retained on a 0.2 mm. sieve. The grains are subangular.

In connection with the plan favoured by Mr. Fetterly, namely using No. 2 well, which seems to be the most feasible scheme, it may be advisable to find out whether there is a screen in the well and if not whether a screen would increase the water supply. This would depend upon the thickness and character of the water sand. If it is proposed to soften the water a fairly complete analysis of the water should be made; some hard waters can be softened by the Zeolite exchange silicate process whereas others cannot. Analyses are made by some of the firms handling water softeners.

Yours sincerely,

'SGD' W.A. Johnston.

It was suggested to the writer verbally, by Mr. Christianson, Inspector of Indian Agencies, at a chance meeting in Edmonton, on Feb. 17th, that a definite recommendation regarding the well situation at Blue Quills Indian School, St. Paul, Alberta, should be made quickly. INSPECTOR'S OFFICE.

CALGARY, ALTA., February 24th, 1933.

Sir:

I beg to bring to your attention that I have just returned from an inspection of the Saddle Lake Agency and while there inspected the Blue Quills School. The Principal naturally brought to my attention the difficulty they have been having with the water supply and sewerage: The deep well has gone out of commission altogether, and even the pump rods are broken. Therefore the well has had to be abandoned.

For the present the school are getting their water from the shallow well which only produces about 2000 gallons per day, whereas 4500 or 5000 gallons are actually required. The water from the shallow well is very hard and unfit for laundry use, and the Sisters have been melting snow to use for washing. The Department will realize how unsatisfactory this is.

On my way back to Calgary, I met Mr. Fetterly, (who has the situation in hand,) by chance in Edmonton, and asked him to make a definite recommendation as to what should be done about it. A letter has been forwarded by him to his Department at Ottawa this morning, and the suggestion is that the deep well be cleaned out and the quicksand pumped out, to make a basin in the bottom of the well, have the cylinder lowered, &c. Memorandum:

With reference to the report of the Auditor hereunder, dated March 4th regarding the heating system for the Blue Quills Indian Residential School, I beg to say that the statement that the boilers have not the necessary capacity for heating the school is incorrect. This School is equipped with two steel return tubular boilers, each having a capacity of 5000 square feet of radiation, making a total capacity of 10,000 square feet. The School is supplied for heating purposes with 6,138 square feet of cast iron radiation. It will be noted, therefore, that the boilers have a capacity of nearly twice the amount of radiation installed.

It appears, however, that they have had difficulty in heating this building, but this is not due to either lack of boilers or radiation, but to the fact that the system appears to be sluggish. When this School was erected electric power was not available, and the system was designed with wet returns in the basement. In order to increase the circulation it will be necessary to install a vacuum pump to trap the ends of the mains through float traps, and change the existing wet returns into dry returns. This would increase the circulation and cut down the fuel bills. This arrangement is possible now as electric power is delivered to the School. There has also been some trouble with the boilers due to alkali water.

Sir,-

Referring to your letter No.4811 of the 11th inst. regarding the equipment for the well at the Blue Quills Indian Residential School, I beg to advise you that I was in St. Paul on the 12th and 13th in connection with the well and the material. Anticipating that the material would be on hand, I had started Mr. Fredrickson on the well and he had just completed the cleaning out process. The material arrived on Wednesday's train and I had this released on Thursday and it was delivered at the school on the same date. I gave Mr. Fredrickson instructions as contained in your letter and asked him to give me a report as soon as possible as to how the test was going. About nine o'clock Saturday night, he reported by phone that he had put in the pump and that he had kept the pump going from 9 p.m. to 3 o'clock the following morning, when the pump stopped. He stated that he had considerable trouble getting the pump out as approximately 24 feet of sand with some mud had come up and the pump rods were stuck. In order to give Mr. Nelson's plan a fair trial, I advised the driller to again clean the well thoroughly and to put in the pump for another pumping test. He was to start on the second test this morning. Personally, I am somewhat doubtful as to this plan being successful. The quantity of fine sand already taken out would indicate a vein of considerable extent and in view of this, the probability of creating a reservoir by pumping appears to be slight.

Should Mr. Nelson's plan prove unsatisfactory, Mr. Fredrickson has made the following suggestion:- that a number of small holes be drilled in a short length of 5-5/8" casing and that this be lowered to the bottom of the well. He claims that this is sometimes done in drilling oil wells. The objectionable feature in this case would be the possibility that should the short casing fail to remedy the trouble, and should it be found impossible to take it up, it would probably leave the well in such a condition that no further work could be done on it. Rev. Father Angin suggests that gravel might again be given a trial and that small holes be drilled in the pipe below the pump cylinder. His idea is that by having the holes, the suction would be from the sides instead of from the bottom of the pipe. Gravel has, however, already been tried out and the suction in any case would be from the bottom of the pipe.

As already states, Mr. Nelson's plan will be given a fair trial but should this fail, what plan would you suggest as an alternative?

In regard to the equipment received, I note that there are no extra rods for the pump. In the event of breaking one of the rods, there will be considerable delay in getting a replacement and in view of this, I am of the opinion that there should

Sir,

With further reference to our telephone conversation on the afternoon of the 18th instant regarding the well at Blue Quills Indian School, Mr. Fetterly states that he waited at his phone (M7346) from 7 p.m. to 10:30 p.m. on the 19th instant for a call from you in accordance with our mutual plan in the original conversation. This call, however, did not come through. We will be very pleased if this is due to the fact that no difficulties had been encountered up to last night.

As a preparation for last night's possible phone conversation Mr. Fetterly again consulted Mr. Nelson, Instructor at the Provincial Technical School, on the 19th. This gentleman was quoted in the former report as a well driller who had had a great deal of experience in the drilling of wells around Camrose and Provost, under similar conditions.

He was informed of the facts you communicated over the phone to Mr. Fetterly. His comments were as follows:

He stated that in the case of one well at Camrose he pumped for a day and the water then came clear of mud. He concluded that it was all right and left it as finished. After another day had elapsed the water became muddy again (evidently a cave-in of sand). He again started to pump the water and sand and continued for a full week, stopping only from 12 p.m. to 6 a.m., and not even then, at times. When he stopped the pump he was careful to see that the stroke was at the top of the cylinder so that if it stuck on him he could gently pound it downward to loosen it. At one such stoppage it happened that he only had one-half inch to spare as the plunger was near the bottom. However, even in these circumstances he was able to loosen it.

Mr. Fetterly asked him if it would be a good plan to raise the cylinder 5 ft. or 10 ft. or 20 ft. He did not think this a good plan as this might raise the cylinder above the heavier sand.

His main advice was "pump incessantly" and don't leave the well until you are sure it is clean. He stated that in one well he pumped over two wagon-loads of sand with the water before clearing. It would not do to clear the water and then leave it immediately as a cave-in might occur for a short time. This advice appears to be reasonable.

REPORT
on
The Well Situation
at
Blue Quills Indian School
by
P.A. Fetterly
Assistant Hydraulic Engineer.

I. Introduction.

A letter was sent to the Director, dated April 22nd 1933, stating that the writer was proceeding to St. Paul immediately to make an inspection of difficulties which had been mentioned in the wire and telephone conversation with Mr. W.E. Gullion, Indian Agent, and Mr. J.E. Fredrickson, driller. These men were interviewed on April 26 and 26.

II. Mr. Fredrickson's Activities.

It was ascertained that the new 3" piping, rods and cylinder had been placed in the well, the bottom of the 6" casing being at the 326 foot level. The water vein being utilized runs from 323 feet to 327 feet, i.e., 4' thick, with the casing one foot from the bottom of the sand vein. A stratum of clay lies under this vein.

Mr. Fredrickson stated that when he started to work the first time, i.e., about November 1, 1932, the accumulation of sand in the 6" casing was 40 feet thick. He, of course, stopped working about December 25. When he began again about April 15, 1933, he found 24 feet of sand, the accumulation of 3½ months. This sand was so dense that
he had to drill through it instead of simply baling it out. This, of course, all took place in the lower 24 feet of the 6" casing, and occupied about half a day. He then lowered the cylinder and pumped water and mud (please note that it seemed to be mud rather than sand, but was similar to the samples which were obtained by the writer on January 10 and sent to Ottawa), for 2½ hours. It then stuck solid and the pump stopped because of the resistance at the end of that time. He then removed the 3" piping and cylinder, about 3 hours' work. He then had to drill the sand out again and bail out until the water became fairly clear but not as clear as it was 2 years ago when he first drilled it. Three days were occupied in this one operation. The sand appears to almost actually shoot up to a depth of several feet within a few minutes.

This operation was repeated three times, each time there being 10' or 12' of sand in the casing accumulated within a few hours or less. The last two times he could only pump 15 or 20 minutes, before the cylinder froze. He had to extract pipe, rods and cylinder every time he cleaned it. When he had tried this for three times he decided that it was wasted effort and advised Mr. Gullion, on April 22, to communicate with Calgary office, stating that the "Nelson plan" had proved unsatisfactory.

III. Cause of Troubles

Mr. Fredrickson believes that the trouble is caused by the fact that the lower 20 feet of casing, or a certain length of it has been ruptured by the continuous
drilling and pounding and that the "mud" in the water comes from the clay stratum immediately above the water sand vein as it is much finer than the original water vein sand. This is problematical. He claims that when he finished the well two years ago, he advised that the pump be started immediately and pumping continued until all sand has disappeared from the water. He believes that this was not done and was the cause of the present trouble. He also states that a well should always be pumped immediately after it is finished to clear it and that if this is not done trouble is liable to ensue.

Mr. Nelson agrees with this fact.

IV Fredrickson's Cure

Mr. Fredrickson is of the opinion that a new well should be driven about 30 or 40 feet away from the present well. He claims that under certain conditions he will guarantee a free flowing well, if he be allowed to plan it and to pump until clearing as soon as finished. He states that a well cannot be allowed to stand as it will deteriorate.

He would not place the cylinder at the bottom of the well as in the present experiment. He drilled a well for the St. Paul Flour Mill, two miles to the east, 360 feet deep, and kept it going for a month. This water is rather harder than that of the School well.

He thought of inserting a 5" casing inside the 6" casing, for the full distance with a screen on the bottom but if the 6" casing were ruptured mud would still
enter to the cylinder.

He claims that he cannot clean the well with the baler as the water stays muddy continuously. Mr. Nelson and Mr. Fredrickson agree on the system of continuous pumping and the latter states that this should have been done at the beginning as it cannot be done now because of the nature of the sediment, as explained above, they only being able to pump for a few minutes at each operation before cleaning the cylinder and pipe.

V. Log of Well

The log of the present well, No.3, is not now available, but the log of Well No.1, drilled by J.G. Douglas, 11706-87th St., Edmonton, in 1929, has been given as follows (this well is 300 ft. west of No.1 and of the School):

- Yellow Clay 0'-30'
- Blue Clay 30'-100', Very Hard water vein at 98'.
- Hard blue clay 100'-120'
- Blue Clay and Many Boulders 120'-198'
- Clay & Gravel 198'-228' Hard water at 207'
- Sand 228'-298'
- "Soft water" sand 298'-330' Softer water at 324' (Clay 2')
- Fine Sand 330'-360'
- Coarse " 360'-370'
- Fine Sand 370'-390'
River Sand 390' - 410'
Sand mud
Quicksand, gravel
and Clay 420' - 461' bottom of well, soft water.

VI. Notes.

A considerable amount of gravel has been placed at different times in the well for straining purposes. This gravel and the sand have been drilled through or pushed down or outwards at various times. It is difficult to estimate the exact or approximate condition of the bottom of the well and 6" casing.

The present pump should deliver 350 to 500 gallons per hour and the present well should produce this amount if in good order. This amount would be sufficient for all school purposes.

VII. Observations.

For the first time the writer has had an opportunity of observing Mr. Fredrickson. He has been drilling wells for 14 years and consequently has a considerable amount of experience in this work. He appears to be quite anxious to obtain water and, in the writer's opinion has done what he could. Mr. Gardner-Smith recommended him in the beginning with apparently good reason after making enquiries.

The writer, together with Mr. Gullion and Father Angin, and afterwards, with Mr. Fredrickson consulted today regarding the matter, and, allowing for limited
knowledge on the part of all but the latter, came to
the conclusion that the only solution they could see
was to drill another well 20' or 30' to the west, with
all of the precautions gained in the experience of
drilling No.3.

While awaiting definite instructions from
Ottawa on the matter, Mr. Fredrickson has been instructed
to make one more attempt. This consists in beginning
with a clear casing as far as may be known, then pour
in a few feet of gravel, say 3 or 4 feet, then insert
the pump and test the efficiency of the screening. If
sand is still found to come through, place one or more
feet of gravel and try again. In this way an exact amount
of gravel to stop the sand but not too much to stop the
water may be found. If this fails then no other method
is known to the writer. One considers that the limit for
experimentation has been nearly reached in the present
well. The cost will soon approximate that for a new
well if not stopped. Mr. Fredrickson guarantees a new
well under certain conditions which are not difficult,
and are principally concerned with the cost.

The water question is more serious to the
School than ever because the snow - which has been their
principal source of soft water - has disappeared.
Laundry conditions are deplorable and the hard water is
affecting the water pipes. Father Angin is exceedingly
anxious and urged the writer to wire to Ottawa for an
immediate answer and authority to proceed.

Mr. Fredrickson's presence on the work increases the cost every day he is there, consequently early instructions are imperative. It is obviously impossible for the writer to be in constant attendance at the School to check up the activities.

Mr. Nelson, on April 22, proposed one last attempt to save the well. This plan was to drill a further 40 feet below the casing, then lower a charge of 4 sticks of dynamite 15 feet below the casing to produce a cavity into which the sand surrounding the bottom could run, if it will not come up by pumping. This was found to be impossible because the sand runs into the drilled hole as fast as drilled and packs there. To hold it, the casing would have to be driven through the water vein and thus cut off the supply.

VIII. Cost Estimate.

It is estimated that a new well, together with an underground gallery 20 feet long, extending the present one would cost about $1300 or $1400. This would include casing, drilling and extension of the basement. The recently purchased material would be utilized.

IX. Addendum.

The writer has just witnessed the baling of the well. The water obtained in the bailer contains at a rough estimate about 5% of fine sand and mud. This settles in 10 minutes to a muddy appearing opaque water with much sediment on the bottom of the can. The remainder clears fairly well in about 2 or 3 hours indicating that clay is present. A sample of the sediment was obtained and dried. It is similar to that obtained in January.
X. Conclusion.

A perusal of this report, prepared at the School, will convey to the reader all that is known by the writer regarding the well situation. Suggestions have been made as to possible procedure. It is with a great deal of hesitation that one recommends another well as the expense of obtaining water has already been great, but it is the only solution to the writer's knowledge.

P.A. BETTERLY,
Assistant Hydraulic Engineer.

Sir,

I am forwarding to you herewith, Mr. Frederickson's account, Voucher No. 3681, amounting to $406.20 in connection with work performed, etc., repairing well at the Blue Quills Indian Residential School.

In regard to the water situation at this school I beg to submit the following report: The question of obtaining a water supply was becoming somewhat serious and on calling at the school on the 3rd instant, I was informed that the vein at the 327 ft. level had stopped and that it was impossible to bring up any more water by pumping, I discussed the question of using dynamite with the driller and before leaving, advised him to endeavour to drill at least a few feet below the bottom of the casing and to try a shot of dynamite. This he did and having opened up the vein, the pump was kept going continuously for approximately twelve days. I called occasionally and found that the water showed no signs of clearing. There was sufficient mud and sand being brought up to make the water appear thick. I called again on the 18th and as there was no improvement, I again discussed the water situation with the driller and the Principal. The driller suggested that although it would probably be found hard, sufficient water might be obtained from the 200 ft. vein. As the water supply at the school was then exhausted and the situation serious, I advised the driller to try a shot of dynamite at the 200 ft. level. He accordingly plugged the well at the bottom and shot the well on the following day. Water was brought in and after bailing, the pump was installed and started. The water came to within 43 ft. of the surface. One hundred feet of pipe was used on the pump. The water cleared about 3 a.m. Sunday, the 21st Inst. and the pump has been going continuously since. I am informed that full pressure is maintained in the pressure tank. Mr. Frederickson advised me that when he first turned the water into the pressure tank, he pumped at the rate of 650 gallons per hour. This did not lower the water and he states that the well will supply 1000 gallons per hour without any difficulty. I believe that the water from this vein was tested at the time of drilling but I have not seen a report of the analyses. I understand however, that the hardness was reported as being about 50 per cent.

Your obedient servant,

O.H. Hoover, Esq.,

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your telegram of the 27th ultimo advising that Fredrickson's guarantee considered unsatisfactory and that efforts to clean existing well should be continued and possibility of now using screen considered.

In this connection, I might refer to my letter of May 25th. I might add further that the prospect of obtaining an adequate supply of suitable water from the existing well at the 327 ft. level was generally considered hopeless. A great deal of work was done on this well and a considerable sum of money expended with practically no results. The question of installing a sand screen was discussed some time ago but at that time I believe it was considered that in order to stop the flow of sand encountered the screen would necessarily have to be so fine that in all probability, the flow of water would be interfered with. The Principal has previously stated that before the well commenced causing trouble, he had to more or less "ration the water" in order to conserve the supply. At that time there were about 87 pupils in the school. There are now 117 pupils and including the staff, the number in the school is 133. It is doubtful therefore if this well could furnish an adequate supply of water from the 327 foot vein even if brought back to its former condition. The driller of course maintains that this condition was brought about by the fact that the pump was not kept going continuously immediately after the well was completed. Taking all this into consideration and as water situation at the school was as stated, serious, the 200 ft. vein was brought in. The well could still be cleaned if it is desired that this should be done but it is doubtful as to the probable result warranting the expenditure that would be entailed. I visited the school yesterday and so far, the supply of water from the 200 ft. level is sufficient to meet all requirements in the school. The Rev. Principal informed me that full pressure is maintained in the pressure tanks at all times and the water is clear. In view of this, I shall await your further advice before going any further in the matter.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,-

Re: Blue Quills Indian School
Well Situation

I beg to advise you that Mr. Fetterly of this staff visited the above named School on June 9, to examine Well No. 3 and to prepare the accounts of J.E. Fredrickson and Father Angin for payment. These are attached to another letter of even date.

He found that Well No. 3 is working satisfactorily. Father Angin is satisfied, providing the water is not too hard. The present capacity is limited by the capacity of the pump. This pump is rated at 650 gallons per hour but on test produced about 500 gallons. The well as at present conditioned would probably produce upwards of 1000 gallons per hour if the pump could handle it. Plenty of water is now available for the School.

Mr. Fredrickson, as a last resort, on the advice of Mr. Gullion and on previous suggestion by Mr. Fetterly, exploded two charges of dynamite of three sticks each, at different times; one at 205 feet and the other at 200 feet. The water, presumably from the "200 ft. seam" arose to within 43 feet from the surface of the ground at the time. It was still at that point on June 9. The cylinder is 100 feet from the surface. The water has been coming since May 20 with no apparent diminution. The School needs 4000 to 5000 gallons per day. There are at present 130 people. If the school filled the number would be 155.

There is no means of knowing whether the well will be a permanent producer. Only time will answer this. At any rate, three quart jars of water were obtained by Mr. Fetterly. He allowed the pump to activate for some time before collecting the water directly from the well. The original sample from this vein indicated 50 grains per gallon of hardness. There is a strong possibility that the present water is too hard for plumbing and boilers. This can only be found on analysis.

I am therefore sending you a sample of the water collected on June 9. I will send another sample to the University of Alberta for analysis. The third sample will be

Ottawa.
retained for possible future use of a manufacturer of Water Softeners.

You will note that a sand sediment is present. This was not noted at the time of collection, although the water was very slightly discoloured.

With reference to your letter of the last instant, paragraph 3, I might state that we were very anxious regarding the expense which was being incurred in attempting to clean out the well but could see no other solution except to attempt rehabilitating Well No. 3 as authorized by you and while awaiting authority to begin another well if efforts were useless. Mr. Fredrickson was on the ground with his outfit and continued his attempts. As a result he has now obtained water, although of unknown hardness. The cost has been much less than was anticipated by this office.

As will be noted, no expense has been incurred since May 10 due to Mr. Fredrickson's expressed unwillingness to add to the already high cost of obtaining water. Mr. Fredrickson has been very reasonable throughout.

With regard to the 4th paragraph of the same letter I might explain that the present well is situated in a 6' x 6' concrete "tunnel" extending at right angles for about 30 feet from the boiler room. The top of the tunnel, consisting of concrete is at the surface of the ground. The greater portion of this tunnel is occupied by the pressure tank. The end of the tunnel farthest from the building contains the pump and well No. 3 in a space 4' x 6' x 6'.

It was proposed to extend this space for 60 feet further for the proposed new well in order to get away from the influence of "Well No. 3.

In order to save expense it was proposed that the chamber for the new well at the end of the new tunnel 60' from the building would have been 6' x 6' x 6' with a narrow gallery for pipes connecting with the old one to minimize excavation and concrete. The alternative method would be to construct a house above the new well. This was considered to be more expensive than an extended tunnel. This new gallery and tunnel would have been at the same elevation as the original, the top being at the surface of the ground.

Mr. Fetterly is of the opinion that the matter can be left in status quo at present until the well has proved itself or until the necessity for a water softener is evident from analysis of the samples which have been secured.

It is to be acknowledged that the very small
quantity of fine sand in the sample submitted is rather disturbing but this may disappear on continued use of the well, although it may also gradually fill up the pipes below the cylinder or collect in the pressure tanks on settling. The results of this particular difficulty will be found later.

Sir:

I have your 407-11A of the 17th instant, relative to the request you received from the Principal of the Blue Quills Indian Residential School for the erection of a granary.

In reply I have to say that, while certain funds were provided in our Estimates for the present fiscal year for this school, it was found necessary to expend therefrom approximately $800 in paying the cost of the work recently carried out in an effort to improve the well and place the water supply in a good condition. The Department has been requested to consider a further reduction of 10% in the Appropriation for Indian Education for the balance of the present fiscal year. Therefore, I regret there will be no funds this year to provide the cost of erecting a granary.

I may add that it may be necessary to incur further expense in connection with the water supply - in providing a water softening plant - which would entirely use up any funds that might be available for this school.

by P.A. Netterly,
Asst. Hydraulic Engineer.

PURPOSE OF REPORT

This report deals finally with the Water Supply at Blue Quills Indian School, St. Paul, Alberta. Letters from this office dated May 30, June 5, 14 and 15, and July 4, the latter containing copies of the chemical analysis, were sent the Director fully covering the well situation.

A final visit was made on July 20 in connection with vouchers.

CONDITION OF WATER SUPPLY

The well was found to be working properly and is producing sufficient water for all purposes. This water is rather hard, as shown by the analysis, but the School Engineer, in the absence of Father Angin, stated that it was "pretty good, although a little hard". A letter from the Director, dated July 17, stated that "no funds were available at the present time for the installation of a water softener and that so long as the water supply remains
adequate as to quantity, no further action will be taken at this time".

The matter of a softener will thus remain in abeyance as long as conditions are as at present.

CONCLUSION

Referring to Mr. Mackenzie's letter of 11th ultimo, File 115-1-5, Ref. 128247 W, last paragraph, there should be no further expenditure at this school for Water Supply.

Assistant Hydraulic Engineer.

Engineer-in-Charge.

Memorandum:

MR. BUSKARD.

With reference to your memorandum of the 22nd instant, concerning the enclosed letter from Mr. C. H. Gauvreau, of St. Paul, Alberta, I have now to state that arrangements might be made for the clearing of the farm at the new Blue Quills Indian Residential School, provided the Minister's correspondent can finance the work until the spring. That portion of the farm to be cleared would have to be indicated by the Reverend Principal, and I believe the contract should be at a certain rate per acre and should be for clearing, stumping and breaking, complete. Of course, the stumping and breaking would likely have to wait until the early summer, but I believe it advisable to have the job completed by those to whom it is entrusted.

I may say that Mr. F. O. Maurice, the Secretary Treasurer of the Village of St. Paul, has urged the Department to do the clearing this winter, and, in December, Mr. Hector Plante wrote, wanting to quote on the brushing and breaking of 100 acres. He stated he had been doing custom work of this kind for farmers during the past few seasons. Perhaps Mr. Gauvreau would like to have this information if the Minister decides to proceed with the work.

It would be necessary for Mr. Gauvreau to see those who are competent to do this work and who need employment and to make an offer to clear, stump and break a certain specified quarter section, as indicated by the Reverend Principal, at so much per acre. This offer should go to the Reverend Principal himself, who could forward it to the Department with his comment concerning the quotation, etc. If this suggestion is made to Mr. Gauvreau, please let me know, so that we can instruct the Reverend Principal.

Duncan C. Scott

Memorandum:

- Breaking - $6.00
- Discing 4 times - $2.00
- Dragging with heavy harrows - $.50
- Picking roots - $.25
- Picking stones - $.50
- Floating - $.50
- Light harrowing - $.25

Total - $10.00

Memorandum:

MR. BUSKARD,

- Breaking plough,
- Mower,
- Gang plough,
- Rake,
- Disc,
- Wagon,
- Harrow,
- Bob sleigh.
- Drill.

Memorandum:

MR. BUSKARD.

The Department now wishes to fence the new farm at the Blue Quills Indian Residential School, near St. Paul, Alberta. It is proposed to fence the whole section and to erect a cross fence to protect the 100 acres that are being prepared for crop next year. The local management has secured a price of $264 from Marshall-Wells Alberta Company, of Edmonton, for wire, staples and gates, and a price of $350 for the posts from the Hayward Lumber Company, of St. Paul. As these firms are on the list and their prices are satisfactory, I wish to recommend that the business be awarded to them. The labour will be done entirely by Indians, under the direction of the school management.

MEMORANDUM:

DR. MCGILL

The following is taken from a letter received by the Minister:

"You will no doubt recall that in November last I discussed with you the water supply problem at the Blue Quills Indian School. Originally the well used at the school was 327 feet, but due to the fact that the well was not used for a considerable period after it was drilled, the sand seeped in and the bottom of the well became plugged. The water found at the depth of 327 feet was soft and suitable in every way for the purposes of the school. When the well plugged with sand, the casing was opened at a vein of water at 200 feet. This water was hard, and is not altogether suitable. The Indian Agent informs me that the Department now proposes to put in a Water Softener, in order to overcome this difficulty.

"I have no doubt that I could drill a well to the depth of 327 feet and find an abundant supply of good soft water, and as the water from this new well would be used continuously, it would not plug with sand. This would be much cheaper and far more satisfactory than installing a Water Softener.

"The cost of a Water Softener of the type required at the School would be about $1500.00. To drill a well 327 feet, provide casing therefor, and install a pump would cost about $700.00. This figure is of course based on the assumption that the pump now in use at the School will be installed in the proposed well."

The Minister would like a report on this matter.

Private Secretary.
March 16th, 1934.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Buckard,

Since the erection of the Blue Quills Indian Residential School, the Department has had considerable difficulty with the water supply. This is due to two reasons: (1) the hardness of the water, and (2) the clogging of the pipes owing to very fine sand filtering into them. The situation became rather acute in December, 1932, and we secured the services of the engineers of the Dominion Water Power Bureau. Under their supervision, considerable work was done during the spring and summer of 1933 and, in a report dated August 17th, 1933, Mr. P. A. Petterly, Assistant Hydraulic Engineer, Calgary, wrote as follows:

"A final visit was made on July 20th to the Blue Quills Residential School. The well was found to be working properly and is producing sufficient water for all purposes. This water is rather hard, as shown by the analysis, but the school engineer, in the absence of Father Amos, stated that it was 'pretty good although a little hard'. A letter from the Director, dated June 17th, stated that no funds were available at the present time for the installation of a water softener and that, so long as the water supply remains adequate as to quantity, no further action will be taken at this time. The matter of a softener will thus remain in abeyance as long as conditions are as at present."

This Department has, therefore, not considered installing a water softener at the Blue Quills School nor have any complaints regarding the water supply been received from either the Indian Agent or the Principal since the date of the report quoted above.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to report on an inspection of the Blue Quills Indian Residential School in the Saddle Lake Agency, which I visited on my recent trip to that Agency. I might say that I spent the greater part of a day making this inspection. I found there were 125 children in residence at that time.

I am pleased to report that conditions at this institution are very favourable. The children all looked exceptionally well and were enjoying the best of health. I made a thorough inspection of everything in connection with the work at the school with the exception of the Class-room work, on which the Department receive a report from the Provincial School Inspector. The girls do a great deal of sewing, fancywork, &c., and the handicraft work done by them is splendid. They make their own dresses, boys' suits, &c. and are given all the usual training received in residential schools.

Doctor Harold W. McGill,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
The girls also do some outside work in the way of planting and looking after gardens, etc. The boys look after the stable, cattle, etc., and do a certain amount of farm work — about the same as at the average Indian residential school on the prairie. The Principal brought to my attention that with the staff he has there he could also arrange to give the boys some instruction in blacksmithing and carpenter work. They have the shop, but not sufficient tools to bring this training into force. The Indian fathers expressed the desire that the Department make arrangements to have their sons get some training in blacksmithing and carpenter work as it would be so useful to them when they came back to the reserve. I realize the Department have no funds for this purpose at the present time, but this is something that should be brought into force at every residential school. As soon as I have time, I shall write to the Department on this matter in connection with all our schools.

I checked over the children's clothing supply and found they were well provided for: The girls have five changes of dresses; the boys three changes; and all have the necessary underwear, socks, etc.

It is not necessary for me to go into detail regarding the work at this institution, as I consider everything is going along satisfactorily. I heard no
complaints whatever regarding this school and I think it is being well managed. The children are well fed and clothed which is quite evident from their appearance. Mr. Sutherland, our Acting Superintendent of Education visited this institution last fall. The enrolment is also very fair now: There are very few children of school age available and every endeavour will be made to recruit them after the holidays.

The building, of course, is in a first class state of repair, although the cement floors are not improving any. Some congooleum rugs were purchased last winter and some battleship linoleum for the halls. I recommended this a year ago last winter when it was not authorized, and did not know it had been furnished until I visited the school this time. The furnishings are all in good shape: This is one thing we can say for the Sisters of Charity, they certainly look after their end of the work and the furnishings are all as good as new. As we have not a lighting plant at this institution, the electricity being supplied from the Town of St. Paul, there is not very much machinery in the school, with the exception of the boilers and laundry machinery. The Principal and the Engineer informed me that this machinery is in a good state of repair, and as far as I could see the engineer seemed to be quite competent.
The pump is in good condition and the school has an ample supply of water, although it is very hard. I shall leave this matter to Mr. Fetterly to deal with.

The school raised an excellent garden last fall and 1000 bushels of potatoes, turnips 150 bushels, peas 25 bushels, beans 30, carrots 14, beets 12, salsifiss 6, parsnips 6, onions 6, sweet corn 2, tomatoes 2, cucumbers 1, table turnips 1, cauliflower 300 heads and cabbages 500 heads, as well as some celery, cress, radishes, &c. They have 12 horses, 1 bul 1, 19 cows, 10 steers 24 yearlings and 10 calves, or 64 head of cattle in all, 70 pigs but no chickens. They have 30 acres in wheat, 50 in oats, 50 in green feed and expect to break 30 acres. This year they are having 1½ acres of garden and 4 acres of potatoes. The Principal expects in a few years to have about 200 acres of land under cultivation. This is about all that can be cultivated without a lot of breaking.

The staff consists of the Principal, Rev. Father Jos. Angin, an Assistant Principal, 11 Sisters of Charity belonging to the Grey Nuns Order, 1 male teacher, 1 engineer, 1 baker and shoe-maker, 1 disciplinarian, 1 farmer, 1 gardener and two labourers.

The children of the school had just recently taken part in a Musical Festival at St. Paul, competing against some 40 or 50 outside schools. There were
three prizes and although they did not participate in any of these, they received favourable mention by the Adjudicators and those who heard them said they had done very well. They sang their songs for me while I was at the school and I thought it was splendid.

The school is very well managed generally, and they have a very efficient staff of Sisters. The finances of the institution are better now as they are raising some crop each year and will soon have sufficient to supply all their own meat.

If the Department have any funds available to buy some paint for interior work in the school, this could be made good use of as some of the walls on the boys' side of the building are beginning to require some decorating. As I have often said, if a little paint is supplied each year the work could be performed by the boys and in this way the walls can always be kept in good condition.

Trusting this report will be of interest to you,

I have the honour to be,
Sir,

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

I checked this matter over and found that this was correct and if this is allowed to continue, we no doubt will have considerable trouble with the water system in a very short time.
